{"Status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "Lens modelling Abell 370: crowning the final frontier field with MUSE", "authors": ["Lagattuta, David J.", "Richard, Johan", "Cl\u00e9ment, Benjamin", "Mahler, Guillaume", "Patr\u00edcio, Vera", "Pell\u00f3, Roser", "Soucail, Genevi\u00e8ve", "Schmidt, Kasper B.", "Wisotzki, Lutz", "Martinez, Johany", "Bina, David"], "author_address": ["AA(Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, Ens de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, F-69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France), AB(Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, Ens de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, F-69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France), AC(Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, Ens de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, F-69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France), AD(Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, Ens de Lyon, CNRS, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon UMR5574, F-69230 Saint-Genis-Laval, France), AE(Univ Lyon, Univ Lyon1, Ens de Lyon, de Toulouse, CNRS, UPS, F-31400 Toulouse, France)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "469", "publication_year": "2017/08/1", "start_page": "3946", "end_page": "3964", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "techniques: imaging spectroscopy", "galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 370", "galaxies: high-redshift", "dark matter", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017MNRAS.469.3946L", "abstract": "We present a strong lensing analysis on the massive cluster Abell 370 (A370; z = 0.375), using a combination of deep multiband Hubble Space Telescope (HST) imaging and Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) spectroscopy. From only 2 h of the MUSE data, we are able to measure 120 redshifts in the southern BCG area, including several multiply imaged lens systems. In total, we increase the number of multiply imaged systems with a secure redshift from 4 to 15, nine of which are newly discovered. Of these, eight are located at z > 3, greatly extending the redshift range of spectroscopically confirmed systems over previous work. Using these systems as constraints, we update a parametric lens model of A370, probing the mass distribution from cluster to galaxy scales. Overall, we find that a model with only two cluster-scale dark matter haloes (one for each BCG) does a poor job of fitting these new image constraints. Instead, two additional mass clumps - a central `bar' of mass located between the BCGs, and another clump located within a `crown' of galaxies in the northern part of the cluster field - provide significant improvements to the fit. Additional physical evidence suggests these clumps are indeed real features of the system, but with relatively few image constraints in the crown region, this claim is difficult to evaluate from a modelling perspective. Additional MUSE observations of A370 covering the entire strong-lensing region will greatly help these efforts, further improving our understanding of this intriguing cluster.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stx1079", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1611.01513", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017MNRAS.469.3946L", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2017MNRAS.469.3946L/PUB_HTML", "Action": "Scanned and processed all tables", "Paper text": "\r\n\r\n\r\n<!DOCTYPE html>\r\n<html lang=\"en\" (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n            hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</section>\r\n        <div class=\"widget widget-SitewideBanner widget-instance-\">\r\n        \r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div id=\"main\"                     <a class=\"linked-name\" href=\"javascript:;\">Lutz Wisotzki</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                        <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap Wisotzki\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\"><span class=\"label\">3</span>Leibniz-Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik Potsdam (AIP), An der Sternwarte 16, D-14482 Potsdam, Germany</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div           </span>\r\n                                    </span>\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-name js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                        <a class=\"linked-name\" href=\"javascript:;\">Johany Martinez</a><span class='delimiter-hidden'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                        <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n                                 <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277354 id=\"88277354\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a strong lensing analysis on the massive cluster Abell 370 (A370; <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.375), using a combination of deep multiband <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) imaging and Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) spectroscopy. From only 2\u00a0h of the MUSE data, we are able to measure 120 redshifts in the southern BCG area, including several multiply imaged lens systems. In total, we increase the number of multiply imaged systems with a secure redshift from 4 to 15, nine of which are newly discovered. Of these, eight are located at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a03, greatly extending the redshift range of spectroscopically confirmed systems over previous work. Using these systems as constraints, we update a parametric lens model of A370, probing the mass distribution from cluster to galaxy scales. Overall, we find that a model with only two cluster-scale dark matter haloes (one for each BCG) does a poor job of fitting these new image constraints. Instead, two additional mass clumps \u2013 a central \u2018bar\u2019 of mass located between the BCGs, and another clump located within a \u2018crown\u2019 of galaxies in the northern part of the cluster field \u2013 provide significant improvements to the fit. Additional physical evidence suggests these clumps are indeed real features of the system, but with relatively few image constraints in the crown region, this claim is difficult to evaluate from a modelling perspective. Additional MUSE observations of A370 covering the entire strong-lensing region will greatly help these efforts, further improving our understanding of this intriguing cluster.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: imaging spectroscopy&quot;\">techniques: imaging spectroscopy</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 370&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 370</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift \u2013 dark matter&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift \u2013 dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277356 id=\"88277356\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy clusters acting as strong gravitational lenses are powerful astrophysical laboratories. The lensed background sources constrain the cluster mass model, providing insight into the mass environments of the densest regions of the Universe (Brada\u010d et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; Hsu, Ebeling &amp; Richard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Massey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). At the same time, the cluster magnifies these sources, making them larger, brighter and better resolved. This allows for more detailed studies of faint, low-mass, high-redshift galaxies, opening a window into the early Universe (Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Sharon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Monna et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Over the past decade, cluster lensing science has significantly expanded, and hundreds of new lensed systems have been discovered (e.g. Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Hoag et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Kawamata et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). This is largely thanks to improved modelling techniques (such as Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a> and Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the efforts of deep, high-resolution imaging campaigns (e.g. Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schmidt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), driven primarily by the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">But while these imaging campaigns are able to identify and resolve background sources like never before, imaging alone does not provide high-precision (\u0394<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.01) redshift information, a crucial component in interpreting models and deriving their physical values. While some spectroscopic campaigns are underway (e.g. Rosati et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), acquiring spectra of lensed systems has, to date, largely been a long, costly and inefficient process. With the advent of Integral Field Unit (IFU) spectroscopy, however, this situation is rapidly changing. Leading the way in these efforts is the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) a wide-field IFU on the Very Large Telescope (VLT) in Chile. With a large 1\u00a0arcmin<sup>2</sup> field of view and high sensitivity between 4800 and 9300 \u00c5, MUSE is an incredibly efficient redshift engine, providing several hundred redshifts between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06 in only a few hours of exposure time (e.g. Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). As an IFU, MUSE is also well suited for blind redshift surveys, able to detect emission lines from continuum-free sources without pre-selecting a redshift range. These objects (which are often missed in traditional broad-band imaging campaigns) include high-redshift, lensed Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emitters. This has been, unsurprisingly, a boon to the lensing community, and some studies have already begun to take advantage of the MUSE data (e.g. Karman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bina et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we present new MUSE data of the strong lensing cluster Abell 370 (A370; Abell <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1958</a>). A370 is a massive cluster (<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>; Umetsu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.375 (Mellier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) with historical significance to lensing: it contains one of the first known \u2018Giant Luminous Arc\u2019 features (Lynds &amp; Petrosian <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>), which later became the first spectroscopically confirmed giant-arc lens system (Soucail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Lynds &amp; Petrosian <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>). Thanks to this discovery, and the identification of other lensed features (Hammer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Paczynski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Fort et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Mellier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>), A370 became an important benchmark in the early days of lens modelling (e.g. Hammer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>; Smail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; B\u00e9zecourt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). However, after an initial period of activity, interest in A370 slowly waned; there was little spectroscopic follow-up on the cluster, and it was not selected to be a part of massive cluster surveys such as MACS (Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) or CLASH (Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), in spite of its high X-ray luminosity (<em>L</em><sub><em>x</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>45</sup>\u00a0erg\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>; Morandi, Ettori &amp; Moscardini <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In 2010, a newly refurbished <em>HST</em> observed A370 to test its deep-imaging capabilities, generating renewed interest. This led to a new lens model (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), additional weak-lensing analyses (Medezinski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Umetsu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and its eventual selection as one of the Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF) clusters (Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Several groups have since modelled the cluster (see the HFF archive<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> and also Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a> and Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), but (until recently) only three lensed systems have had a secure redshift, all with <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.2 (see Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.1.1</a> for details). As a result, these models are only able to probe the critical line region of the cluster out to small radii. While recent work by Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) has increased the number of secure-redshift systems, the highest of these is still <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02. Here, we extend the redshift range of spectroscopically confirmed systems even further and present newly discovered systems as well. By combining the MUSE spectroscopy with the current HFF data, we can therefore improve on existing lens models, probing the mass distribution out to larger scales and with much higher precision. In this way, we can improve our view of this massive cluster in conjunction with the final HFF data release.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overall, this work is organized as follows: in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe the MUSE and HFF data and the data reduction processes we used. In Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, we describe how we extract MUSE redshifts and present the A370 redshift catalogue, paying particular attention to redshifts of the multiply imaged galaxies. Using these redshifts, we construct a new mass model, which we present in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>. We discuss the results of the mass modelling and make predictions for future work in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. Finally, we briefly conclude in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a>. Throughout this paper, we assume a standard cosmological model with \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. Using this model, 1\u00a0arcsec covers a physical distance of 5.162\u00a0kpc at the A370 redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.375). All magnitudes are measured using the AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277362 id=\"88277362\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing is a three-dimensional effect, sensitive to both the transverse and line-of-sight distances between objects. Therefore, we need a combination of imaging data (to identify lensed objects and measure their apparent positions) and redshift data (to measure radial distances) to construct an accurate lens model of A370.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277364 id=\"88277364\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 <em>HST</em> imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> imaging data of A370 were taken as part of the HFF Programme, and are publicly available on the HFF website.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> While the imaging campaign for A370 is now complete, the Epoch 1 (v1.0) mosaics that we use in this work consist of deep Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS; Ford et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) data in three optical bands, <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> (ID: 13504, PI: J. Lotz). These are supplemented by shallower <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> imaging from archival programmes: (ID: 11507, PI: K. Noll) and (ID: 11591, PI: J.-P. Kneib). Additionally, shallow, archival, Wide-Field Camera 3 (Kimble et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) data are available in three bands: <em>F</em>105<em>W</em> (ID: 13459, PI: T. Treu), <em>F</em>140<em>W</em> (ID: 11108, PI: E. Hu; ID: 13459, PI: T. Treu) and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> (ID: 11591, PI: J.-P. Kneib; ID: 14216, PI: R. Kirshner), and a shallow, pilot HF exposure, also in the <em>F</em>140<em>W</em> band.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Individual exposures are reduced and stacked by the HFF team directly, using the standard Pyraf/STSDAS pipeline. Additionally, the ACS mosaics are further corrected with a \u2018self-calibration\u2019 technique to eliminate charge transfer inefficiency effects and low-level pixel noise<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> (J. Anderson, in preparation). The full reduction procedure is described in the A370 HFF data archive.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After combining all exposures, total integration times are 51\u00a0400, 25\u00a0316, 130\u00a0643, 2335, 12\u00a0894 and 9647\u00a0s for the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>105<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>140<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> bands, respectively. This is equivalent to 20, 10, 52, 1, 5 and 4 <em>HST</em> orbits. Collectively, this represents one of the deepest, highest resolution imaging of A370 ever taken, and corresponds to average limiting magnitudes of 29.3 in the optical bands and 27.6 in the near-IR bands. A colour image of the cluster field consisting of the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> mosaics is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277368\" scrollto-destination=\"88277368\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ab472ahmRhqwFr52o8Fd5monWn4d1yp~O1gpd6b~zBFQFN2Q6e9gc8utfnQhif3726jk7Fg6yg4xSUXnmS9zUqnVtdNbX1PHkU~CfqtAZ74UNvk5fiyKUCP7J9vP-wfqKxj~hjYVRbgRxBkpwh6sPbAkF0qDjZ-F0sm2xoWNKgOM1z7piNIUMSum8cIEeOab7Yd2O53nroMHzomlI7IkweBM1t1gJ8Nqxg~eC2cms7CwMZuEkr5sGEc4uQarnAAbQPdtZdr7B3W~KJnjhrJLKK5dLay-hBV3UlqVsEK5pbp9ScoHd7CyseOQDsxjhqx-O1AJJuvF4Tjx71tql23gsA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A colour image of the A370 field of view, using the F435W, F606W and F814W observations from the HFF project. The region of the cluster covered by the MUSE GTO programme is shown in white. In addition, the positions of the multiply imaged systems used as constraints in the mass model (Section 4) are shown as coloured circles. Previously known systems are in red, while newly identified objects are in green. Images predicted by the model but not detected in either imaging or spectroscopic data are shown in yellow.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277368/stx1079fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277368\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=J1LOOC7EXomm3DmHjoI53xQktbuy4KTwAUqpPeDfQe151DDXaNrT5s9ceN2lQLVNsJR4krgQaUpWuuXcNm8j~tq6gSNyZpa2i5xFYnaNyK23Ly6cmgpYkkxaOmL-8LZIU48eAaJBc0LBKNIxK8TY~NF8bLWmcn4GnoKUYyU~0h-7Rqi-mLW2MOgju~RDPQ5UJLntrBhOUo6j6jMjZ6ANj4O~Kd8UCJ3OmsG4lxx3NnJrVmrq5shkvoMEYCbOdNJApPTtDj-3cMOycIwsgtCEnzF~kVEqtvvr~B7tYDlDk~GkfLGILPhfiks1H6srdCIz7MECh4KXoJ3-iZYHi-Zuww__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277368&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A colour image of the A370 field of view, using the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> observations from the HFF project. The region of the cluster covered by the MUSE GTO programme is shown in white. In addition, the positions of the multiply imaged systems used as constraints in the mass model (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>) are shown as coloured circles. Previously known systems are in red, while newly identified objects are in green. Images predicted by the model but not detected in either imaging or spectroscopic data are shown in yellow.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ab472ahmRhqwFr52o8Fd5monWn4d1yp~O1gpd6b~zBFQFN2Q6e9gc8utfnQhif3726jk7Fg6yg4xSUXnmS9zUqnVtdNbX1PHkU~CfqtAZ74UNvk5fiyKUCP7J9vP-wfqKxj~hjYVRbgRxBkpwh6sPbAkF0qDjZ-F0sm2xoWNKgOM1z7piNIUMSum8cIEeOab7Yd2O53nroMHzomlI7IkweBM1t1gJ8Nqxg~eC2cms7CwMZuEkr5sGEc4uQarnAAbQPdtZdr7B3W~KJnjhrJLKK5dLay-hBV3UlqVsEK5pbp9ScoHd7CyseOQDsxjhqx-O1AJJuvF4Tjx71tql23gsA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A colour image of the A370 field of view, using the F435W, F606W and F814W observations from the HFF project. The region of the cluster covered by the MUSE GTO programme is shown in white. In addition, the positions of the multiply imaged systems used as constraints in the mass model (Section 4) are shown as coloured circles. Previously known systems are in red, while newly identified objects are in green. Images predicted by the model but not detected in either imaging or spectroscopic data are shown in yellow.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277368/stx1079fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277368\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=J1LOOC7EXomm3DmHjoI53xQktbuy4KTwAUqpPeDfQe151DDXaNrT5s9ceN2lQLVNsJR4krgQaUpWuuXcNm8j~tq6gSNyZpa2i5xFYnaNyK23Ly6cmgpYkkxaOmL-8LZIU48eAaJBc0LBKNIxK8TY~NF8bLWmcn4GnoKUYyU~0h-7Rqi-mLW2MOgju~RDPQ5UJLntrBhOUo6j6jMjZ6ANj4O~Kd8UCJ3OmsG4lxx3NnJrVmrq5shkvoMEYCbOdNJApPTtDj-3cMOycIwsgtCEnzF~kVEqtvvr~B7tYDlDk~GkfLGILPhfiks1H6srdCIz7MECh4KXoJ3-iZYHi-Zuww__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277368&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A colour image of the A370 field of view, using the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> observations from the HFF project. The region of the cluster covered by the MUSE GTO programme is shown in white. In addition, the positions of the multiply imaged systems used as constraints in the mass model (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>) are shown as coloured circles. Previously known systems are in red, while newly identified objects are in green. Images predicted by the model but not detected in either imaging or spectroscopic data are shown in yellow.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277369 id=\"88277369\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 MUSE spectroscopy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MUSE observations of A370 were taken on <span class=\"small-caps\">UT</span> 2014 November 20, as part of the Guaranteed Time Observing (GTO) Programme 094.A-0115(A) (PI: Richard). In total, we observed four 30-min exposures in WFM-NOAO-N mode, centred at (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a02<sup>h</sup> 39<sup>m</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$53{^{\\rm s}_{.}}111$|\u2060</span>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121\u00b0 34<sup>\u0384</sup> 55<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>77). We applied a small (\u223c 0.5\u00a0arcsec) dither pattern between exposures to average out systematics on the detector, and we alternated taking exposures between PA = 0\u00b0 and PA = 8\u00b0 to reduce the systematic striping pattern caused by the IFU image slicers. The full observational footprint can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Typical field of view during the observations was 0.75\u00a0arcsec, as measured by stars in the field.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The raw data were reduced through the MUSE pipeline (Weilbacher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) provided by ESO (version 1.2). This pipeline performs all basic reduction techniques: bias and flat-field correction (using a combination of internal flats and illumination and twilight exposures), wavelength and geometric calibration, sky subtraction, flux calibration and telluric correction. The A370 data were flux-calibrated using a combination of several standard stars observed under photometric conditions. After basic corrections, we align individual exposures to a common world coordinate system (WCS) with <span class=\"small-caps\">scamp</span> (Bertin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), shifting each frame relative to a reference image, which in this case is the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> HFF data. We then transform the re-aligned images into data cubes, resampling all pixels on to a common three-dimensional grid with two spatial and one spectral axis. The final spectral resolution of the cubes varies from <em>R</em> = 2000 to <em>R</em> = 4000, with a spectral range between 4750 and 9350 \u00c5. To ensure that cubes are properly Nyquist-sampled, we set the wavelength grid to 1.25 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. The final spatial resolution is 0.2\u00a0arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> in order to properly sample the PSF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we process each cube with the Zurich Atmosphere Purge (<span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span>; Soto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), a software package that uses a principal component analysis technique to remove known systematics from the sky model, further improving sky-subtraction residuals. To account for changes in sky transmittance from exposure to exposure, we compare the fluxes of stars common to each cube. The cube with the brightest flux values is taken as a new photometric standard, and we scale the zero-points of the other cubes until the fluxes agree across all exposures. We then merge all cubes together to create a combined master cube. During the merging process, we apply a 3\u03c3 clipping routine to reject outliers, eliminating cosmic ray strikes and hot pixels on the detector. As a final step, we re-run the <span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span> process on the master cube in order to eliminate low-level sky residuals that can only be seen in the improved signal-to-noise ratio of the combined data.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277373 id=\"88277373\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 REDSHIFT MEASUREMENT AND SPECTROSCOPIC CATALOGUE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After reducing the data, we probe the MUSE cube for redshifts using two complementary techniques: (1) an automated emission line detection program, and (2) a customized, interactive data visualization tool designed to extract MUSE aperture spectra by hand.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The automated program, <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> is included as part of the Muse Python Data Analysis Framework (<span class=\"small-caps\">mpdaf</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a>) version 2.0. It first creates narrow-band images of the data, averaging the flux over a narrow emission wavelength range and then subtracting a local continuum. For the A370 cube, we choose an emission window of 6.25 \u00c5 (spanning five MUSE wavelength slices), with each window centred on one of the original wavelength planes. The continuum is created by averaging two 25 \u00c5 slices, immediately bluewards and redwards of the emission window. After creating the narrow-band images, <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> uses Source Extractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) to identify emission features in each image, then merges these features together into a final master catalogue. Emission features at different wavelengths are considered to belong to the same source if they fall within 0.8\u00a0arcsec of each other (i.e. within the seeing FWHM) in the case of continuum-free detections, or if they fall within half of the effective radius (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>/2) of a continuum-emission object. For every source that has multiple emission lines identified, <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> fits a redshift using a template of known spectral lines. To ensure the accuracy of the <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> fit, we manually inspect the line features of each identified redshift before adding it to the final catalogue.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In cases where an obvious galaxy appears in the <em>HST</em> image or MUSE cube but is undetected (absorption galaxies) or unclassified (single emission-line galaxies) by <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>, we instead use the interactive tool. The tool, a custom-made <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> script, collapses the data cube along the wavelength axis, creating a \u2018white-light\u2019 image of the field. A second panel, matched to the WCS of the cube, shows a corresponding <em>HST</em> image to help identify the target galaxy. Once a galaxy has been identified, a user can draw a (circular or rectangular) aperture around the target object, which will extract both a 2D and 1D spectrum from the cube. From these spectra, the user can then interactively fit a redshift to the galaxy, using the same set of lines as the automatic line-finder. An example of this process can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. As an additional check, we run the redshift-measuring software <span class=\"small-caps\">autoz</span> (Baldry et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) on the extracted 1D spectrum. In all cases, we find the difference between the manual and <span class=\"small-caps\">autoz</span> fits to be less than \u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.001.</p>                        <a id=\"88277377\" scrollto-destination=\"88277377\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=sS~aQN1fpFw4hGlVozcs0lzI-IvDN1-MWDSLAqSAbDOtXQQ1nAZquugK~udiMp3o2fRfCVSghIPdpK0u8uaY0jNq0LXGFfGcB68CRvJS-MJOiI~KpRbav5R-NPtWgQItYkvwoDcM6Q3fdwoaBYekq5tL~ax5DatcC~qanx8~LWAFaRtk9bb~iTKxGRQj7VES1wlEz8-y64rtPDgB2SKA08ri4sZENZqGvuVLYLo4os-b8He-bDlsQF3SlHoS~~Wo2M6VxOnPa~u84lz02Weh1frEw4flWKxnUDZYk9snYnd0wPV5mL6QYHuBXIRDy2fEVCty5J-QOD19rWvNrrQZBw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sample spectrum extracted by our interactive Python tool. Here, we see Image 14.1, a newly detected Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emitter at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a03.1309. The Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emission is clearly detected in the spectrum and is double-peaked.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277377/stx1079fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277377\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=by1hJj~nTcjgrmE8Zxxc40FLyEDU1X0bgGSl120kPYN4v9jXHRkPG4KgBt0btPtoZaBJEKUMXYP1C43dEtdcNa5O6HaA2HLtAjNc0wOaptjBBaPtVHuti-Dc5iYD6Dtdm9ID6x2p11BSPs2uxitI0DGVeRr4uh4aFoVuzR0IcjMoyIPzdqQDqyFLC~wJNzu2RDOg-sOsa3HPAzFm~3vzhPI2Pk79RNywaOQ8P2yk3SeCPlCpL6JG3ZMYKmxKQHBENbbr5AnuM0eAa4GH7EXoxx6l21Qi8wUUCvimQzHLwztGx0jhhsuHLr~wnAzqTlpOMHCmetigLd1XZzfD84Kgfg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277377&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sample spectrum extracted by our interactive Python tool. The Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emission is clearly detected in the spectrum and is double-peaked.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=sS~aQN1fpFw4hGlVozcs0lzI-IvDN1-MWDSLAqSAbDOtXQQ1nAZquugK~udiMp3o2fRfCVSghIPdpK0u8uaY0jNq0LXGFfGcB68CRvJS-MJOiI~KpRbav5R-NPtWgQItYkvwoDcM6Q3fdwoaBYekq5tL~ax5DatcC~qanx8~LWAFaRtk9bb~iTKxGRQj7VES1wlEz8-y64rtPDgB2SKA08ri4sZENZqGvuVLYLo4os-b8He-bDlsQF3SlHoS~~Wo2M6VxOnPa~u84lz02Weh1frEw4flWKxnUDZYk9snYnd0wPV5mL6QYHuBXIRDy2fEVCty5J-QOD19rWvNrrQZBw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sample spectrum extracted by our interactive Python tool. Here, we see Image 14.1, a newly detected Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emitter at redshift z\u00a0=\u00a03.1309. The Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emission is clearly detected in the spectrum and is double-peaked.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277377/stx1079fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277377\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=by1hJj~nTcjgrmE8Zxxc40FLyEDU1X0bgGSl120kPYN4v9jXHRkPG4KgBt0btPtoZaBJEKUMXYP1C43dEtdcNa5O6HaA2HLtAjNc0wOaptjBBaPtVHuti-Dc5iYD6Dtdm9ID6x2p11BSPs2uxitI0DGVeRr4uh4aFoVuzR0IcjMoyIPzdqQDqyFLC~wJNzu2RDOg-sOsa3HPAzFm~3vzhPI2Pk79RNywaOQ8P2yk3SeCPlCpL6JG3ZMYKmxKQHBENbbr5AnuM0eAa4GH7EXoxx6l21Qi8wUUCvimQzHLwztGx0jhhsuHLr~wnAzqTlpOMHCmetigLd1XZzfD84Kgfg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277377&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sample spectrum extracted by our interactive Python tool. Here, we see Image 14.1, a newly detected Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emitter at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1309. The Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emission is clearly detected in the spectrum and is double-peaked.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">After running both methods on the A370 cube, we combine all of the redshift results into a final catalogue. Overall, we securely identify 120 redshifts, consisting of multiply imaged systems, cluster members, foreground interlopers, background sources and stars. The spatial and spectral distributions of these redshifts are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277379\" scrollto-destination=\"88277379\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=d1HIVXe~OcxQ2Tz~UOpzlvvJ1KR-44FcefZHak8O0yGixSGivZzHBYHNnewNQt9Y3cMIa77ROD6RHjz58URj-B6pcC5DwQ6kH7~VoEnfXDuSWlwaFdsVU24uBfqxrsZxxoEVnkjkJYve4gxCp-f8NQ4bsjqEKZbS1NjN4Jy~zPDanlaSJKr2cR7ukcizhwKAHSyWlyb1~VblBoxTLv13Vr6jBMMnY88CbsRkOWZjQ~UYvD~8cNMwLn8rehxTQwZexVt0TnhLLZxjkGwPDHs1XvU1f4hw2mSE4eHYqEZCBT7kw~v5OP-FfuZngf6e6ruZe76cEvT3n8ehk4P~7OLa5g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: positions of all objects with a secured redshift in the MUSE GTO cube. The colour of each circle represents the object's type and redshift range, according to the following scheme. Purple: star (z\u00a0=\u00a00), blue: foreground galaxy (0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0z\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.35), green: cluster member (0.35 \u2264 z \u2264 0.4), yellow: [O\u00a0ii] emitter (0.4\u00a0&lt;\u00a0z\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5), orange: [C\u00a0iii] emitter (1.5 \u2264 z\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.0), red: Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitter (z \u2265 3.0). Object labels correspond to entries in Table\u00a01 (multiply imaged systems), Table\u00a02 (cluster members) and Table\u00a03 (foreground and background objects). Bottom left: redshift distribution of all singly imaged systems in the cube. The colour scheme is the same as in the position map. A clear overdensity of galaxies can be seen at the cluster redshift range, as expected. Bottom right: similar redshift distribution, but for the multiply imaged systems. Solid colour lines represent individual systems, while the hashed lines represent all the counterimages that make up these systems.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277379/stx1079fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277379\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=I4pXNXkpX9zwVViIxrE~tZiZJm8qys7Rh-EKU7KZEavmpFBeyncpNWkbbfgxbR3Pv6O5LWd9B4iTxLCybO2VOC7CdG6Q1UF~IvqHupIJX-W-LpZ3U0KVdJZYncj4Q7P7~tmi313zhrguVNyx6~v1Ey~aLfDihicXIJibbuhm~uUmIUdl67h-7WoCulOJimpaq1hf29dmaMKHLoE8w2PdrucZEa4kGbhnSCyR6c8hYIzXv1hYPBILPRYdLUis9TC~X0K7i8w84DX1jEZ~dAJiL1lC5T35ZXAbmJVM0RC7mOoY1xKN7JtoJ3TYpTNcLTflf7ZpFAsS~N5S7Ke4cujFdQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277379&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: positions of all objects with a secured redshift in the MUSE GTO cube. The colour of each circle represents the object's type and redshift range, according to the following scheme. Purple: star (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00), blue: foreground galaxy (0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.35), green: cluster member (0.35 \u2264 <em>z</em> \u2264 0.4), yellow: [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitter (0.4\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5), orange: [C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emitter (1.5 \u2264 <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.0), red: Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitter (<em>z</em> \u2265 3.0). Bottom left: redshift distribution of all singly imaged systems in the cube. The colour scheme is the same as in the position map. A clear overdensity of galaxies can be seen at the cluster redshift range, as expected. Bottom right: similar redshift distribution, but for the multiply imaged systems. Solid colour lines represent individual systems, while the hashed lines represent all the counterimages that make up these systems.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=d1HIVXe~OcxQ2Tz~UOpzlvvJ1KR-44FcefZHak8O0yGixSGivZzHBYHNnewNQt9Y3cMIa77ROD6RHjz58URj-B6pcC5DwQ6kH7~VoEnfXDuSWlwaFdsVU24uBfqxrsZxxoEVnkjkJYve4gxCp-f8NQ4bsjqEKZbS1NjN4Jy~zPDanlaSJKr2cR7ukcizhwKAHSyWlyb1~VblBoxTLv13Vr6jBMMnY88CbsRkOWZjQ~UYvD~8cNMwLn8rehxTQwZexVt0TnhLLZxjkGwPDHs1XvU1f4hw2mSE4eHYqEZCBT7kw~v5OP-FfuZngf6e6ruZe76cEvT3n8ehk4P~7OLa5g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: positions of all objects with a secured redshift in the MUSE GTO cube. The colour of each circle represents the object's type and redshift range, according to the following scheme. Purple: star (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00), blue: foreground galaxy (0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.35), green: cluster member (0.35 \u2264 <em>z</em> \u2264 0.4), yellow: [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitter (0.4\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5), orange: [C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emitter (1.5 \u2264 <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.0), red: Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitter (<em>z</em> \u2265 3.0). Object labels correspond to entries in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> (multiply imaged systems), Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> (cluster members) and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (foreground and background objects). Bottom left: redshift distribution of all singly imaged systems in the cube. The colour scheme is the same as in the position map. A clear overdensity of galaxies can be seen at the cluster redshift range, as expected. Bottom right: similar redshift distribution, but for the multiply imaged systems. Solid colour lines represent individual systems, while the hashed lines represent all the counterimages that make up these systems.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277380 id=\"88277380\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Multiply imaged systems</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiply imaged background sources are particularly important in this work, since they provide strong constraints on the lensing mass model (see Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>). Using a combination of the HFF imaging and the MUSE spectroscopy, we are able to identify and confirm the redshifts of previously known multi-image systems and identify new systems as well.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=88277382 id=\"88277382\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 Previously known systems</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Prior to the release of the newest HFF and MUSE data, 13 multi-image objects were identified in the A370 field (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) including three with known redshifts: Systems 1 (Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>), 2 (Soucail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) and 6 (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). A tentative guess for System 4 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.275) using the VLT/FORS2 grism spectroscopy was also presented in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Of these systems, seven have at least one image that falls within the MUSE A370 footprint: Systems 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 9. Using the MUSE data, we are able to confirm the previous redshifts of Systems 1 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.8041), 2 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.7251) and 6 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.0633), refine and secure the redshift for System 4 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2728) and provide new redshifts for Systems 5 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2775) and 7 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.7512). We note that these new redshifts are within 2\u03c3 of the values predicted in the Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) lens model (System 4: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.34 \u00b1 0.03; System 5: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.30 \u00b1 0.05; System 7: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a04.97 \u00b1 1.17), a reasonably good agreement. We are unable to identify any strong features in System 9 because it is too faint for a secure measurement. However, Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) identify [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] features for the system in the <em>HST</em> grism spectroscopy, placing it at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.52. We note that this redshift is consistent with a non-detection in MUSE, since it falls in the \u2018redshift desert\u2019 where no strong emission features appear in the MUSE wavelength range. Additionally, Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) also identify faint [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission for System 3 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.95. We adopt these redshift values in this work, also.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=88277384 id=\"88277384\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 New systems</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the known objects, we also identify nine new multiply imaged systems in the MUSE field (Systems 14\u201322). Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) independently identify four of these systems: 14, 20, 21 and 22 (labelled Systems 10, 29, 26 and 18, respectively, in their work) though without spectroscopic redshifts. With the exception of System 21 (identified by [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]), these new systems are all strong Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emitters, located at considerably higher redshifts (3\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a06) than those previously identified. Systems 14 and 22 are particularly interesting, as they are reasonably close together and have an identical redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1309). This suggests that they could be an interacting pair of galaxies, and indeed, narrow-band imaging shows that the emission-line regions of the two are clearly overlapping (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). Careful observation of the HFF data reveals at least some flux associated with each of the new systems in broad-band imaging, but in some cases \u2013 especially Systems 15 and 16 \u2013 this flux is extremely faint and contaminated by brighter objects nearby. Spectra of all systems in the MUSE field of view are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5a\" data-open=\"fig5a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The full list of multiply imaged systems, including all identified and/or model-predicted counterimages of a given system, is presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277386\" scrollto-destination=\"88277386\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=dgwCce5qb0wXeSO461VAq0grIhLTb~lDNbQeJgV~ybNTChzPoYGQmpgkOWnCQ0LXMy6BTraj5spqmNC5DtbzUku29uoyTvo8eOiFAMHb-eLuazwnSM4fs06zCiZxZqukcxXMV65oR6HXOQoR3bB1R5ez8~ZoV0MrWeyePEYmSDFsfLswOLma1xiAwV0SnUYrA4HOPeFSNPfeTAGB3ojDBcnroF0GR6IMnoW6mN6JngWo9U-T5RJuSaZ95vYbVYT0OKeD251PJNicQ5mw0ec4y9cUYsNteaAMXAO7lL0W6C4vWl3OzLBDm15h~V6AotWeKb~ReL9QqoSvx0XKsZ2c3g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Close-up of the area containing Images 14.3 and 22.1, two newly identified, multiply imaged, Lyman\u00a0\u03b1-emitting galaxies. While the HST imaging alone shows that the two galaxies are in close proximity to one another and have similar colours, new spectroscopy from MUSE reveals that they have exactly the same redshift (z\u00a0=\u00a03.1309). Additionally, narrow-band imaging of the emission line (green contours) shows that there is a significant overlap between the galaxies\u2019 Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes, suggesting that the two galaxies could be interacting.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277386/stx1079fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277386\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=FjFSMkQIG4c3zM0N-M9zgt-Z64djoJ5DY2SBRQCpMCaGwiBV1NIOO0Ivf68851ZkW3X7tdSSXsk9FBoVBwKG6poKz5bv6dphWPVgKEANxhBG0DcYm8zz7gbRdeuMe9hCJtthucMgECG2tvpkYyvDHHPkNdMOWWrty3xAz6211j5qGraMASTovKTRGTD6HJXa~XUDWtqrNExKivAZbJcbrYMasIAMyWkk-CF474zhiF9w1Iv1xoQUHsfH0~5Y0lwejD7eu5O-LZihDZi4mY7nlCDs9sK894QJwTi85LPphKGaEY0WK5xN8JFxQUp5~cRmcjlL6EGeg3mBAiFDYywVBA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277386&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Close-up of the area containing Images 14.3 and 22.1, two newly identified, multiply imaged, Lyman\u00a0\u03b1-emitting galaxies. While the <em>HST</em> imaging alone shows that the two galaxies are in close proximity to one another and have similar colours, new spectroscopy from MUSE reveals that they have exactly the same redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1309). Additionally, narrow-band imaging of the emission line (green contours) shows that there is a significant overlap between the galaxies\u2019 Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes, suggesting that the two galaxies could be interacting.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=dgwCce5qb0wXeSO461VAq0grIhLTb~lDNbQeJgV~ybNTChzPoYGQmpgkOWnCQ0LXMy6BTraj5spqmNC5DtbzUku29uoyTvo8eOiFAMHb-eLuazwnSM4fs06zCiZxZqukcxXMV65oR6HXOQoR3bB1R5ez8~ZoV0MrWeyePEYmSDFsfLswOLma1xiAwV0SnUYrA4HOPeFSNPfeTAGB3ojDBcnroF0GR6IMnoW6mN6JngWo9U-T5RJuSaZ95vYbVYT0OKeD251PJNicQ5mw0ec4y9cUYsNteaAMXAO7lL0W6C4vWl3OzLBDm15h~V6AotWeKb~ReL9QqoSvx0XKsZ2c3g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Close-up of the area containing Images 14.3 and 22.1, two newly identified, multiply imaged, Lyman\u00a0\u03b1-emitting galaxies. While the HST imaging alone shows that the two galaxies are in close proximity to one another and have similar colours, new spectroscopy from MUSE reveals that they have exactly the same redshift (z\u00a0=\u00a03.1309). Additionally, narrow-band imaging of the emission line (green contours) shows that there is a significant overlap between the galaxies\u2019 Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes, suggesting that the two galaxies could be interacting.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277386/stx1079fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277386\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=FjFSMkQIG4c3zM0N-M9zgt-Z64djoJ5DY2SBRQCpMCaGwiBV1NIOO0Ivf68851ZkW3X7tdSSXsk9FBoVBwKG6poKz5bv6dphWPVgKEANxhBG0DcYm8zz7gbRdeuMe9hCJtthucMgECG2tvpkYyvDHHPkNdMOWWrty3xAz6211j5qGraMASTovKTRGTD6HJXa~XUDWtqrNExKivAZbJcbrYMasIAMyWkk-CF474zhiF9w1Iv1xoQUHsfH0~5Y0lwejD7eu5O-LZihDZi4mY7nlCDs9sK894QJwTi85LPphKGaEY0WK5xN8JFxQUp5~cRmcjlL6EGeg3mBAiFDYywVBA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277386&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Close-up of the area containing Images 14.3 and 22.1, two newly identified, multiply imaged, Lyman\u00a0\u03b1-emitting galaxies. While the <em>HST</em> imaging alone shows that the two galaxies are in close proximity to one another and have similar colours, new spectroscopy from MUSE reveals that they have exactly the same redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1309). Additionally, narrow-band imaging of the emission line (green contours) shows that there is a significant overlap between the galaxies\u2019 Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes, suggesting that the two galaxies could be interacting.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"88277387\" scrollto-destination=\"88277387\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5a\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=KtrmInZMO1H2XNJMkXRmz-f4qse~JwPi007RAkH8dEG2e-RKMptZljxdlZ5NgN-bBM1E8KgFSOlwVNWCb8r14lfN8gb5BPW2IglCmCEn9WFx6SoPLwt9b-vO~fe5jj-jsVI33uImrpuKZeG7vn5iavBlx5PRnH52HTttPF1mgdxd4rYDDWC7fGPxua2iIHsgXocr4VfPRUom9JvilNrki17xbmiZK2DrNWE6lIIDh4DeVVlWsQXhIy0ysFP~~cY3OFUGRPeiGkOJyhYMIPdFTPuavCfKJ6qzYYnhPLf~98NLVJucwrkcPwPdk6Bszqcsukcy9NdXZwf9~9WBxrU~9A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"(a) Multiply imaged systems with MUSE spectroscopy. Individual members of a given system (constraints) are labelled according to Table\u00a01. In the top panels, we show colour images of each constraint, using the F435W/F606W/F814W HFF bands for the RGB channels of the figure. The one exception is System 6, which instead uses a colour scheme of F435W/F814W/F160W to better highlight its morphology. Green contours represent the 1\u03c3, 3\u03c3 and 5\u03c3 (per pixel) levels of the brightest emission line seen in narrow-band imaging of the MUSE data cube. Cutouts of the extracted spectra, again centred on the brightest emission line, are shown in the bottom panel. The label colour of a given constraint matches the colour of its corresponding spectrum. Constraints that fall outside of the MUSE field of view, and thus have no MUSE spectroscopy, are labelled in white. With the exception of System 16, which includes the undetected Image 16.2, only image constraints used in the A370 mass model are displayed here. Model predictions outside of the MUSE footprint where we find no obvious HST counterpart are not shown. For merging pairs of images (Images 5.3/5.4, 7.1/7.2 and 21.1/21.2) we use a common extraction region for both spectra. The combined spectrum of both images then appears as a single line in the plot. (b) New MUSE-identified systems. The contours seen in Image 14.3 are identical to those in Fig.\u00a04, highlighting the overlap between the Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes of Images 14.3 and 22.1. (c) The final three MUSE-identified systems. We again see the overlap between the Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes of Images 14.3 and 22.1.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig5a.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277387/stx1079fig5a.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig5a.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277387\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=uC28-pXnUEAf8qMxmiCxWhLXJFcMDMAwCu2Gfuxa5DmJFyHehUoeb~cv5bP0pvAWdgLoe6h6pVG4F9tY79mREVHtj2PS9tA1mxD8GyHP8UePElilmc4~n54OAaXNriO8r5qto3pD5rovq-d1APRY6Ob~QMPIi4lEqHwx5aqc5qsaq8ysGEdOAfVvcV62FenczgjWbGjz4ZG4G7ewSaa6tpDt7sdFzlzTmhZoMoz6-f4iLVg9PGy7udrU1aGUre~JhL6pFz7jw6AKnzK0~XBGSbtiWIntW~gt9xAAEYjSNkrY0dAyEKipi0Yt0E-mYUsDKxYrOWg3ztXGev6eRweVwg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277387&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig5a.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(a) Multiply imaged systems with MUSE spectroscopy. Individual members of a given system (constraints) are labelled according to Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. In the top panels, we show colour images of each constraint, using the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>/<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>/<em>F</em>814<em>W</em> HFF bands for the RGB channels of the figure. The one exception is System 6, which instead uses a colour scheme of <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>/<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>/<em>F</em>160<em>W</em> to better highlight its morphology. Cutouts of the extracted spectra, again centred on the brightest emission line, are shown in the bottom panel. The label colour of a given constraint matches the colour of its corresponding spectrum. Constraints that fall outside of the MUSE field of view, and thus have no MUSE spectroscopy, are labelled in white. With the exception of System 16, which includes the undetected Image 16.2, only image constraints used in the A370 mass model are displayed here. Model predictions outside of the MUSE footprint where we find no obvious <em>HST</em> counterpart are not shown. For merging pairs of images (Images 5.3/5.4, 7.1/7.2 and 21.1/21.2) we use a common extraction region for both spectra. The combined spectrum of both images then appears as a single line in the plot. (b) New MUSE-identified systems. (c) The final three MUSE-identified systems. We again see the overlap between the Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes of Images 14.3 and 22.1.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5a\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=KtrmInZMO1H2XNJMkXRmz-f4qse~JwPi007RAkH8dEG2e-RKMptZljxdlZ5NgN-bBM1E8KgFSOlwVNWCb8r14lfN8gb5BPW2IglCmCEn9WFx6SoPLwt9b-vO~fe5jj-jsVI33uImrpuKZeG7vn5iavBlx5PRnH52HTttPF1mgdxd4rYDDWC7fGPxua2iIHsgXocr4VfPRUom9JvilNrki17xbmiZK2DrNWE6lIIDh4DeVVlWsQXhIy0ysFP~~cY3OFUGRPeiGkOJyhYMIPdFTPuavCfKJ6qzYYnhPLf~98NLVJucwrkcPwPdk6Bszqcsukcy9NdXZwf9~9WBxrU~9A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"(a) Multiply imaged systems with MUSE spectroscopy. class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Images labelled with an asterisk (*) fall outside of the MUSE cube and do not have secure redshifts. We identify them in the HFF data, using the A370 mass model as a guide.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Images in italics are predicted by the model, but no suitable counterimage is seen in the <em>HST</em> data. We do not include these images as model constraints, but we present them here for completeness. Image 16.2, which is in the MUSE field of view but predicted to fall behind a bright cluster galaxy, is also included here, since it is undetected in MUSE.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Redshifts enclosed in braces ({}) are fit by the model as free parameters. The fit range is given in the \u2018<em>z</em> range\u2019 column.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Redshifts for these systems are taken from Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277390\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\"
