class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Images labelled with an asterisk (*) fall outside of the MUSE cube and do not have secure redshifts. We identify them in the HFF data, using the A370 mass model as a guide.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Images in italics are predicted by the model, but no suitable counterimage is seen in the <em>HST</em> data. We do not include these images as model constraints, but we present them here for completeness. Image 16.2, which is in the MUSE field of view but predicted to fall behind a bright cluster galaxy, is also included here, since it is undetected in MUSE.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Redshifts enclosed in braces ({}) are fit by the model as free parameters. The fit range is given in the \u2018<em>z</em> range\u2019 column.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Redshifts for these systems are taken from Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277390\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277391 id=\"88277391\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Cluster members</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster members make up the largest subgroup in the spectroscopic catalogue, with 56 confirmed redshifts. To identify cluster members, we select all galaxies that fall between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.35 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4, a \u03b4<em>v</em>\u00a0=\u00a015\u2009000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> cut in velocity space centred on the A370 central redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.375). In the overall redshift catalogue, these boundaries naturally separate the cluster overdensity from all other objects, and a large fraction of galaxies in this range fall on both the (<em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>) and (<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>) red sequences. While a majority of objects are passive, elliptical galaxies showing only absorption features, some do show strong [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and/or H\u2009\u03b1 emission. Of these emission-line galaxies, CL49 (located close to the bright, foreground spiral F12) is unique, as it is the only detected cluster member in the MUSE field of view without an <em>HST</em> counterpart (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). Strangely, the object also appears to have a divergent velocity field: moving in either direction along the long axis, the flux becomes more and more redshifted relative to the centre. We do not have an explanation for this behaviour at this time, though it would be interesting to revisit in future work.</p>                        <a id=\"88277393\" scrollto-destination=\"88277393\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=f-Ko32PAiy8tia41fLhLc60Uy5qRQ5SCD~VNWobU3ljm~nDlXapYlwZ-xBMzQVMkFsDY91eoC5YWOYM5egAAhzWCzAWmXw5kcqRMZ5xrwQj5Hu5~4odlcQji93Q4liS-8bWs6DdBRZcRCVnjcuAsqRhaFF6E2lBL5yk0z1hi6L3FlndnE8awan-ZoAegmkB00mzPxMbVx9jPqdkBOPNKnfOt8dRCfq~SlWKC2wpNPrlxwcqQTCyNQpSPbH~zBjtOu4H8r4FSoPb~TMDlSKf9-Oe2MQN8-xyUicLbNbQp5pwJCHBmxjld1-FcUrlrQxZSNlDp5d2ct7afGAHLX6OYJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cluster member CL49, an emission-line object (z\u00a0=\u00a00.3843) not seen in broad-band HST imaging. The estimated centroid of the object is shown as a green circle, while the cyan and red contours trace the 1\u03c3, 3\u03c3 and 5\u03c3 (per pixel) regions of [O\u00a0ii] and H\u00a0\u03b1 emission, respectively. Curiously, the long axis of emission seems to have a divergent velocity field, as the flux at either end is slightly redshifted relative to the centre.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277393/stx1079fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277393\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=GJtderB0WESJ6kUXga0reD0ARwdXaXxQoGDjY-kaX75isEfMWHG-7VITrZupDLlVfRlvLtgtC8ybmGp7SoO0FfPtw2sFDRtS0o2GeoVNLDSixCpxg6psDq5nroq7dBaHyeR1xGfZHZcw8UKUrRbZuJPSB94-VlVqh2c7MIj6gLMGE8u017bA9briXDsaGv2OWDWYlHQZKgvfAheu~4NQUgciAgnqYotA1cyxdihBPLYJ5uL1qyYiv0-K-gTETVfB~tUM-1oJiMbCoFWyE8BmDYV~NfYuoBR6T5UZrB7Euc5LmEia2mJvJQlGfDP1UHTdkEiaj3fUKRTmbeMzQpSJyQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277393&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster member CL49, an emission-line object (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3843) not seen in broad-band <em>HST</em> imaging. The estimated centroid of the object is shown as a green circle, while the cyan and red contours trace the 1\u03c3, 3\u03c3 and 5\u03c3 (per pixel) regions of [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and H\u00a0\u03b1 emission, respectively. Curiously, the long axis of emission seems to have a divergent velocity field, as the flux at either end is slightly redshifted relative to the centre.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=f-Ko32PAiy8tia41fLhLc60Uy5qRQ5SCD~VNWobU3ljm~nDlXapYlwZ-xBMzQVMkFsDY91eoC5YWOYM5egAAhzWCzAWmXw5kcqRMZ5xrwQj5Hu5~4odlcQji93Q4liS-8bWs6DdBRZcRCVnjcuAsqRhaFF6E2lBL5yk0z1hi6L3FlndnE8awan-ZoAegmkB00mzPxMbVx9jPqdkBOPNKnfOt8dRCfq~SlWKC2wpNPrlxwcqQTCyNQpSPbH~zBjtOu4H8r4FSoPb~TMDlSKf9-Oe2MQN8-xyUicLbNbQp5pwJCHBmxjld1-FcUrlrQxZSNlDp5d2ct7afGAHLX6OYJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cluster member CL49, an emission-line object (z\u00a0=\u00a00.3843) not seen in broad-band HST imaging. The estimated centroid of the object is shown as a green circle, while the cyan and red contours trace the 1\u03c3, 3\u03c3 and 5\u03c3 (per pixel) regions of [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and H\u00a0\u03b1 emission, respectively. Curiously, the long axis of emission seems to have a divergent velocity field, as the flux at either end is slightly redshifted relative to the centre.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster galaxy positions are represented by green circles in the top panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Listed emission/absorption lines refer to the most prominent features seen in the galaxy's spectrum.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277395\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277396 id=\"88277396\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Other objects</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to cluster members and multiply imaged systems, the catalogue also contains a number of foreground objects and singly imaged background objects at various redshifts. We identify four stars within the MUSE field of view, mostly located near the BCG. Beyond the Milky Way, we find 13 galaxies in the foreground of the cluster, between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.2 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.35. Nearly all of these objects are optically blue and have emission features, in particular a very strong H\u00a0\u03b1 line. However, object F11 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3275) shows strong absorption line features, with only weak [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission. Behind the cluster, we find an additional 13 objects at redshifts between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.41 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.5. Here again, these systems are largely identified by strong [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and/or [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission lines, however object B4 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4655) is another absorption-line galaxy showing weak [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission. Information on all singly imaged objects can be found in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277398\" scrollto-destination=\"88277398\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B3\u00a0</td><td>39.976\u00a0931\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.590\u00a09864\u00a0</td><td>0.4225\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B4\u00a0</td><td>39.969\u00a0400\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.573\u00a06444\u00a0</td><td>0.4655\u00a0</td><td>Ca\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> H, K\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B5\u00a0</td><td>39.968\u00a0908\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.587\u00a01056\u00a0</td><td>0.5804\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B6\u00a0</td><td>39.969\u00a0464\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.589\u00a05997\u00a0</td><td>0.6037\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B7\u00a0</td><td>39.967\u00a0551\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.586\u00a01036\u00a0</td><td>0.6801\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B8\u00a0</td><td>39.967\u00a0227\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.589\u00a09252\u00a0</td><td>0.8040\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B9\u00a0</td><td>39.963\u00a0801\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.588\u00a02507\u00a0</td><td>0.8049\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B10\u00a0</td><td>39.978\u00a0094\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.585\u00a02708\u00a0</td><td>1.0606\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B11\u00a0</td><td>39.962\u00a0676\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.585\u00a01813\u00a0</td><td>1.0635\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B12\u00a0</td><td>39.976\u00a0042\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.589\u00a03204\u00a0</td><td>1.3398\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B13\u00a0</td><td>39.979\u00a0281\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.590\u00a02451\u00a0</td><td>1.4497\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277398\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277399 id=\"88277399\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 LENS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To measure the mass distribution of A370, we follow a procedure used in previous works (e.g. Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>): namely, we model the system as a collection of mass clumps, including both large-scale dark matter haloes representing cluster potentials and smaller, galaxy-scale haloes representing individual galaxies. Each halo, regardless of size, is assumed to have a truncated dual Pseudo-Isothermal Elliptical mass distribution (dPIE; El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). The description of a dPIE halo consists of seven parameters: position (\u03b1 and \u03b4), velocity dispersion (\u03c3<sub>0</sub>), position angle (\u03b8), ellipticity (\u03b5) and two scale radii (<em>r</em><sub>core</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>) that modify the halo's mass slope. Here, <em>r</em><sub>core</sub> represents the halo's inner core radius, inside of which the mass slope flattens instead of increasing isothermally. Finally, <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> represents the halo's cut-off radius, outside of which the mass slope drops more steeply.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">During the optimization process, we allow most cluster halo parameters to freely vary within a given prior distribution, but we fix <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> to a large value of 800\u00a0kpc (155\u00a0arcsec). This is because the current data do not extend far enough to meaningfully constrain its value. To limit the overall size of the parameter space, we place additional restrictions on the galaxy-scale haloes, adopting a light-traces-mass approach that assumes correlation between the observed baryons and their galaxy haloes. Galaxy positions, ellipticities and position angles are fixed to values measured from the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> HFF data, while <em>r</em><sub>core</sub>, <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> and \u03c3<sub>0</sub> are scaled based on the galaxy's luminosity (<em>L</em>), relative to an <em>L</em>* galaxy. At the A370 cluster redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m^*_{\\rm F814W}$|</span> = 18.31. We fix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r^*_{\\rm core}$|</span> to be 0.15\u00a0kpc, while we allow <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r^*_{\\rm cut}$|</span> to vary with a uniform prior between 10 and 50\u00a0kpc. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r^*_{\\rm cut}$|</span> value is kept low to account for tidal stripping effects by the cluster haloes (Halkola, Seitz &amp; Pannella <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007a</a>; Natarajan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Similarly, we allow (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\sigma ^*_0$|\u2060</span>) to vary, but we instead assume a Gaussian prior distribution with mean \u03bc<sub>pdf</sub> = 158\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and width \u03c3<sub>pdf</sub> = 27\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, following the Bernardi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) observations of early-type galaxies in high-density environments in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we model three galaxy-scale haloes separately from the scaling relation: the two BCGs and another bright galaxy (GAL1) lying close to the System 2 giant arc. The southern BCG and GAL1 (objects Cl29 and Cl32, respectively, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) are close enough and massive enough to significantly affect the shape of System 2. The northern BCG mildly influences the orientation of the northern cluster potential. Like the other galaxy potentials, we fix the position, PA and ellipticity values to match the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> HFF data. We also fix <em>r</em><sub>core</sub>, though we assume different values (0.14\u00a0kpc for the BCGs, 0.06\u00a0kpc for GAL1) based on their magnitudes, which are consistent with the original scaling relation. The values of \u03c3<sub>0</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> are allowed to vary freely, using their magnitude-scaled values relative to <em>L</em>* as a starting point.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Individual galaxies that we include in the model as cluster-member haloes are selected through a colour cut, using the three optical HFF bands. Additionally, we limit the selection to bright galaxies (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.6), since beyond this cutoff \u2013 roughly equivalent to\u00a0\u223c0.02 <em>L</em><sub>*</sub> \u2013 galaxies will have a negligible effect on the mass budget. We also exclude galaxies at distances beyond <em>R</em>\u00a0=\u00a070\u00a0arcsec from the cluster centre (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a02<sup>h</sup> 39<sup>m</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$59{^{\\rm s}_{.}}9$|\u2060</span>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121\u00b0 34<sup>\u0384</sup> 36<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>5), corresponding to <em>R</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0360\u00a0kpc in physical space, for similar reasons. For the colour cut itself, we construct the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013i814<em>W</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams and look for evidence of a red sequence. The colour\u2013magnitude diagrams are shown in the upper panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, along with the boundary conditions used to select candidate cluster members. These are given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n(-0.11 \\times m_{\\rm F814W}) + 4.06 \\le (m_{\\rm F435W} - m_{\\rm F606W})\\nonumber \\\\\r\n (-0.11 \\times m_{\\rm F814W}) + 4.45 \\ge (m_{\\rm F435W} - m_{\\rm F606W})\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>for <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n(-0.04 \\times m_{\\rm F814W}) + 1.74 \\le (m_{\\rm F606W} - m_{\\rm F814W}) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n (-0.04 \\times m_{\\rm F814W}) + 1.93 \\ge (m_{\\rm F606W} - m_{\\rm F814W})\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>for <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>. We then combine the two plots into a colour\u2013colour diagram and select galaxies that satisfy both red sequence cuts. The majority of these galaxies fall into a tight cluster locus (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, bottom). To measure galaxy photometry, we run SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) in dual-image mode, using the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band data as the detection template. In the region covered by the MUSE footprint, we further refine the selection process by including all spectroscopically confirmed cluster members (including the bluer, late-type galaxies missed by the colour\u2013colour cut) and rejecting all non-cluster members regardless of their colours or magnitudes.</div>                        <a id=\"88277404\" scrollto-destination=\"88277404\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=P0eiEOIvfT64uwQt9vE~rY7Fbad-yvw2YZw12tXdnbe~0GsDAGmgb~NlEqNpoBd2kG8Fk-0rGup~Rx2pIP0Ih3Jg9FRvOmVmEaHQxcbJmMtl7~Aeq3RP9W-hw1Eev4Lar~YCBY3s3SecBWdR6-bBurpe8ki0GgBx-ya8~SMDQ78j52V8R5DqJ5NQZ1D6jQfaXm3H8~ZTJB2u8UCPjPs5B8eYOO9pYEmRkZU~PWQfdeAyvlFhZIuCiMUch-w2IFLFudqjuvC4NP6j-VXp1fnESPuWZGsl0T0UrGXlWRFcOjPnBdEjVFn72~JcNmUSBUk9ykNwXAngW-g1f6LBtrNg8w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour criterion used to select galaxies for mass modelling. Top: objects selected from the (F435W\u2013F606W) versus F814W colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Diagonal lines trace the 3\u03c3 upper- and lower bounds defining the cluster red sequence, while a faint-end magnitude cutoff (mF814W\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.6) is represented by the vertical line. Galaxies selected through this criterion are shown in red. Additionally, spectroscopically confirmed cluster members are highlighted by green rings, and are included in the final model regardless of colour or magnitude. Middle: similar selection diagram, using the (F606W\u2013F814W) versus F814W colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Bottom: combination of the two colour\u2013magnitude diagrams into a colour\u2013colour diagram. \u2018Good\u2019 objects \u2013 those falling simultaneously within both cluster red sequences \u2013 are mainly located within a tight locus. The final set of colour\u2013colour selected galaxies are shown in red, while the spectroscopic galaxies are again shown as green rings.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277404/stx1079fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277404\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=AQ7EAb3x~bCE5BKj7HFc3HNy34NX5ya3iCiA1QDjmpeKO85Q1h7GuF6AZz8fyWstywe44x2MTyOL1XEEq1dOl6AQ28m~cSfoKUNvXL-kQLKpa00eHvZS4zBNdq7-tqx~IfOxWY9h2JeAjxbDdzHMi4rOsMXfWHpwahXBbptdSPI5tom5pc~Sp04lY2xEHknTJQh4RRw3gtnKjHSeQClWbjPp8QdTr22XfzSuiYwefjjsh2VQR-cgz9Ux-2~IJ9i5cs3An5tP~FM6iFc2ga8APkdYat7FeeCAtoMss3oD6R-KoZX429bsUOJrmqE2BMoseP6i7e7Eht9ZqEOx9ZdF7A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277404&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour criterion used to select galaxies for mass modelling. Top: objects selected from the (<em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>) versus <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Diagonal lines trace the 3\u03c3 upper- and lower bounds defining the cluster red sequence, while a faint-end magnitude cutoff (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.6) is represented by the vertical line. Galaxies selected through this criterion are shown in red. Additionally, spectroscopically confirmed cluster members are highlighted by green rings, and are included in the final model regardless of colour or magnitude. Middle: similar selection diagram, using the (<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>) versus <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Bottom: combination of the two colour\u2013magnitude diagrams into a colour\u2013colour diagram. \u2018Good\u2019 objects \u2013 those falling simultaneously within both cluster red sequences \u2013 are mainly located within a tight locus. The final set of colour\u2013colour selected galaxies are shown in red, while the spectroscopic galaxies are again shown as green rings.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=P0eiEOIvfT64uwQt9vE~rY7Fbad-yvw2YZw12tXdnbe~0GsDAGmgb~NlEqNpoBd2kG8Fk-0rGup~Rx2pIP0Ih3Jg9FRvOmVmEaHQxcbJmMtl7~Aeq3RP9W-hw1Eev4Lar~YCBY3s3SecBWdR6-bBurpe8ki0GgBx-ya8~SMDQ78j52V8R5DqJ5NQZ1D6jQfaXm3H8~ZTJB2u8UCPjPs5B8eYOO9pYEmRkZU~PWQfdeAyvlFhZIuCiMUch-w2IFLFudqjuvC4NP6j-VXp1fnESPuWZGsl0T0UrGXlWRFcOjPnBdEjVFn72~JcNmUSBUk9ykNwXAngW-g1f6LBtrNg8w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour criterion used to select galaxies for mass modelling. Top: objects selected from the (F435W\u2013F606W) versus F814W colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Diagonal lines trace the 3\u03c3 upper- and lower bounds defining the cluster red sequence, while a faint-end magnitude cutoff (mF814W\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.6) is represented by the vertical line. Galaxies selected through this criterion are shown in red. Additionally, spectroscopically confirmed cluster members are highlighted by green rings, and are included in the final model regardless of colour or magnitude. Middle: similar selection diagram, using the (F606W\u2013F814W) versus F814W colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Bottom: combination of the two colour\u2013magnitude diagrams into a colour\u2013colour diagram. \u2018Good\u2019 objects \u2013 those falling simultaneously within both cluster red sequences \u2013 are mainly located within a tight locus. The final set of colour\u2013colour selected galaxies are shown in red, while the spectroscopic galaxies are again shown as green rings.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277404/stx1079fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277404\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=AQ7EAb3x~bCE5BKj7HFc3HNy34NX5ya3iCiA1QDjmpeKO85Q1h7GuF6AZz8fyWstywe44x2MTyOL1XEEq1dOl6AQ28m~cSfoKUNvXL-kQLKpa00eHvZS4zBNdq7-tqx~IfOxWY9h2JeAjxbDdzHMi4rOsMXfWHpwahXBbptdSPI5tom5pc~Sp04lY2xEHknTJQh4RRw3gtnKjHSeQClWbjPp8QdTr22XfzSuiYwefjjsh2VQR-cgz9Ux-2~IJ9i5cs3An5tP~FM6iFc2ga8APkdYat7FeeCAtoMss3oD6R-KoZX429bsUOJrmqE2BMoseP6i7e7Eht9ZqEOx9ZdF7A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277404&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour criterion used to select galaxies for mass modelling. Top: objects selected from the (<em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>) versus <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Diagonal lines trace the 3\u03c3 upper- and lower bounds defining the cluster red sequence, while a faint-end magnitude cutoff (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.6) is represented by the vertical line. Galaxies selected through this criterion are shown in red. Additionally, spectroscopically confirmed cluster members are highlighted by green rings, and are included in the final model regardless of colour or magnitude. Middle: similar selection diagram, using the (<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>) versus <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Bottom: combination of the two colour\u2013magnitude diagrams into a colour\u2013colour diagram. \u2018Good\u2019 objects \u2013 those falling simultaneously within both cluster red sequences \u2013 are mainly located within a tight locus. The final set of colour\u2013colour selected galaxies are shown in red, while the spectroscopic galaxies are again shown as green rings.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We constrain the mass model with the positions of known multiply imaged systems, however, we first revise the interpretation of System 5, previously described as a three-image system (5.1, 5.2, 5.3). Image 5.3 is actually located close to a background galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.6 (object B6 in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) that perturbs the lens model, and we add it as an additional galaxy-scale potential. As illustrated by a simulation of the lensing effect on Images 5.1 and 5.2, this small perturbation convincingly produces a merging pair of two additional images previously identified as 5.3 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). Therefore, we update our constraint list to include the new Image 5.3 and Image 5.4 in the model. While we use nearly all of the 22 current systems (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) we exclude System 10, a faint radial arc without a secure redshift that also lacks bright counterimages. Because even small changes in the mass model produce wildly different predictions for radial systems, the lack of counterimages makes the system fully degenerate with the parameters of the northern cluster halo.</p>                        <a id=\"88277406\" scrollto-destination=\"88277406\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=PrhvrZ4FPb8Wnge3eyNRUJJGHqDYDxh6967yBSmm21D6XAzVCHVOGeR3dnzlpYBFpsWtxMncXMxJYHp~0ECDtQXC00iTnHF2Pym--L9BhnMvmjfWYcjnryUFt7UiZ6z8m4vwOODhdL91i~poV~~LF3E-Xq9-QhNwJ5A2GYvizmZ5Amq~85zdqWADqgSZ8fPKZQbVqaTevg1ZMEjgOqdYK8xKNIywelR-pC7AsOhVa9lC0FdWzlmPb8HZdLk~8l4dUaSbprZwFLo65uJIphgnm5OEOnri7Y54ipOq4v1xp9EsP0kVRtJEr4SB1TJSaedaKMw78kXZwnKMxCZ-Xhq0Ig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Our new interpretation of System 5. The critical line at z\u00a0=\u00a01.2775 (red line in both panels) is affected by the background z\u00a0=\u00a00.6 spiral galaxy (B6; see Table 3) on the right and crosses the rightmost image previously known as 5.3. We interpret 5.3 as a merging pair of two additional images mirroring only part of the source. This is seen convincingly in the simulation, which reproduce the relative surface brightnesses of the observations well.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277406/stx1079fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277406\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=z-qwYc1LA3x0gnpfP2RTrO7nt0rFm9QYphF01b2x1CnxZSM1C7uAF-2XTMU3MxeFpj5O0NoXWhUKxwFNJjTP8GzxYPn4dn1VVH9hjhVZ-d1RfietQ00BwwLsOz5C2USrfzi3Hk3-M4dymi50jRmEEMloBOr4dZjlOIFbJkgtK0Oab2JBHys8fDPi6kSciaaMHl6Q12lehtiB7SMvnVeP49-ess071d8T8Jvn4MS-TeC3e0tL0L4LTKmFwXWvbVRavaBsxpcqKTW9kosITPmKrup9rO2IB40r1aq2zC2PnEe3ndcW6hE72SeoFVAPg-mtKmcLRaHqaP6g~lu7JF2csA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277406&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our new interpretation of System 5. In this simulation, a pixelized image of the galaxy is sent to the source plane and then back to the image plane to be compared with observations. The critical line at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2775 (red line in both panels) is affected by the background <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.6 spiral galaxy (B6; see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) on the right and crosses the rightmost image previously known as 5.3. We interpret 5.3 as a merging pair of two additional images mirroring only part of the source. This is seen convincingly in the simulation, which reproduce the relative surface brightnesses of the observations well.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=PrhvrZ4FPb8Wnge3eyNRUJJGHqDYDxh6967yBSmm21D6XAzVCHVOGeR3dnzlpYBFpsWtxMncXMxJYHp~0ECDtQXC00iTnHF2Pym--L9BhnMvmjfWYcjnryUFt7UiZ6z8m4vwOODhdL91i~poV~~LF3E-Xq9-QhNwJ5A2GYvizmZ5Amq~85zdqWADqgSZ8fPKZQbVqaTevg1ZMEjgOqdYK8xKNIywelR-pC7AsOhVa9lC0FdWzlmPb8HZdLk~8l4dUaSbprZwFLo65uJIphgnm5OEOnri7Y54ipOq4v1xp9EsP0kVRtJEr4SB1TJSaedaKMw78kXZwnKMxCZ-Xhq0Ig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Our new interpretation of System 5. Top: an ACS RGB image of System 5. Bottom: a simulated image, using the lens model. In this simulation, a pixelized image of the galaxy is sent to the source plane and then back to the image plane to be compared with observations. The critical line at z\u00a0=\u00a01.2775 (red line in both panels) is affected by the background z\u00a0=\u00a00.6 spiral galaxy (B6; see Table 3) on the right and crosses the rightmost image previously known as 5.3. We interpret 5.3 as a merging pair of two additional images mirroring only part of the source. This is seen convincingly in the simulation, which reproduce the relative surface brightnesses of the observations well.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277406/stx1079fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277406\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=z-qwYc1LA3x0gnpfP2RTrO7nt0rFm9QYphF01b2x1CnxZSM1C7uAF-2XTMU3MxeFpj5O0NoXWhUKxwFNJjTP8GzxYPn4dn1VVH9hjhVZ-d1RfietQ00BwwLsOz5C2USrfzi3Hk3-M4dymi50jRmEEMloBOr4dZjlOIFbJkgtK0Oab2JBHys8fDPi6kSciaaMHl6Q12lehtiB7SMvnVeP49-ess071d8T8Jvn4MS-TeC3e0tL0L4LTKmFwXWvbVRavaBsxpcqKTW9kosITPmKrup9rO2IB40r1aq2zC2PnEe3ndcW6hE72SeoFVAPg-mtKmcLRaHqaP6g~lu7JF2csA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277406&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our new interpretation of System 5. Top: an ACS RGB image of System 5. Bottom: a simulated image, using the lens model. In this simulation, a pixelized image of the galaxy is sent to the source plane and then back to the image plane to be compared with observations. The critical line at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2775 (red line in both panels) is affected by the background <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.6 spiral galaxy (B6; see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) on the right and crosses the rightmost image previously known as 5.3. We interpret 5.3 as a merging pair of two additional images mirroring only part of the source. This is seen convincingly in the simulation, which reproduce the relative surface brightnesses of the observations well.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">While some systems have only a single MUSE detection (Systems 16, 17, 18, 19 and 22), these objects are often bright in broad-band photometry, and we are able to identify their counterparts in the HFF data directly. In fact, many lens systems with MUSE spectroscopy have at least one counterimage that falls outside of the current footprint, since the GTO data only cover a fraction of the A370 field of view. Though we are unable to confirm these objects spectroscopically, we can identify them with the help of the lens model itself. Specifically, we start with known (spectroscopically confirmed) members of a given lens system and use the model to predict the location of counterimages. From this rough guess, we look for candidates in the HFF data that match the system members (i.e. galaxies with similar colours, morphology and shape), which we take to be the counterimages. We then optimize a new version of the model, including these other constraints. We can compare the models with and without the added constraints, and if the new results stay within an acceptable error limit: an average model rms displacement of 1\u00a0arcsec or lower, we keep the counterimages and start the process again. In this way, we are able to iteratively refine and improve the model until it converges on the best solution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the best A370 model, we identify 16 counterimages this way: Images 7.4, 7.5, 14.4, 14.5, 15.4, 15.5, 16.3, 17.2, 17.3, 18.2, 18.3, 19.2, 19.3, 21.3, 22.2 and 22.3. With the exception of the System 7 counterimages, they are all associated with newly identified MUSE objects, again highlighting the power of MUSE as a redshift engine. While the model also predicts the existence of Images 3.4 and 20.3, there are no obvious candidates in the available HFF data, so we do not include them as constraints. The remaining systems (8, 11, 12 and 13) fall outside of the MUSE footprint and lack secure redshift information. Thus, we use the positions of these systems as constraints but leave their redshift values as free parameters to be fit by the model. In some cases, the best-fitting model predicts additional counterimages for these objects (Images 8.3, 11.3 and 13.3), but we again find no obvious counterparts in the HFF data, so we do not use them as model constraints. This is because predicted positions without redshift have significantly larger uncertainties. While we do note that any object without a secure redshift may not be a real counterimage but instead the chance alignment of a different galaxy, the combination of model predictions and visual evidence from the <em>HST</em> data makes this scenario extremely unlikely. As a result, we do not consider this possibility in our current lens modelling. However, we will revisit these objects in future work with a larger MUSE mosaic. After adding and removing objects as described above, we are left with 21 unique systems with a total of 66 individual image constraints.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To optimize the model, we feed all parameters and constraints into the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a> (Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jullo &amp; Kneib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) software program, which probes the full parameter space with a Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampler. To evaluate a given model, <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> reconstructs the parametrized mass distribution and transforms the constraint coordinates from the image (observed) plane to the source (undeflected) plane. In the source plane, the program calculates the barycentre of each constraining system, then transforms these results back to the lens plane, creating a set of predicted images that can be compared to observation. By minimizing the rms displacement between prediction and observation, <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> is thus able to objectively determine the \u2018best\u2019 model for a given set of input parameters (e.g. Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Following Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), our initial model includes two massive cluster potentials (each centred on a BCG) and the cluster galaxies selected from the colour\u2013colour cut outlined above. However, after several MCMC iterations with this model, we find that no combination of parameter values sufficiently recreates the observed image positions (i.e. with an average rms error\u00a0&lt;1\u00a0arcsec). In particular, we are unable to simultaneously model the positions of the systems in the north and the new MUSE-identified images near the centre. This is most noticeable in System 12, where typical model displacements can be as large as 6\u00a0arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To help correct this disagreement, we first add an elongated, bar-like mass potential (DM3) as a bridge between the two cluster haloes (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). This flattens the mass distribution in the region between the two BCGs, and improves the fit of the central, radial image constraints of Systems 7, 14 and 15. As a consequence of adding the bar, the northern cluster potential (DM2) becomes more elongated and its centroid moves further away from the BCG. This can be explained as a model degeneracy between the positions of DM2 and DM3, since there is a significant overlap between their mass distributions. In fact, the barycentre of the two components falls slightly to the south of the BCG itself.</p>                        <a id=\"88277412\" scrollto-destination=\"88277412\"></a>\r\n<div id=\"fn-TFN006\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN006\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u0394\u03b1 and \u0394\u03b4 are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (\u03b1 = 39.971\u00a034, \u03b4 = \u22121.582\u00a02597).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN007\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN007\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Ellipticity (\u03b5) is defined to be (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN008\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN008\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277412\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Even after adding the bar, however, we are only able to reduce the model rms to 1.17\u00a0arcsec, with the northern systems still poorly fit. Therefore, we add an additional large-scale cluster potential to the model (DM4), centred near a group of bright galaxies in the northeastern corner of the cluster (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). This location is chosen both because of its proximity to Image 12.3 (the image constraint with the highest rms error), and because it is part of a \u2018crown\u2019 of galaxies sitting above the northern BCG. Since all of the galaxies in the crown are bright and have similar, cluster-like colours and several are spectroscopically confirmed to be cluster members (Mellier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) it is possible this collection represents another, unaccounted-for mass component of A370.</p>                        <a id=\"88277414\" scrollto-destination=\"88277414\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=edATFU6CsBIBuApUcsmt3pQJXTOESZUhor4xnkPOQH2NIhScz~2~A3C9ia-IM4NYwY7c54BXY7uyQzOB8edStDJSzmX5pQuKL-unOe~m0ld7CoZUsN7XpWGqZIh61mGPZG532Vk-o5sgi3VCBEnLGQZWto-ErnYKCiAvhVJh70NmRUK3ArUgzWAo8b0qEgFjS9sKb2vG8sjJMxTeYn2D-2F44keBGsK9I9Q9RaUPQKdPCx4bi5sBLtTjArgaEiQan950KHQzzxK4UQXQUPN~VyhUqmkdUZI74a6W7s0l4Rd72JMvLKC7YOrlunwy~NSPzjE3DQsQ~4~Tb2oDz~m9sQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Dark matter surface mass density contours (green) measured from the lens model. Contours are shown in steps of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0108 M\u2299\u00a0kpc\u22122, starting from 109 M\u2299\u00a0kpc\u22122. Highlighted in red are the centroids of the four cluster-scale dark matter haloes. Red ellipses are used to give a rough estimate of the relative shape and strength of each component, but we stress that the actual mass contours are much larger and less elliptical.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277414/stx1079fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277414\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=KAsCmXgk8lqrtayyNUSA9XIgKZaE~9UjcIoL5TAaN7SFdwVysFQAesA9rfTy5kZFKMpuX3YbtPXEudWHoDqK2psa4pMafr2BDdK4hB7LntXikl822EMNBqTUpWNiHZz7BQpyoDiejKBQMxTJrRhJK15j9K2cF-dlO-yCnRbT5HHlw8Xc~XWadlyUbl9J6sB0p9O2mcwPjOI62cVRlwFEvNMuuse6el~mJyruyMSsDgMUIWfWNpmIhYmWvTqg1s88CMVKBdWdv089hOeMwVBYNpU5b7YtR9vcOVbVgXBxoTOnEonArSgXA69YVFC5MlGEB11h5EvY8ffmoyIPPz4F3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277414&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dark matter surface mass density contours (green) measured from the lens model. Contours are shown in steps of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>, starting from 10<sup>9</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>. Highlighted in red are the centroids of the four cluster-scale dark matter haloes. Red ellipses are used to give a rough estimate of the relative shape and strength of each component, but we stress that the actual mass contours are much larger and less elliptical.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=edATFU6CsBIBuApUcsmt3pQJXTOESZUhor4xnkPOQH2NIhScz~2~A3C9ia-IM4NYwY7c54BXY7uyQzOB8edStDJSzmX5pQuKL-unOe~m0ld7CoZUsN7XpWGqZIh61mGPZG532Vk-o5sgi3VCBEnLGQZWto-ErnYKCiAvhVJh70NmRUK3ArUgzWAo8b0qEgFjS9sKb2vG8sjJMxTeYn2D-2F44keBGsK9I9Q9RaUPQKdPCx4bi5sBLtTjArgaEiQan950KHQzzxK4UQXQUPN~VyhUqmkdUZI74a6W7s0l4Rd72JMvLKC7YOrlunwy~NSPzjE3DQsQ~4~Tb2oDz~m9sQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Dark matter surface mass density contours (green) measured from the lens model. Contours are shown in steps of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0108 M\u2299\u00a0kpc\u22122, starting from 109 M\u2299\u00a0kpc\u22122. Highlighted in red are the centroids of the four cluster-scale dark matter haloes. Red ellipses are used to give a rough estimate of the relative shape and strength of each component, but we stress that the actual mass contours are much larger and less elliptical.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277414/stx1079fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277414\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=KAsCmXgk8lqrtayyNUSA9XIgKZaE~9UjcIoL5TAaN7SFdwVysFQAesA9rfTy5kZFKMpuX3YbtPXEudWHoDqK2psa4pMafr2BDdK4hB7LntXikl822EMNBqTUpWNiHZz7BQpyoDiejKBQMxTJrRhJK15j9K2cF-dlO-yCnRbT5HHlw8Xc~XWadlyUbl9J6sB0p9O2mcwPjOI62cVRlwFEvNMuuse6el~mJyruyMSsDgMUIWfWNpmIhYmWvTqg1s88CMVKBdWdv089hOeMwVBYNpU5b7YtR9vcOVbVgXBxoTOnEonArSgXA69YVFC5MlGEB11h5EvY8ffmoyIPPz4F3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277414&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dark matter surface mass density contours (green) measured from the lens model. Contours are shown in steps of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>, starting from 10<sup>9</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>. Highlighted in red are the centroids of the four cluster-scale dark matter haloes. Red ellipses are used to give a rough estimate of the relative shape and strength of each component, but we stress that the actual mass contours are much larger and less elliptical.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As with the other cluster potentials, we allow the dPIE parameters of the crown component to vary freely within a set of priors, though we assume an initial configuration that is more elliptical (like the bar), to better account for the stretched nature of the crown. Including this additional mass clump further improves the fit, reducing the average rms displacement from 1.17\u00a0arcsec to 0.94\u00a0arcsec, below the benchmark level of rms = 1\u00a0arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To see if even more mass structures are needed to describe A370, we also test a five-clump mass model, placing an additional mass clump on the western side of the A370 crown. Like the eastern clump, we choose locations close to bright cluster galaxies \u2013 including the pair of elliptical galaxies near the top of the crown \u2013 though we do allow the centroid to vary around these locations. However, this does not significantly improve the fit (rms = 0.88\u00a0arcsec) and actually lowers the Bayesian evidence, possibly suggesting an overfit to the data (see Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>). Thus, given the success of the four-clump model in reproducing the image constraint positions, we treat its optimized parameter set as our \u2018best-fitting\u2019 description of the A370 mass distribution. Optimized parameters for all models can be seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, and the final model mass reconstruction is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277417 id=\"88277417\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277418 id=\"88277418\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 The case for additional mass clumps</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While adding two new large-scale mass clumps to the model significantly improves the fit, it is important to ask the question \u2018Is this additional mass truly necessary?\u2019 In other words, are these new mass clumps real features supported by the data, or is it simply a case of overfitting in a sparsely sampled region of the cluster? To answer this, we look at both model and (perhaps more importantly) physical evidence.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From a purely statistical point of view, the Bayesian evidence value (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathcal {E}$|\u2060</span>) can discriminate between models, taking into account and in some cases penalizing additional terms and model complexities, while simultaneously evaluating goodness of fit. Models with larger evidence terms are preferred over those with smaller terms, providing an objective criterion for comparison (see e.g. Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). For the A370 models (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), we find that the evidence of the three-clump model (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log (\\mathcal {E})$|</span> = \u2212303.19) is significantly larger than that of the two-clump model (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log (\\mathcal {E})$|</span> = \u22121817.07), showing that the data strongly prefer a mass distribution that includes a flatter, central \u2018bar\u2019 component. The evidence term of the four-clump model is larger still (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log (\\mathcal {E})$|</span> = \u2212201.90) \u2013 though the relative improvement over the three-clump model is not as great \u2013 again suggesting a real need for the crown clump. Finally, although the more complex five-clump model has a marginally improved fit over the four-clump model (rms = 0.88\u00a0arcsec), its evidence value actually decreases (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log \\mathcal {E}$|</span> = \u2212202.67) suggesting that the fifth mass clump is unnecessary and that we are beginning to overfit the system. Additional tests, placing the fifth clump at several other locations throughout the crown, yield similar (or worse) results.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">As a complementary check on overfitting, we also calculate the Bayesian information criterion (BIC) term for each model: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{\\rm BIC} = -2 \\times \\log (\\mathcal {L}) + k \\times \\log (n),\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}$|</span> is the model likelihood, <em>k</em> is the number of model free parameters and <em>n</em> is the number of model constraints. Lower BIC values are favoured over higher values, and for our models, we again see that the four-clump case (BIC = 455.35) is preferred over all others (we present all values in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), bolstering the claim that the bar and the crown are real, necessary features.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the physical side of the evidence argument, we first turn to the cluster light distribution. As previously mentioned, the presence of the northern crown of galaxies already suggests an additional mass distribution not captured by the two-clump model. To test this theory, we first isolate the cluster light in the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band (the filter where cluster members are brightest), keeping only the objects selected by the cluster-member colour\u2013colour cut (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>) and masking the rest. We then smooth the remaining light with a Gaussian kernel (\u03c3<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0=\u00a010\u00a0arcsec), providing a cleaner view of the light distribution. Comparing this distribution to the four-clump mass model ( Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, left), we find good agreement between the brightest points of the light map and the positions of the large-scale clumps. As expected, the southern cluster halo sits near the southern BCG, the combined northern cluster halo and bar surround the northern BCG, and the fourth clump sits on the eastern side of the crown. Even more promisingly, the orientation of the fourth mass clump is aligned with the distribution of the crown light, even though it is allowed to vary freely in the model. Assuming then that, at least to some degree, the presence of light traces the presence of mass, the agreement between the light map and mass model provides another argument in favour of the four-clump model.</p>                        <a id=\"88277423\" scrollto-destination=\"88277423\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ETSIZ9iFcYLTwEvQYc4neMbW~n~g2h8CcmbUxtuABqF6k3vn0DyiZ3Vj5iCHd8v5sWzZ614hlcn-YP0T3H1W3kI-gxpoaDpqSDmZnEAkhcXz-CWToGU8lDEHonRmGuj3GbHXGcCR9ors5GFyFfNjehQ5jqBoh3FdvK9SDhGZiHslfatGluFEKNakBDxZ3glr28dR0T5SkxEebolK2fcGfNn15SISx57CVXWJmb4VLjX0Jd6yuQNTmPBHCDqVaUUuhXEu0P3hJUdRrt8eY4z-CpKxUCXp8nu4bDQihBZsZvXf6MZQy00pgAeylQzWNQl3RqLYQKNnXLJmg7nbMV-o9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparisons between model mass clumps and two physical parameter maps. Left: the smoothed cluster light map. We see an agreement between the mass clump positions and the locations of the brightest cluster light. We also find a good agreement between the orientation of the light in the \u2018crown\u2019 and the fourth mass clump (DM4). Right: the X-ray gas map. We again see an agreement between the map and the large-scale clump positions, along with an agreement in shape and orientation of the X-ray gas contours (blue lines) and model mass contours (green lines). In both cases, the mass contours are the same as those presented in Fig.\u00a09. Taken together these two maps suggest that the bar (DM3) and the crown (DM4) are real features of the cluster, and not a simple case of overfitting the data.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277423/stx1079fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277423\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=EIaT0GUBFF8xp2yZd9vQf9KEWcJm3FAgZzm708tSVvkQJEDpODR-FXkfjawtAxyqjPCjz~XaAllSYKFHg7Ua1cBjf3ZufMME0hIVB-YQonsxQbTutuEIKCYBNU8toj~pP~4qMYg4Cj6mcwJrqp96aNNmtCVt1-LZqjrkOWB9Qlt0-6mRT7ET6WCJAMJ32E1l2j0jQeXaSOsWyc9kN8oPp8l9WRZUP67dBumDMlurqzDOF4gIZJ63cFPGtNf25RKw5wmNCYOPEQ~ywEF-7DByhZ~GqcfUa0iAHQsQiGLEEdqYXSAUeIq8bNzSj4~Aehcl~7Wq0TBpATW8wTNj-LuZ~Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277423&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between model mass clumps and two physical parameter maps. Left: the smoothed cluster light map. We see an agreement between the mass clump positions and the locations of the brightest cluster light. We also find a good agreement between the orientation of the light in the \u2018crown\u2019 and the fourth mass clump (DM4). Right: the X-ray gas map. We again see an agreement between the map and the large-scale clump positions, along with an agreement in shape and orientation of the X-ray gas contours (blue lines) and model mass contours (green lines). In both cases, the mass contours are the same as those presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. Taken together these two maps suggest that the bar (DM3) and the crown (DM4) are real features of the cluster, and not a simple case of overfitting the data.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ETSIZ9iFcYLTwEvQYc4neMbW~n~g2h8CcmbUxtuABqF6k3vn0DyiZ3Vj5iCHd8v5sWzZ614hlcn-YP0T3H1W3kI-gxpoaDpqSDmZnEAkhcXz-CWToGU8lDEHonRmGuj3GbHXGcCR9ors5GFyFfNjehQ5jqBoh3FdvK9SDhGZiHslfatGluFEKNakBDxZ3glr28dR0T5SkxEebolK2fcGfNn15SISx57CVXWJmb4VLjX0Jd6yuQNTmPBHCDqVaUUuhXEu0P3hJUdRrt8eY4z-CpKxUCXp8nu4bDQihBZsZvXf6MZQy00pgAeylQzWNQl3RqLYQKNnXLJmg7nbMV-o9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparisons between model mass clumps and two physical parameter maps. Left: the smoothed cluster light map. We see an agreement between the mass clump positions and the locations of the brightest cluster light. We also find a good agreement between the orientation of the light in the \u2018crown\u2019 and the fourth mass clump (DM4). Right: the X-ray gas map. We again see an agreement between the map and the large-scale clump positions, along with an agreement in shape and orientation of the X-ray gas contours (blue lines) and model mass contours (green lines). In both cases, the mass contours are the same as those presented in Fig.\u00a09. Taken together these two maps suggest that the bar (DM3) and the crown (DM4) are real features of the cluster, and not a simple case of overfitting the data.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277423/stx1079fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277423\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=EIaT0GUBFF8xp2yZd9vQf9KEWcJm3FAgZzm708tSVvkQJEDpODR-FXkfjawtAxyqjPCjz~XaAllSYKFHg7Ua1cBjf3ZufMME0hIVB-YQonsxQbTutuEIKCYBNU8toj~pP~4qMYg4Cj6mcwJrqp96aNNmtCVt1-LZqjrkOWB9Qlt0-6mRT7ET6WCJAMJ32E1l2j0jQeXaSOsWyc9kN8oPp8l9WRZUP67dBumDMlurqzDOF4gIZJ63cFPGtNf25RKw5wmNCYOPEQ~ywEF-7DByhZ~GqcfUa0iAHQsQiGLEEdqYXSAUeIq8bNzSj4~Aehcl~7Wq0TBpATW8wTNj-LuZ~Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277423&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between model mass clumps and two physical parameter maps. Left: the smoothed cluster light map. We see an agreement between the mass clump positions and the locations of the brightest cluster light. We also find a good agreement between the orientation of the light in the \u2018crown\u2019 and the fourth mass clump (DM4). Right: the X-ray gas map. We again see an agreement between the map and the large-scale clump positions, along with an agreement in shape and orientation of the X-ray gas contours (blue lines) and model mass contours (green lines). In both cases, the mass contours are the same as those presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. Taken together these two maps suggest that the bar (DM3) and the crown (DM4) are real features of the cluster, and not a simple case of overfitting the data.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we also look at the A370 X-ray gas profile, as the presence of hot X-ray gas is often used as a tracer of deep mass potentials. For this, we turn to publicly available, deep <em>Chandra</em> data: an 88 ks image of A370, observed using the using the Advanced CCD Imaging Spectrometer S-array (ACIS-S) camera (ID: 08700025, PI: G. Garmire). After smoothing the X-ray map using the <span class=\"monospace\">ASMOOTH</span> algorithm (Ebeling, White &amp; Rangarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), we compare the smoothed X-ray map to the positions of the four-clump mass model components (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, right). While the results here are not as definitive as in the cluster-light case, we do still see a moderate agreement between the map and the clump positions. Generally, the X-ray contours are also slightly extended in the vicinity of the crown clump, again hinting at the presence of an additional potential well.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Focusing more closely on the X-ray contours, we can see that they follow a distinct box-like pattern, which is especially noticeable in the outskirts of the cluster. Interestingly, the mass contours in the four-clump model have a similar shape, largely driven by the overlap between the northern cluster halo and the central bar. Given the rough agreement between the X-ray and mass contours, it is possible that the best-fitting positions of the northern mass clumps are more than a simple degeneracy, but instead driven by physical parameters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thus, taken as a whole, the combination of physical and statistical evidence indicates that the additional mass clumps in the cluster centre and crown region are necessary components of the mass model. This suggests an even more complex mass distribution than previously thought, motivating future studies in this area.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277427 id=\"88277427\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Comparisons with other models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Thanks to the discovery of several new lensing constraints, our picture of the A370 mass distribution is beginning to evolve. While the addition of new mass clumps is the largest change, it is not the only difference. To get a better understanding of these changes and what they mean physically, we can compare our model to previous results. This is especially easy with the models presented by Johnson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), since they were both also generated with <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span>, using a similar set of parameters. On the whole, while the total mass of A370 remains largely unchanged between models, where the mass enclosed within a 500\u00a0kpc circular radius is \u223c8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> in each case, the distribution of mass between various components does not. In particular, we find that the cluster halo associated with the southern BCG (DM1) is much rounder and more compact than either of the previous models, flattening the mass profile in this region. This is predominantly due to the number of radial, five-image systems seen near the southern cluster (Systems 7, 14 and 15), as a more elliptical mass distribution would break the symmetry and destroy the radial arcs. Conversely, the northern cluster halo (DM2) is more elliptical and tilted at a steeper angle away from north, though this is largely driven by model degeneracies between DM2 and the central bar component. Both cluster potentials are also considerably less massive in our model, which is another consequence of the bar. Finally, we note that our model favours a significantly larger <em>L</em>* galaxy velocity dispersion, placing more emphasis on localized substructure contributions to the total mass profile. A list of specific parameter differences can be seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> .</p>                        <a id=\"88277429\" scrollto-destination=\"88277429\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Model parameter comparisons.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Parameter<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Model<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<sub>0</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(kpc)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(kpc)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" no-formula-id\">|$^{+100}_{-46}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>0.47<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.02}_{-0.03}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>80.8<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+0.99}_{-0.74}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>88.2<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$^{+8.7}_{-5.7}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[1500]<sup><em>b</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>R14\u00a0</td><td>833<span class=\"inline-formula
