-2.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN009\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN009\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Model Key \u2013 J14: Johnson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), R14: Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), L16: this work.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN010\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN010\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277429\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to specific model parameters, we can also compare the total mass properties of our model. For this exercise, we turn to the public models constructed for the HFF lens modelling initiative. In the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, we show the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve for our best-fitting model, compared to the magnification maps of three different HFF models: \u2018CATS\u2019, from the Clusters As TelescopeS team, (Co-PIs: J.P. Kneib and P. Natarajan), \u2018Sharon v.2\u2019 (PI: K. Sharon) and \u2018Zitrin-LTM\u2019 (PI: A. Zitrin). We select these models because they are constructed using only strong-lensing constraints, and because the resolution of their magnification maps at the core of the cluster is sufficiently high enough to compare their critical curves. In general, the shape of our curve largely traces the high-magnification regions in the other models, suggesting a broad agreement between our work and earlier studies. However, we do note that our curve has a boxier shape, due to the interaction between the northern cluster halo and the central bar and to the presence of the crown clump. Furthermore, the radial critical region (traced out by the internal orange line) is much larger in our model. This is again a result of the rounder, flatter mass distribution predicted by our model, and also highlights the increased area containing radial lensing constraints such as Systems 7, 14 and 15.</p>                        <a id=\"88277431\" scrollto-destination=\"88277431\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=CV0hMwanUdQIF1aKfp5VwDWDoApPQg5quOjmy07dTTFPpecinMRm2nGcWLmU1HQUjvGrIOogxrsdzkpyRmTke4CvQta4taeUg0as6L6Vbitih4cZQerJu7wN7jTyei4VBkPKSiKh0OjcOYYD1fSVABC7i4G2Q1nTZ9opNMW9FxUERToffhpos43-Xv21oiHEu2j2aqUVPePpcfwOQojP6nCsKg9FXIxF~OzV3c7w7QH42C9DGK~NQ2ZXLgU39V45NFIGgoOOYm6W7-zBJFuO75zo8iFFTEPv5JhhNRnre9I60FBvpsTB9a4P4GtoyX9MijzyGCI9a4KoPpRMBE-q-w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparisons between our best-fitting mass model and previous HFF models. Left: magnification maps of the CATS (blue), Sharon (green) and Zitrin-LTM (red) models, compared to the z\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve of our model (orange line). Areas of high magnification (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a020) appear as the coloured regions in each map. We see good agreement between our model and the others, but our model has a larger radial critical region (internal orange line) driven by the discovery of several radial lens systems. Additionally, our critical line has a boxier shape than the other models, due to the orientation of the northern cluster potential and the central bar (Table\u00a04). Right: radial surface mass density profile, using several HFF public models. Our model (orange dashed line) has a lower value at small radii, due to the radial caustic region. At\u00a0\u223c250\u00a0kpc, we see a distinct bump, which represents the additional mass clump in the crown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277431/stx1079fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277431\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=m-DXDMK3arSiHsTY4jAXu6xymDfS2pzhjrZQuNvmHhWXBo6dXTBvVyzRvNYSFJ3Lhg0HZ-ycmnroFTIfUSHC-ZhuqGi~HsBO1JWEdFre-Z~eMqTlG0NJ17fAHvjPYqgGi~FGQmQoPXQVqGYgtjWBTy4-MBnFzGs4F36JAImsDvS1WtFsUVSMWZp~N3xDhBJ6ZpGNrCkyNdU7qHA4wRoJqw7HeIqa33kwcPKttMBSm5RkFcXERCnOt~8YwSjHP7iUIhYFg~s0K~cwOZMVcN3iwW3zWFLiEfLYnCg0AWclxtoHIpjXGSHYrqIKDLWTU4WTZmZBF16Qxqt7MCLznx6gEA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277431&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between our best-fitting mass model and previous HFF models. Left: magnification maps of the CATS (blue), Sharon (green) and Zitrin-LTM (red) models, compared to the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve of our model (orange line). Areas of high magnification (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a020) appear as the coloured regions in each map. We see good agreement between our model and the others, but our model has a larger radial critical region (internal orange line) driven by the discovery of several radial lens systems. Additionally, our critical line has a boxier shape than the other models, due to the orientation of the northern cluster potential and the central bar (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). Right: radial surface mass density profile, using several HFF public models. Our model (orange dashed line) has a lower value at small radii, due to the radial caustic region. At\u00a0\u223c250\u00a0kpc, we see a distinct bump, which represents the additional mass clump in the crown.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=CV0hMwanUdQIF1aKfp5VwDWDoApPQg5quOjmy07dTTFPpecinMRm2nGcWLmU1HQUjvGrIOogxrsdzkpyRmTke4CvQta4taeUg0as6L6Vbitih4cZQerJu7wN7jTyei4VBkPKSiKh0OjcOYYD1fSVABC7i4G2Q1nTZ9opNMW9FxUERToffhpos43-Xv21oiHEu2j2aqUVPePpcfwOQojP6nCsKg9FXIxF~OzV3c7w7QH42C9DGK~NQ2ZXLgU39V45NFIGgoOOYm6W7-zBJFuO75zo8iFFTEPv5JhhNRnre9I60FBvpsTB9a4P4GtoyX9MijzyGCI9a4KoPpRMBE-q-w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparisons between our best-fitting mass model and previous HFF models. Left: magnification maps of the CATS (blue), Sharon (green) and Zitrin-LTM (red) models, compared to the z\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve of our model (orange line). Areas of high magnification (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a020) appear as the coloured regions in each map. We see good agreement between our model and the others, but our model has a larger radial critical region (internal orange line) driven by the discovery of several radial lens systems. Additionally, our critical line has a boxier shape than the other models, due to the orientation of the northern cluster potential and the central bar (Table\u00a04). Right: radial surface mass density profile, using several HFF public models. Our model (orange dashed line) has a lower value at small radii, due to the radial caustic region. At\u00a0\u223c250\u00a0kpc, we see a distinct bump, which represents the additional mass clump in the crown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277431/stx1079fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277431\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=m-DXDMK3arSiHsTY4jAXu6xymDfS2pzhjrZQuNvmHhWXBo6dXTBvVyzRvNYSFJ3Lhg0HZ-ycmnroFTIfUSHC-ZhuqGi~HsBO1JWEdFre-Z~eMqTlG0NJ17fAHvjPYqgGi~FGQmQoPXQVqGYgtjWBTy4-MBnFzGs4F36JAImsDvS1WtFsUVSMWZp~N3xDhBJ6ZpGNrCkyNdU7qHA4wRoJqw7HeIqa33kwcPKttMBSm5RkFcXERCnOt~8YwSjHP7iUIhYFg~s0K~cwOZMVcN3iwW3zWFLiEfLYnCg0AWclxtoHIpjXGSHYrqIKDLWTU4WTZmZBF16Qxqt7MCLznx6gEA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277431&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between our best-fitting mass model and previous HFF models. Left: magnification maps of the CATS (blue), Sharon (green) and Zitrin-LTM (red) models, compared to the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve of our model (orange line). Areas of high magnification (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a020) appear as the coloured regions in each map. We see good agreement between our model and the others, but our model has a larger radial critical region (internal orange line) driven by the discovery of several radial lens systems. Additionally, our critical line has a boxier shape than the other models, due to the orientation of the northern cluster potential and the central bar (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). Right: radial surface mass density profile, using several HFF public models. Our model (orange dashed line) has a lower value at small radii, due to the radial caustic region. At\u00a0\u223c250\u00a0kpc, we see a distinct bump, which represents the additional mass clump in the crown.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">These features can also be seen in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, where we show the radial surface mass density profile for several models (including Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), starting from a point roughly centred between the two BCGs (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2^{\\rm h}{}39^{\\rm m}{}52{^{\\rm s}_{.}}937$|\u2060</span>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121\u00b0 34<sup>\u0384</sup> 37<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>003). At small radii (&lt;100\u00a0kpc), our mass profile is lower than several others, since this region covers the flatter core responsible for the extended radial critical curve. On the other hand, our model profile is slightly higher than the others between 200 and 300\u00a0kpc, due to the crown mass clump.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Of course, important spatial information is lost when the mass map is radially averaged, so it is important to look for differences in the full 2D mass distribution, as well. For this test, we compare our four-clump model to the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), which is also generated from the HFF data, but constructed in a completely independent way, reducing potential sources of unknown bias. In that work, the driver model is constructed to recreate the positions of 10 very secure lens systems, including seven systems identified here (Systems 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7 and 9). Unlike our purely parametric approach, this model uses a broad grid of 2D Gaussians to characterize the smooth, cluster-scale mass distribution, along with a compact light-traces-mass component for bright galaxies (similar to our own method). To make the comparison, we subtract the free-form model's mass density map from our own map, measuring relative differences on a pixel-by-pixel basis. The results can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. Overall, we do see differences between the two approaches: the Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) model is generally more concentrated and slightly rounder. Our parametric approach shows a noticeable overdensity in the vicinity of the crown, due to the crown mass clump (DM4) in the east, and the extension of the northern cluster clump and the central bar (DM2 and DM3, respectively) in the north-west. The parametric model also has a larger fraction of total mass in the outskirts of the cluster, which is also seen in the radial profile presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. While model differences can be large at large radii \u2013 the parametric model is roughly twice as dense as the free-form model at the edges of the map \u2013 we note that the absolute mass density values at these distances are very small (\u223c10<sup>8</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>) and contribute a negligible amount to the total mass budget. Conversely, the relative differences near the cluster centre are typically less than 10 per\u00a0cent, resulting in an overall good agreement between the two models.</p>                        <a id=\"88277434\" scrollto-destination=\"88277434\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ytDNWS1tDzPNd3HcnJO0qF2L4ineKC~e2bryuM3OzZNCi3IabYn-ZdOEgjiYeQRnfKYuz82wMAGlDD4c8FHzHflwIbepqLkVWRq-b~g9O4J~v~4rsVjdhgUhuBYFTql6Yfa4RK5dUO3aJ2ziaJFWMPnASUiTnQvu1a8DaGEIldiUWJ~YeeTMkRXMI9wOkRjGXeWmhUyLrs-mrMWzHeMCR7hYa0QoNuD1EzGcKKQm2KR9k2sBLfh-7AXiG2pdmt5jDj0KQ0GRzdX9x0I9zlV6xrZofFpn3IqHTLL4r6BxAbmJOhuc0~asKJiAdFjpp95s2EyKdjm5RhrX6ZcgZjljag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residual mass density map between our best parametric model and the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (2016). In this plot, red represents an overdensity in the parametric model, while blue represents an overdensity in the free-form case. Although there are differences in the spatial distributions of the models, the typical variation is less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent. We note that the largest deviations appear in the cluster outskirts, where the absolute mass density is small. As a result, the total mass is roughly the same in both cases.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277434/stx1079fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277434\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=PZoMOlnTWstH4WFyHWEkpUvRGRqJ2wfrdonaXeX1S3EnZY7c1U1SHjJByo-qBY2XiobOIGpsJ7PGq~ge-kK6VKRPZtNWE0VpVuh~8~ReyrTSs~SJBve2v1N0fvJ87UKxetXIe4AH01u6T6FYH9r1frXupo4PvAtXdBY18-ijUJP18XD3l8dBwskQplE2NfjcKJpikYPrEvYT600R0LwkjSFi-nqCuqbA9LwfB7W802rjN7PcDYAkQaLHoSdp0dKB13Tfa31hDiYCC01YTkEAPhVHMFINfY10wKaKzGu8ptWPg-sAB0yllgI3ea7Tu344MNRRc8IJ9x06hwFS4qLdHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277434&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residual mass density map between our best parametric model and the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In this plot, red represents an overdensity in the parametric model, while blue represents an overdensity in the free-form case. Although there are differences in the spatial distributions of the models, the typical variation is less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent. We note that the largest deviations appear in the cluster outskirts, where the absolute mass density is small. As a result, the total mass is roughly the same in both cases.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ytDNWS1tDzPNd3HcnJO0qF2L4ineKC~e2bryuM3OzZNCi3IabYn-ZdOEgjiYeQRnfKYuz82wMAGlDD4c8FHzHflwIbepqLkVWRq-b~g9O4J~v~4rsVjdhgUhuBYFTql6Yfa4RK5dUO3aJ2ziaJFWMPnASUiTnQvu1a8DaGEIldiUWJ~YeeTMkRXMI9wOkRjGXeWmhUyLrs-mrMWzHeMCR7hYa0QoNuD1EzGcKKQm2KR9k2sBLfh-7AXiG2pdmt5jDj0KQ0GRzdX9x0I9zlV6xrZofFpn3IqHTLL4r6BxAbmJOhuc0~asKJiAdFjpp95s2EyKdjm5RhrX6ZcgZjljag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residual mass density map between our best parametric model and the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (2016). In this plot, red represents an overdensity in the parametric model, while blue represents an overdensity in the free-form case. Although there are differences in the spatial distributions of the models, the typical variation is less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent. We note that the largest deviations appear in the cluster outskirts, where the absolute mass density is small. As a result, the total mass is roughly the same in both cases.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277434/stx1079fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277434\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=PZoMOlnTWstH4WFyHWEkpUvRGRqJ2wfrdonaXeX1S3EnZY7c1U1SHjJByo-qBY2XiobOIGpsJ7PGq~ge-kK6VKRPZtNWE0VpVuh~8~ReyrTSs~SJBve2v1N0fvJ87UKxetXIe4AH01u6T6FYH9r1frXupo4PvAtXdBY18-ijUJP18XD3l8dBwskQplE2NfjcKJpikYPrEvYT600R0LwkjSFi-nqCuqbA9LwfB7W802rjN7PcDYAkQaLHoSdp0dKB13Tfa31hDiYCC01YTkEAPhVHMFINfY10wKaKzGu8ptWPg-sAB0yllgI3ea7Tu344MNRRc8IJ9x06hwFS4qLdHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277434&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residual mass density map between our best parametric model and the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In this plot, red represents an overdensity in the parametric model, while blue represents an overdensity in the free-form case. Although there are differences in the spatial distributions of the models, the typical variation is less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent. We note that the largest deviations appear in the cluster outskirts, where the absolute mass density is small. As a result, the total mass is roughly the same in both cases.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we can compare our model (and all models) of A370 to other clusters in the HFF programme. The combined rms error for our best-fitting model (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.94\u00a0arcsec) is higher than the error presented in Johnson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.82\u00a0arcsec), comparable to the error in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.93\u00a0arcsec), and smaller than the error presented in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 1.76\u00a0arcsec). However all of these rms values are larger than the best-fitting models of most other HFF clusters, such as MACS 0416 (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.6\u00a0arcsec; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) or Abell 2744 (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.7\u00a0arcsec; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Instead, while not as large, our rms is more similar to MACS 0717 (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 1.9\u00a0arcsec; Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Like MACS 0717, A370 is a complex cluster, with several interacting mass components covering a large field of view. In fact, the A370 \u2018multiple-image zone\u2019 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>), the region predicted to contain all multiple images out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a010), is the second largest of all of the Frontier Fields, behind only MACS 0717. Given the similarities, it is therefore unsurprising that the typical rms is also high.</p>                        <a id=\"88277436\" scrollto-destination=\"88277436\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=AC~zlXcyT3XFHZ8Xuhep1AZy229hdgSKJi8V75166LDYbvDMA28AQlJx6eRX1QSD8B4GcCYNiQEbugj6sXBQlsH0iuoin9lpR8WSFOHTtQpjQzlkxo~1quMIODDp2qXc0H58vymQgoOAr67jH2Sphl5k8shy8IYjLyUtApSeXb~Fg2MC1VRzh416OwfN5yoIska0oYSiijXIosLoVjNv62c19ksqzMhe5awFTq-y10wtFfGJ1hOMO-5gtHFIGHLDtN~3~xfPYmrw~Svw5gBDPWi~xNdNhchzE9uLa8VF8wurbB0YJ-2tyTc08yPDFAepeoFAYlq0GBsKnsivfzPGFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Extent of the \u2018multi-image zone\u2019 (yellow curve) as predicted by the best A370 mass model. This region represents the area that encloses all expected multiple images out to high redshift (z\u00a0=\u00a010). The MUSE data footprint (white square) is again included for reference, and is considerably smaller than the multi-image zone. Additionally, three critical curves are displayed, highlighting lines of high magnification for three redshifts: z\u00a0=\u00a01 (cyan), z\u00a0=\u00a03 (green) and z\u00a0=\u00a09 (red). These lines are heavily clustered around the BCGs and the northern galaxy crown (noted by the dashed contour). Finally, all image constraints used in the model are shown as magenta circles.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277436/stx1079fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277436\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=wtQnyEMBoRVLBUE9oNIanzzRmgPzVIs~KJB3wUvCOAdMOouGUcVOfrnUN9~i2gVG6jb4Zm7AzpQkZ8IdkT-tB-6Czq1hXcspxDwpqDv-N6d8R9DGEKK7MndJVGf1WRK~njbvS5hFE0qFAK9hqUzavEnSzZzg7Qbyc92l0yVQ3W3TSastDljnyij1rmBV1l8bPhzJJ0ASNOIrrQ8wGEIA~uvx15Ay9YNMMdIGX15eRZTUSJlZTe7RXpUK6Z0lqI8jluGWK64KW46hU65FivjTssYp84RfuDFNws~FH4Wb8-F5N85CJ70BPPFNxtLHPtxmvrSLZznkwY7oJvsmPuBvlQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277436&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Extent of the \u2018multi-image zone\u2019 (yellow curve) as predicted by the best A370 mass model. This region represents the area that encloses all expected multiple images out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a010). The MUSE data footprint (white square) is again included for reference, and is considerably smaller than the multi-image zone. Additionally, three critical curves are displayed, highlighting lines of high magnification for three redshifts: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 (cyan), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03 (green) and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09 (red). These lines are heavily clustered around the BCGs and the northern galaxy crown (noted by the dashed contour). Finally, all image constraints used in the model are shown as magenta circles.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=AC~zlXcyT3XFHZ8Xuhep1AZy229hdgSKJi8V75166LDYbvDMA28AQlJx6eRX1QSD8B4GcCYNiQEbugj6sXBQlsH0iuoin9lpR8WSFOHTtQpjQzlkxo~1quMIODDp2qXc0H58vymQgoOAr67jH2Sphl5k8shy8IYjLyUtApSeXb~Fg2MC1VRzh416OwfN5yoIska0oYSiijXIosLoVjNv62c19ksqzMhe5awFTq-y10wtFfGJ1hOMO-5gtHFIGHLDtN~3~xfPYmrw~Svw5gBDPWi~xNdNhchzE9uLa8VF8wurbB0YJ-2tyTc08yPDFAepeoFAYlq0GBsKnsivfzPGFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Extent of the \u2018multi-image zone\u2019 (yellow curve) as predicted by the best A370 mass model. This region represents the area that encloses all expected multiple images out to high redshift (z\u00a0=\u00a010). The MUSE data footprint (white square) is again included for reference, and is considerably smaller than the multi-image zone. Additionally, three critical curves are displayed, highlighting lines of high magnification for three redshifts: z\u00a0=\u00a01 (cyan), z\u00a0=\u00a03 (green) and z\u00a0=\u00a09 (red). These lines are heavily clustered around the BCGs and the northern galaxy crown (noted by the dashed contour). Finally, all image constraints used in the model are shown as magenta circles.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277436/stx1079fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277436\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=wtQnyEMBoRVLBUE9oNIanzzRmgPzVIs~KJB3wUvCOAdMOouGUcVOfrnUN9~i2gVG6jb4Zm7AzpQkZ8IdkT-tB-6Czq1hXcspxDwpqDv-N6d8R9DGEKK7MndJVGf1WRK~njbvS5hFE0qFAK9hqUzavEnSzZzg7Qbyc92l0yVQ3W3TSastDljnyij1rmBV1l8bPhzJJ0ASNOIrrQ8wGEIA~uvx15Ay9YNMMdIGX15eRZTUSJlZTe7RXpUK6Z0lqI8jluGWK64KW46hU65FivjTssYp84RfuDFNws~FH4Wb8-F5N85CJ70BPPFNxtLHPtxmvrSLZznkwY7oJvsmPuBvlQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277436&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Extent of the \u2018multi-image zone\u2019 (yellow curve) as predicted by the best A370 mass model. This region represents the area that encloses all expected multiple images out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a010). The MUSE data footprint (white square) is again included for reference, and is considerably smaller than the multi-image zone. Additionally, three critical curves are displayed, highlighting lines of high magnification for three redshifts: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 (cyan), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03 (green) and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09 (red). These lines are heavily clustered around the BCGs and the northern galaxy crown (noted by the dashed contour). Finally, all image constraints used in the model are shown as magenta circles.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To reduce the total rms further, we need to explore the other areas of the cluster with MUSE. This will help to refine the model even more and allow us to test whether or not our current interpretation is correct. In particular, the crown mass clump may only be a temporary solution; future data may require additional large-scale haloes, or even suggest an alternative to the crown. We cannot be sure of this until we have additional constraints in the north. Fortunately, such a survey is currently underway (PI: F. Bauer), and the results of this study will be the topic of a future paper.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277438 id=\"88277438\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we have presented a new mass model for the A370 cluster, taking advantage of deep HFF imaging and new MUSE spectroscopy. Our main conclusions are as follows. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a MUSE-based redshift catalogue for A370, consisting of 120 secure redshifts (\u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.1\u2009per\u2009cent), including 34 multiply imaged background objects (comprising 15 unique systems), 13 singly imaged background galaxies, 56 cluster members, 13 foreground galaxies and 4 stars.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Together, HFF and MUSE data are a powerful combination, greatly improving our ability to construct lens models. The MUSE spectroscopy is particularly valuable for this work, as it can be used to blindly identify new lensing constraints without selecting a specific redshift range.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">After constructing a mass model with the new multiply imaged constraints, we find two key differences with previous work. <ol class=\"number\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2003\u2003\u2002(1) A central core that is flatter and less massive due to an \u2003increase in radial lensing systems.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2003\u2003\u2002(2) The need for additional large-scale mass clumps (\u2018the bar\u2019 \u2003and \u2018the crown\u2019) to better fit lensing constraints in the\u00a0north of \u2003the cluster.</p></li></ol></p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A lack of model constraints in the north makes accurate comparisons difficult. We will need more MUSE data, covering a larger area of the A370 cluster to discriminate between possible interpretations. These data are currently being taken, and will be the subject of an upcoming paper.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additionally, our model can be used as a guide for upcoming observations, as high-magnification regions in our models (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>) should be ideal places to look for new, magnified high-redshift galaxies. With new MUSE spectroscopy on the way, the A370 cluster should continue to provide a wealth of new information in the future.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277441 id=\"88277441\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgments</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors wish to thank the anonymous referee for providing several helpful comments and suggestions to improve the manuscript. DJL thanks Jose M. Diego for providing a mass density map of his \u2018driver\u2019 model, which was useful for the quantitative comparisons in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. DJL, JR, BC, GM, VP and JM acknowledge support from the European Research Council (ERC) starting grant 336736-CALENDS. This work has been carried out thanks to the support of the Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR) FOGHAR (ANR-13-BS05-0010-02) and the Origines Constituants et EVolution de l'Univers (OCEVU) Labex (ANR-11-LABX-0060). LW acknowledges support by the Competitive Fund of the Leibniz Association through grant SAW-2015-AIP-2. Some of the data presented in this paper were obtained from the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST) at the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI). STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span The region of the cluster covered by the MUSE GTO programme is shown in white. In addition, the positions of the multiply imaged systems used as constraints in the mass model (Section 4) are shown as coloured circles. Previously known systems are in red, while newly identified objects are in green. () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>David J. Lagattuta, Johan Richard, Benjamin Cl\u00e9ment, Guillaume Mahler, Vera Patr\u00edcio, Roser Pell\u00f3, Genevi\u00e8ve Soucail, Kasper B. Schmidt, Lutz Wisotzki, Johany Martinez, David Bina,  Lens modelling Abell 370: crowning the final frontier field with MUSE, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 469, Issue 4, August 2017, Pages 3946\u20133964, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stx1079\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stx1079</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form action=\"/Citation/Download\" method=\"get\" id=\"citationModal\">\r\n            <input type=\"hidden\" name=\"resourceId\" value=\"3800685\" />\r\n class=\"widget widget-ToolboxPermissions widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\r\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution js-nav-dropdown\">\r\n                            University           <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f469%2f4%2f3946%2f3800685\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n   <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input        <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277354 id=\"88277354\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a strong lensing analysis on the massive cluster Abell 370 (A370; <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.375), using a combination of deep multiband <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) imaging and Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) spectroscopy. From only 2\u00a0h of the MUSE data, we are able to measure 120 redshifts in the southern BCG area, including several multiply imaged lens systems. In total, we increase the number of multiply imaged systems with a secure redshift from 4 to 15, nine of which are newly discovered. Of these, eight are located at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a03, greatly extending the redshift range of spectroscopically confirmed systems over previous work. Using these systems as constraints, we update a parametric lens model of A370, probing the mass distribution from cluster to galaxy scales. Overall, we find that a model with only two cluster-scale dark matter haloes (one for each BCG) does a poor job of fitting these new image constraints. Instead, two additional mass clumps \u2013 a central \u2018bar\u2019 of mass located between the BCGs, and another clump located within a \u2018crown\u2019 of galaxies in the northern part of the cluster field \u2013 provide significant improvements to the fit. Additional physical evidence suggests these clumps are indeed real features of the system, but with relatively few image constraints in the crown region, this claim is difficult to evaluate from a modelling perspective. Additional MUSE observations of A370 covering the entire strong-lensing region will greatly help these efforts, further improving our understanding of this intriguing cluster.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: imaging spectroscopy&quot;\">techniques: imaging spectroscopy</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 370&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual: Abell 370</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift \u2013 dark matter&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift \u2013 dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277356 id=\"88277356\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy clusters acting as strong gravitational lenses are powerful astrophysical laboratories. The lensed background sources constrain the cluster mass model, providing insight into the mass environments of the densest regions of the Universe (Brada\u010d et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; Hsu, Ebeling &amp; Richard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Massey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). At the same time, the cluster magnifies these sources, making them larger, brighter and better resolved. This allows for more detailed studies of faint, low-mass, high-redshift galaxies, opening a window into the early Universe (Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Sharon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Monna et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Over the past decade, cluster lensing science has significantly expanded, and hundreds of new lensed systems have been discovered (e.g. Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Hoag et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Kawamata et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). This is largely thanks to improved modelling techniques (such as Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a> and Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the efforts of deep, high-resolution imaging campaigns (e.g. Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schmidt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), driven primarily by the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">But while these imaging campaigns are able to identify and resolve background sources like never before, imaging alone does not provide high-precision (\u0394<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.01) redshift information, a crucial component in interpreting models and deriving their physical values. While some spectroscopic campaigns are underway (e.g. Rosati et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), acquiring spectra of lensed systems has, to date, largely been a long, costly and inefficient process. With the advent of Integral Field Unit (IFU) spectroscopy, however, this situation is rapidly changing. Leading the way in these efforts is the Multi-Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) a wide-field IFU on the Very Large Telescope (VLT) in Chile. With a large 1\u00a0arcmin<sup>2</sup> field of view and high sensitivity between 4800 and 9300 \u00c5, MUSE is an incredibly efficient redshift engine, providing several hundred redshifts between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06 in only a few hours of exposure time (e.g. Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). As an IFU, MUSE is also well suited for blind redshift surveys, able to detect emission lines from continuum-free sources without pre-selecting a redshift range. These objects (which are often missed in traditional broad-band imaging campaigns) include high-redshift, lensed Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emitters. This has been, unsurprisingly, a boon to the lensing community, and some studies have already begun to take advantage of the MUSE data (e.g. Karman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bina et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we present new MUSE data of the strong lensing cluster Abell 370 (A370; Abell <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1958</a>). A370 is a massive cluster (<em>M</em><sub>vir</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>15</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>; Umetsu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.375 (Mellier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) with historical significance to lensing: it contains one of the first known \u2018Giant Luminous Arc\u2019 features (Lynds &amp; Petrosian <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>), which later became the first spectroscopically confirmed giant-arc lens system (Soucail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Lynds &amp; Petrosian <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>). Thanks to this discovery, and the identification of other lensed features (Hammer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Paczynski <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Fort et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Mellier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>), A370 became an important benchmark in the early days of lens modelling (e.g. Hammer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>; Smail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; B\u00e9zecourt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). However, after an initial period of activity, interest in A370 slowly waned; there was little spectroscopic follow-up on the cluster, and it was not selected to be a part of massive cluster surveys such as MACS (Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) or CLASH (Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), in spite of its high X-ray luminosity (<em>L</em><sub><em>x</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>45</sup>\u00a0erg\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>; Morandi, Ettori &amp; Moscardini <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In 2010, a newly refurbished <em>HST</em> observed A370 to test its deep-imaging capabilities, generating renewed interest. This led to a new lens model (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), additional weak-lensing analyses (Medezinski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Umetsu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and its eventual selection as one of the Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF) clusters (Lotz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Several groups have since modelled the cluster (see the HFF archive<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> and also Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a> and Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), but (until recently) only three lensed systems have had a secure redshift, all with <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.2 (see Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.1.1</a> for details). As a result, these models are only able to probe the critical line region of the cluster out to small radii. While recent work by Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) has increased the number of secure-redshift systems, the highest of these is still <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02. Here, we extend the redshift range of spectroscopically confirmed systems even further and present newly discovered systems as well. By combining the MUSE spectroscopy with the current HFF data, we can therefore improve on existing lens models, probing the mass distribution out to larger scales and with much higher precision. In this way, we can improve our view of this massive cluster in conjunction with the final HFF data release.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overall, this work is organized as follows: in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe the MUSE and HFF data and the data reduction processes we used. In Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, we describe how we extract MUSE redshifts and present the A370 redshift catalogue, paying particular attention to redshifts of the multiply imaged galaxies. Using these redshifts, we construct a new mass model, which we present in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>. We discuss the results of the mass modelling and make predictions for future work in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. Finally, we briefly conclude in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a>. Throughout this paper, we assume a standard cosmological model with \u03a9<sub><em>M</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. Using this model, 1\u00a0arcsec covers a physical distance of 5.162\u00a0kpc at the A370 redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.375). All magnitudes are measured using the AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277362 id=\"88277362\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing is a three-dimensional effect, sensitive to both the transverse and line-of-sight distances between objects. Therefore, we need a combination of imaging data (to identify lensed objects and measure their apparent positions) and redshift data (to measure radial distances) to construct an accurate lens model of A370.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277364 id=\"88277364\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 <em>HST</em> imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> imaging data of A370 were taken as part of the HFF Programme, and are publicly available on the HFF website.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> While the imaging campaign for A370 is now complete, the Epoch 1 (v1.0) mosaics that we use in this work consist of deep Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS; Ford et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) data in three optical bands, <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> (ID: 13504, PI: J. Lotz). These are supplemented by shallower <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> imaging from archival programmes: (ID: 11507, PI: K. Noll) and (ID: 11591, PI: J.-P. Kneib). Additionally, shallow, archival, Wide-Field Camera 3 (Kimble et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) data are available in three bands: <em>F</em>105<em>W</em> (ID: 13459, PI: T. Treu), <em>F</em>140<em>W</em> (ID: 11108, PI: E. Hu; ID: 13459, PI: T. Treu) and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> (ID: 11591, PI: J.-P. Kneib; ID: 14216, PI: R. Kirshner), and a shallow, pilot HF exposure, also in the <em>F</em>140<em>W</em> band.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Individual exposures are reduced and stacked by the HFF team directly, using the standard Pyraf/STSDAS pipeline. Additionally, the ACS mosaics are further corrected with a \u2018self-calibration\u2019 technique to eliminate charge transfer inefficiency effects and low-level pixel noise<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> (J. Anderson, in preparation). The full reduction procedure is described in the A370 HFF data archive.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After combining all exposures, total integration times are 51\u00a0400, 25\u00a0316, 130\u00a0643, 2335, 12\u00a0894 and 9647\u00a0s for the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>105<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>140<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> bands, respectively. This is equivalent to 20, 10, 52, 1, 5 and 4 <em>HST</em> orbits. Collectively, this represents one of the deepest, highest resolution imaging of A370 ever taken, and corresponds to average limiting magnitudes of 29.3 in the optical bands and 27.6 in the near-IR bands. A colour image of the cluster field consisting of the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> mosaics is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277368\" scrollto-destination=\"88277368\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ab472ahmRhqwFr52o8Fd5monWn4d1yp~O1gpd6b~zBFQFN2Q6e9gc8utfnQhif3726jk7Fg6yg4xSUXnmS9zUqnVtdNbX1PHkU~CfqtAZ74UNvk5fiyKUCP7J9vP-wfqKxj~hjYVRbgRxBkpwh6sPbAkF0qDjZ-F0sm2xoWNKgOM1z7piNIUMSum8cIEeOab7Yd2O53nroMHzomlI7IkweBM1t1gJ8Nqxg~eC2cms7CwMZuEkr5sGEc4uQarnAAbQPdtZdr7B3W~KJnjhrJLKK5dLay-hBV3UlqVsEK5pbp9ScoHd7CyseOQDsxjhqx-O1AJJuvF4Tjx71tql23gsA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A colour image of the A370 field of view, using the F435W, F606W and F814W observations from the HFF project. In addition, the positions of the multiply imaged systems used as constraints in the mass model (Section 4) are shown as coloured circles. Previously known systems are in red, while newly identified objects are in green. Images predicted by the model but not detected in either imaging or spectroscopic data are shown in yellow.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277368/stx1079fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277368\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=J1LOOC7EXomm3DmHjoI53xQktbuy4KTwAUqpPeDfQe151DDXaNrT5s9ceN2lQLVNsJR4krgQaUpWuuXcNm8j~tq6gSNyZpa2i5xFYnaNyK23Ly6cmgpYkkxaOmL-8LZIU48eAaJBc0LBKNIxK8TY~NF8bLWmcn4GnoKUYyU~0h-7Rqi-mLW2MOgju~RDPQ5UJLntrBhOUo6j6jMjZ6ANj4O~Kd8UCJ3OmsG4lxx3NnJrVmrq5shkvoMEYCbOdNJApPTtDj-3cMOycIwsgtCEnzF~kVEqtvvr~B7tYDlDk~GkfLGILPhfiks1H6srdCIz7MECh4KXoJ3-iZYHi-Zuww__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277368&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A colour image of the A370 field of view, using the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> observations from the HFF project. The region of the cluster covered by the MUSE GTO programme is shown in white. In addition, the positions of the multiply imaged systems used as constraints in the mass model (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>) are shown as coloured circles. Previously known systems are in red, while newly identified objects are in green. Images predicted by the model but not detected in either imaging or spectroscopic data are shown in yellow.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ab472ahmRhqwFr52o8Fd5monWn4d1yp~O1gpd6b~zBFQFN2Q6e9gc8utfnQhif3726jk7Fg6yg4xSUXnmS9zUqnVtdNbX1PHkU~CfqtAZ74UNvk5fiyKUCP7J9vP-wfqKxj~hjYVRbgRxBkpwh6sPbAkF0qDjZ-F0sm2xoWNKgOM1z7piNIUMSum8cIEeOab7Yd2O53nroMHzomlI7IkweBM1t1gJ8Nqxg~eC2cms7CwMZuEkr5sGEc4uQarnAAbQPdtZdr7B3W~KJnjhrJLKK5dLay-hBV3UlqVsEK5pbp9ScoHd7CyseOQDsxjhqx-O1AJJuvF4Tjx71tql23gsA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A colour image of the A370 field of view, using the F435W, F606W and F814W observations from the HFF project. The region of the cluster covered by the MUSE GTO programme is shown in white. In addition, the positions of the multiply imaged systems used as constraints in the mass model (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>) are shown as coloured circles. Previously known systems are in red, while newly identified objects are in green. Images predicted by the model but not detected in either imaging or spectroscopic data are shown in yellow.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277369 id=\"88277369\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 MUSE spectroscopy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MUSE observations of A370 were taken on <span class=\"small-caps\">UT</span> 2014 November 20, as part of the Guaranteed Time Observing (GTO) Programme 094.A-0115(A) (PI: Richard). In total, we observed four 30-min exposures in WFM-NOAO-N mode, centred at (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a02<sup>h</sup> 39<sup>m</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$53{^{\\rm s}_{.}}111$|\u2060</span>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121\u00b0 34<sup>\u0384</sup> 55<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>77). We applied a small (\u223c 0.5\u00a0arcsec) dither pattern between exposures to average out systematics on the detector, and we alternated taking exposures between PA = 0\u00b0 and PA = 8\u00b0 to reduce the systematic striping pattern caused by the IFU image slicers. The full observational footprint can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Typical field of view during the observations was 0.75\u00a0arcsec, as measured by stars in the field.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The raw data were reduced through the MUSE pipeline (Weilbacher et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) provided by ESO (version 1.2). This pipeline performs all basic reduction techniques: bias and flat-field correction (using a combination of internal flats and illumination and twilight exposures), wavelength and geometric calibration, sky subtraction, flux calibration and telluric correction. The A370 data were flux-calibrated using a combination of several standard stars observed under photometric conditions. After basic corrections, we align individual exposures to a common world coordinate system (WCS) with <span class=\"small-caps\">scamp</span> (Bertin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), shifting each frame relative to a reference image, which in this case is the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> HFF data. We then transform the re-aligned images into data cubes, resampling all pixels on to a common three-dimensional grid with two spatial and one spectral axis. The final spectral resolution of the cubes varies from <em>R</em> = 2000 to <em>R</em> = 4000, with a spectral range between 4750 and 9350 \u00c5. To ensure that cubes are properly Nyquist-sampled, we set the wavelength grid to 1.25 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. The final spatial resolution is 0.2\u00a0arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> in order to properly sample the PSF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we process each cube with the Zurich Atmosphere Purge (<span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span>; Soto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), a software package that uses a principal component analysis technique to remove known systematics from the sky model, further improving sky-subtraction residuals. To account for changes in sky transmittance from exposure to exposure, we compare the fluxes of stars common to each cube. The cube with the brightest flux values is taken as a new photometric standard, and we scale the zero-points of the other cubes until the fluxes agree across all exposures. We then merge all cubes together to create a combined master cube. During the merging process, we apply a 3\u03c3 clipping routine to reject outliers, eliminating cosmic ray strikes and hot pixels on the detector. As a final step, we re-run the <span class=\"small-caps\">zap</span> process on the master cube in order to eliminate low-level sky residuals that can only be seen in the improved signal-to-noise ratio of the combined data.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277373 id=\"88277373\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 REDSHIFT MEASUREMENT AND SPECTROSCOPIC CATALOGUE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">After reducing the data, we probe the MUSE cube for redshifts using two complementary techniques: (1) an automated emission line detection program, and (2) a customized, interactive data visualization tool designed to extract MUSE aperture spectra by hand.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The automated program, <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> is included as part of the Muse Python Data Analysis Framework (<span class=\"small-caps\">mpdaf</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a>) version 2.0. It first creates narrow-band images of the data, averaging the flux over a narrow emission wavelength range and then subtracting a local continuum. For the A370 cube, we choose an emission window of 6.25 \u00c5 (spanning five MUSE wavelength slices), with each window centred on one of the original wavelength planes. The continuum is created by averaging two 25 \u00c5 slices, immediately bluewards and redwards of the emission window. After creating the narrow-band images, <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> uses Source Extractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) to identify emission features in each image, then merges these features together into a final master catalogue. Emission features at different wavelengths are considered to belong to the same source if they fall within 0.8\u00a0arcsec of each other (i.e. within the seeing FWHM) in the case of continuum-free detections, or if they fall within half of the effective radius (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>/2) of a continuum-emission object. For every source that has multiple emission lines identified, <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> fits a redshift using a template of known spectral lines. To ensure the accuracy of the <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span> fit, we manually inspect the line features of each identified redshift before adding it to the final catalogue.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In cases where an obvious galaxy appears in the <em>HST</em> image or MUSE cube but is undetected (absorption galaxies) or unclassified (single emission-line galaxies) by <span class=\"small-caps\">muselet</span>, we instead use the interactive tool. The tool, a custom-made <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> script, collapses the data cube along the wavelength axis, creating a \u2018white-light\u2019 image of the field. A second panel, matched to the WCS of the cube, shows a corresponding <em>HST</em> image to help identify the target galaxy. Once a galaxy has been identified, a user can draw a (circular or rectangular) aperture around the target object, which will extract both a 2D and 1D spectrum from the cube. From these spectra, the user can then interactively fit a redshift to the galaxy, using the same set of lines as the automatic line-finder. An example of this process can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. As an additional check, we run the redshift-measuring software <span class=\"small-caps\">autoz</span> (Baldry et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) on the extracted 1D spectrum. In all cases, we find the difference between the manual and <span class=\"small-caps\">autoz</span> fits to be less than \u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.001.</p>                        <a id=\"88277377\" scrollto-destination=\"88277377\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=sS~aQN1fpFw4hGlVozcs0lzI-IvDN1-MWDSLAqSAbDOtXQQ1nAZquugK~udiMp3o2fRfCVSghIPdpK0u8uaY0jNq0LXGFfGcB68CRvJS-MJOiI~KpRbav5R-NPtWgQItYkvwoDcM6Q3fdwoaBYekq5tL~ax5DatcC~qanx8~LWAFaRtk9bb~iTKxGRQj7VES1wlEz8-y64rtPDgB2SKA08ri4sZENZqGvuVLYLo4os-b8He-bDlsQF3SlHoS~~Wo2M6VxOnPa~u84lz02Weh1frEw4flWKxnUDZYk9snYnd0wPV5mL6QYHuBXIRDy2fEVCty5J-QOD19rWvNrrQZBw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sample spectrum extracted by our interactive Python tool. The Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emission is clearly detected in the spectrum and is double-peaked.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277377/stx1079fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277377\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=by1hJj~nTcjgrmE8Zxxc40FLyEDU1X0bgGSl120kPYN4v9jXHRkPG4KgBt0btPtoZaBJEKUMXYP1C43dEtdcNa5O6HaA2HLtAjNc0wOaptjBBaPtVHuti-Dc5iYD6Dtdm9ID6x2p11BSPs2uxitI0DGVeRr4uh4aFoVuzR0IcjMoyIPzdqQDqyFLC~wJNzu2RDOg-sOsa3HPAzFm~3vzhPI2Pk79RNywaOQ8P2yk3SeCPlCpL6JG3ZMYKmxKQHBENbbr5AnuM0eAa4GH7EXoxx6l21Qi8wUUCvimQzHLwztGx0jhhsuHLr~wnAzqTlpOMHCmetigLd1XZzfD84Kgfg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277377&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sample spectrum extracted by our interactive Python tool. Here, we see Image 14.1, a newly detected Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emitter at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1309. The Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emission is clearly detected in the spectrum and is double-peaked.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">After running both methods on the A370 cube, we combine all of the redshift results into a final catalogue. Overall, we securely identify 120 redshifts, consisting of multiply imaged systems, cluster members, foreground interlopers, background sources and stars. The spatial and spectral distributions of these redshifts are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277379\" scrollto-destination=\"88277379\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=d1HIVXe~OcxQ2Tz~UOpzlvvJ1KR-44FcefZHak8O0yGixSGivZzHBYHNnewNQt9Y3cMIa77ROD6RHjz58URj-B6pcC5DwQ6kH7~VoEnfXDuSWlwaFdsVU24uBfqxrsZxxoEVnkjkJYve4gxCp-f8NQ4bsjqEKZbS1NjN4Jy~zPDanlaSJKr2cR7ukcizhwKAHSyWlyb1~VblBoxTLv13Vr6jBMMnY88CbsRkOWZjQ~UYvD~8cNMwLn8rehxTQwZexVt0TnhLLZxjkGwPDHs1XvU1f4hw2mSE4eHYqEZCBT7kw~v5OP-FfuZngf6e6ruZe76cEvT3n8ehk4P~7OLa5g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: positions of all objects with a secured redshift in the MUSE GTO cube.
