Solid colour lines represent individual systems, while the hashed lines represent all the counterimages that make up these systems.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=d1HIVXe~OcxQ2Tz~UOpzlvvJ1KR-44FcefZHak8O0yGixSGivZzHBYHNnewNQt9Y3cMIa77ROD6RHjz58URj-B6pcC5DwQ6kH7~VoEnfXDuSWlwaFdsVU24uBfqxrsZxxoEVnkjkJYve4gxCp-f8NQ4bsjqEKZbS1NjN4Jy~zPDanlaSJKr2cR7ukcizhwKAHSyWlyb1~VblBoxTLv13Vr6jBMMnY88CbsRkOWZjQ~UYvD~8cNMwLn8rehxTQwZexVt0TnhLLZxjkGwPDHs1XvU1f4hw2mSE4eHYqEZCBT7kw~v5OP-FfuZngf6e6ruZe76cEvT3n8ehk4P~7OLa5g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: positions of all objects with a secured redshift in the MUSE GTO cube. The colour of each circle represents the object's type and redshift range, according to the following scheme. Purple: star (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00), blue: foreground galaxy (0\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.35), green: cluster member (0.35 \u2264 <em>z</em> \u2264 0.4), yellow: [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emitter (0.4\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5), orange: [C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emitter (1.5 \u2264 <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.0), red: Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitter (<em>z</em> \u2265 3.0). Object labels correspond to entries in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> (multiply imaged systems), Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> (cluster members) and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (foreground and background objects). Bottom left: redshift distribution of all singly imaged systems in the cube. The colour scheme is the same as in the position map. A clear overdensity of galaxies can be seen at the cluster redshift range, as expected. Bottom right: similar redshift distribution, but for the multiply imaged systems. Solid colour lines represent individual systems, while the hashed lines represent all the counterimages that make up these systems.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277380 id=\"88277380\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Multiply imaged systems</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiply imaged background sources are particularly important in this work, since they provide strong constraints on the lensing mass model (see Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>). Using a combination of the HFF imaging and the MUSE spectroscopy, we are able to identify and confirm the redshifts of previously known multi-image systems and identify new systems as well.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=88277382 id=\"88277382\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 Previously known systems</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Prior to the release of the newest HFF and MUSE data, 13 multi-image objects were identified in the A370 field (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) including three with known redshifts: Systems 1 (Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>), 2 (Soucail et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) and 6 (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). A tentative guess for System 4 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.275) using the VLT/FORS2 grism spectroscopy was also presented in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Of these systems, seven have at least one image that falls within the MUSE A370 footprint: Systems 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 9. Using the MUSE data, we are able to confirm the previous redshifts of Systems 1 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.8041), 2 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.7251) and 6 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.0633), refine and secure the redshift for System 4 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2728) and provide new redshifts for Systems 5 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2775) and 7 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.7512). We note that these new redshifts are within 2\u03c3 of the values predicted in the Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) lens model (System 4: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.34 \u00b1 0.03; System 5: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.30 \u00b1 0.05; System 7: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a04.97 \u00b1 1.17), a reasonably good agreement. We are unable to identify any strong features in System 9 because it is too faint for a secure measurement. However, Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) identify [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] features for the system in the <em>HST</em> grism spectroscopy, placing it at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.52. We note that this redshift is consistent with a non-detection in MUSE, since it falls in the \u2018redshift desert\u2019 where no strong emission features appear in the MUSE wavelength range. Additionally, Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) also identify faint [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission for System 3 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.95. We adopt these redshift values in this work, also.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=88277384 id=\"88277384\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 New systems</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the known objects, we also identify nine new multiply imaged systems in the MUSE field (Systems 14\u201322). Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) independently identify four of these systems: 14, 20, 21 and 22 (labelled Systems 10, 29, 26 and 18, respectively, in their work) though without spectroscopic redshifts. With the exception of System 21 (identified by [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]), these new systems are all strong Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 emitters, located at considerably higher redshifts (3\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a06) than those previously identified. Systems 14 and 22 are particularly interesting, as they are reasonably close together and have an identical redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1309). This suggests that they could be an interacting pair of galaxies, and indeed, narrow-band imaging shows that the emission-line regions of the two are clearly overlapping (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). Careful observation of the HFF data reveals at least some flux associated with each of the new systems in broad-band imaging, but in some cases \u2013 especially Systems 15 and 16 \u2013 this flux is extremely faint and contaminated by brighter objects nearby. Spectra of all systems in the MUSE field of view are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5a\" data-open=\"fig5a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The full list of multiply imaged systems, including all identified and/or model-predicted counterimages of a given system, is presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277386\" scrollto-destination=\"88277386\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=dgwCce5qb0wXeSO461VAq0grIhLTb~lDNbQeJgV~ybNTChzPoYGQmpgkOWnCQ0LXMy6BTraj5spqmNC5DtbzUku29uoyTvo8eOiFAMHb-eLuazwnSM4fs06zCiZxZqukcxXMV65oR6HXOQoR3bB1R5ez8~ZoV0MrWeyePEYmSDFsfLswOLma1xiAwV0SnUYrA4HOPeFSNPfeTAGB3ojDBcnroF0GR6IMnoW6mN6JngWo9U-T5RJuSaZ95vYbVYT0OKeD251PJNicQ5mw0ec4y9cUYsNteaAMXAO7lL0W6C4vWl3OzLBDm15h~V6AotWeKb~ReL9QqoSvx0XKsZ2c3g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Close-up of the area containing Images 14.3 and 22.1, two newly identified, multiply imaged, Lyman\u00a0\u03b1-emitting galaxies. While the HST imaging alone shows that the two galaxies are in close proximity to one another and have similar colours, new spectroscopy from MUSE reveals that they have exactly the same redshift (z\u00a0=\u00a03.1309). Additionally, narrow-band imaging of the emission line (green contours) shows that there is a significant overlap between the galaxies\u2019 Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes, suggesting that the two galaxies could be interacting.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277386/stx1079fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277386\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=FjFSMkQIG4c3zM0N-M9zgt-Z64djoJ5DY2SBRQCpMCaGwiBV1NIOO0Ivf68851ZkW3X7tdSSXsk9FBoVBwKG6poKz5bv6dphWPVgKEANxhBG0DcYm8zz7gbRdeuMe9hCJtthucMgECG2tvpkYyvDHHPkNdMOWWrty3xAz6211j5qGraMASTovKTRGTD6HJXa~XUDWtqrNExKivAZbJcbrYMasIAMyWkk-CF474zhiF9w1Iv1xoQUHsfH0~5Y0lwejD7eu5O-LZihDZi4mY7nlCDs9sK894QJwTi85LPphKGaEY0WK5xN8JFxQUp5~cRmcjlL6EGeg3mBAiFDYywVBA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277386&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Close-up of the area containing Images 14.3 and 22.1, two newly identified, multiply imaged, Lyman\u00a0\u03b1-emitting galaxies. While the <em>HST</em> imaging alone shows that the two galaxies are in close proximity to one another and have similar colours, new spectroscopy from MUSE reveals that they have exactly the same redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.1309). Additionally, narrow-band imaging of the emission line (green contours) shows that there is a significant overlap between the galaxies\u2019 Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes, suggesting that the two galaxies could be interacting.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=dgwCce5qb0wXeSO461VAq0grIhLTb~lDNbQeJgV~ybNTChzPoYGQmpgkOWnCQ0LXMy6BTraj5spqmNC5DtbzUku29uoyTvo8eOiFAMHb-eLuazwnSM4fs06zCiZxZqukcxXMV65oR6HXOQoR3bB1R5ez8~ZoV0MrWeyePEYmSDFsfLswOLma1xiAwV0SnUYrA4HOPeFSNPfeTAGB3ojDBcnroF0GR6IMnoW6mN6JngWo9U-T5RJuSaZ95vYbVYT0OKeD251PJNicQ5mw0ec4y9cUYsNteaAMXAO7lL0W6C4vWl3OzLBDm15h~V6AotWeKb~ReL9QqoSvx0XKsZ2c3g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Close-up of the area containing Images 14.3 and 22.1, two newly identified, multiply imaged, Lyman\u00a0\u03b1-emitting galaxies. Additionally, narrow-band imaging of the emission line (green contours) shows that there is a significant overlap between the galaxies\u2019 Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes, suggesting that the two galaxies could be interacting.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"88277387\" scrollto-destination=\"88277387\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5a\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=KtrmInZMO1H2XNJMkXRmz-f4qse~JwPi007RAkH8dEG2e-RKMptZljxdlZ5NgN-bBM1E8KgFSOlwVNWCb8r14lfN8gb5BPW2IglCmCEn9WFx6SoPLwt9b-vO~fe5jj-jsVI33uImrpuKZeG7vn5iavBlx5PRnH52HTttPF1mgdxd4rYDDWC7fGPxua2iIHsgXocr4VfPRUom9JvilNrki17xbmiZK2DrNWE6lIIDh4DeVVlWsQXhIy0ysFP~~cY3OFUGRPeiGkOJyhYMIPdFTPuavCfKJ6qzYYnhPLf~98NLVJucwrkcPwPdk6Bszqcsukcy9NdXZwf9~9WBxrU~9A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"(a) Multiply imaged systems with MUSE spectroscopy. Individual members of a given system (constraints) are labelled according to Table\u00a01. In the top panels, we show colour images of each constraint, using the F435W/F606W/F814W HFF bands for the RGB channels of the figure. The one exception is System 6, which instead uses a colour scheme of F435W/F814W/F160W to better highlight its morphology. Green contours represent the 1\u03c3, 3\u03c3 and 5\u03c3 (per pixel) levels of the brightest emission line seen in narrow-band imaging of the MUSE data cube. Cutouts of the extracted spectra, again centred on the brightest emission line, are shown in the bottom panel. The label colour of a given constraint matches the colour of its corresponding spectrum. Constraints that fall outside of the MUSE field of view, and thus have no MUSE spectroscopy, are labelled in white. With the exception of System 16, which includes the undetected Image 16.2, only image constraints used in the A370 mass model are displayed here. Model predictions outside of the MUSE footprint where we find no obvious HST counterpart are not shown. For merging pairs of images (Images 5.3/5.4, 7.1/7.2 and 21.1/21.2) we use a common extraction region for both spectra. The combined spectrum of both images then appears as a single line in the plot. (b) New MUSE-identified systems. The contours seen in Image 14.3 are identical to those in Fig.\u00a04, highlighting the overlap between the Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes of Images 14.3 and 22.1. (c) The final three MUSE-identified systems. We again see the overlap between the Lyman\u00a0\u03b1 haloes of Images 14.3 and 22.1.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig5a.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277387/stx1079fig5a.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig5a.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277387\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=uC28-pXnUEAf8qMxmiCxWhLXJFcMDMAwCu2Gfuxa5DmJFyHehUoeb~cv5bP0pvAWdgLoe6h6pVG4F9tY79mREVHtj2PS9tA1mxD8GyHP8UePElilmc4~n54OAaXNriO8r5qto3pD5rovq-d1APRY6Ob~QMPIi4lEqHwx5aqc5qsaq8ysGEdOAfVvcV62FenczgjWbGjz4ZG4G7ewSaa6tpDt7sdFzlzTmhZoMoz6-f4iLVg9PGy7udrU1aGUre~JhL6pFz7jw6AKnzK0~XBGSbtiWIntW~gt9xAAEYjSNkrY0dAyEKipi0Yt0E-mYUsDKxYrOWg3ztXGev6eRweVwg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277387&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig5a.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">(a) Multiply imaged systems with MUSE spectroscopy. In the top panels, we show colour images of each constraint, using the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>/<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>/<em>F</em>814<em>W</em> HFF bands for the RGB channels of the figure. class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Images labelled with an asterisk (*) fall outside of the MUSE cube and do not have secure redshifts. We identify them in the HFF data, using the A370 mass model as a guide.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Images in italics are predicted by the model, but no suitable counterimage is seen in the <em>HST</em> data. We do not include these images as model constraints, but we present them here for completeness. Image 16.2, which is in the MUSE field of view but predicted to fall behind a bright cluster galaxy, is also included here, since it is undetected in MUSE.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Redshifts enclosed in braces ({}) are fit by the model as free parameters. 0</td><td>\u22121.582\u00a00861\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>19.1\u00a0</td><td>39.971\u00a0996\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.587\u00a08654\u00a0</td><td>5.6493\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*19.2\u00a0</td><td>39.985\u00a0142\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.579\u00a00944\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*19.3\u00a0</td><td>39.958\u00a0316\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.581\u00a03093\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20.1\u00a0</td><td>39.965\u00a0279\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.587\u00a08055\u00a0</td><td>5.7505\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>20.2\u00a0</td><td>39.963\u00a0619\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.586\u00a08798\u00a0</td><td>5.7505\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*<em>20.3</em>\u00a0</td><td><em>39.986\u00a0651</em>\u00a0</td><td><em>\u22121.581\u00a02606</em>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>21.1\u00a0</td><td>39.966\u00a0733\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.584\u00a06943\u00a0</td><td>1.2567\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>21.2\u00a0</td><td>39.967\u00a0252\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.584\u00a09694\u00a0</td><td>1.2567\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*21.3\u00a0</td><td>39.981\u00a0539\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.581\u00a04028\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>22.1\u00a0</td><td>39.974\u00a0406\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.586\u00a01017\u00a0</td><td>3.1309\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*22.2\u00a0</td><td>39.981\u00a0675\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.579\u00a06852\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>*22.3\u00a0</td><td>39.957\u00a0906\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.581\u00a00108\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Images labelled with an asterisk (*) fall outside of the MUSE cube and do not have secure redshifts. We identify them in the HFF data, using the A370 mass model as a guide.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Images in italics are predicted by the model, but no suitable counterimage is seen in the <em>HST</em> data. We do not include these images as model constraints, but we present them here for completeness. Image 16.2, which is in the MUSE field of view but predicted to fall behind a bright cluster galaxy, is also included here, since it is undetected in MUSE.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Redshifts enclosed in braces ({}) are fit by the model as free parameters. The fit range is given in the \u2018<em>z</em> range\u2019 column.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Redshifts for these systems are taken from Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277390\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277391 id=\"88277391\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Cluster members</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster members make up the largest subgroup in the spectroscopic catalogue, with 56 confirmed redshifts. To identify cluster members, we select all galaxies that fall between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.35 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4, a \u03b4<em>v</em>\u00a0=\u00a015\u2009000\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> cut in velocity space centred on the A370 central redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.375). In the overall redshift catalogue, these boundaries naturally separate the cluster overdensity from all other objects, and a large fraction of galaxies in this range fall on both the (<em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>) and (<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>) red sequences. While a majority of objects are passive, elliptical galaxies showing only absorption features, some do show strong [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and/or H\u2009\u03b1 emission. Of these emission-line galaxies, CL49 (located close to the bright, foreground spiral F12) is unique, as it is the only detected cluster member in the MUSE field of view without an <em>HST</em> counterpart (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). Strangely, the object also appears to have a divergent velocity field: moving in either direction along the long axis, the flux becomes more and more redshifted relative to the centre. We do not have an explanation for this behaviour at this time, though it would be interesting to revisit in future work.</p>                        <a id=\"88277393\" scrollto-destination=\"88277393\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=f-Ko32PAiy8tia41fLhLc60Uy5qRQ5SCD~VNWobU3ljm~nDlXapYlwZ-xBMzQVMkFsDY91eoC5YWOYM5egAAhzWCzAWmXw5kcqRMZ5xrwQj5Hu5~4odlcQji93Q4liS-8bWs6DdBRZcRCVnjcuAsqRhaFF6E2lBL5yk0z1hi6L3FlndnE8awan-ZoAegmkB00mzPxMbVx9jPqdkBOPNKnfOt8dRCfq~SlWKC2wpNPrlxwcqQTCyNQpSPbH~zBjtOu4H8r4FSoPb~TMDlSKf9-Oe2MQN8-xyUicLbNbQp5pwJCHBmxjld1-FcUrlrQxZSNlDp5d2ct7afGAHLX6OYJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cluster member CL49, an emission-line object (z\u00a0=\u00a00.3843) not seen in broad-band HST imaging. The estimated centroid of the object is shown as a green circle, while the cyan and red contours trace the 1\u03c3, 3\u03c3 and 5\u03c3 (per pixel) regions of [O\u00a0ii] and H\u00a0\u03b1 emission, respectively. Curiously, the long axis of emission seems to have a divergent velocity field, as the flux at either end is slightly redshifted relative to the centre.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277393/stx1079fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277393\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=GJtderB0WESJ6kUXga0reD0ARwdXaXxQoGDjY-kaX75isEfMWHG-7VITrZupDLlVfRlvLtgtC8ybmGp7SoO0FfPtw2sFDRtS0o2GeoVNLDSixCpxg6psDq5nroq7dBaHyeR1xGfZHZcw8UKUrRbZuJPSB94-VlVqh2c7MIj6gLMGE8u017bA9briXDsaGv2OWDWYlHQZKgvfAheu~4NQUgciAgnqYotA1cyxdihBPLYJ5uL1qyYiv0-K-gTETVfB~tUM-1oJiMbCoFWyE8BmDYV~NfYuoBR6T5UZrB7Euc5LmEia2mJvJQlGfDP1UHTdkEiaj3fUKRTmbeMzQpSJyQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277393&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster member CL49, an emission-line object (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3843) not seen in broad-band <em>HST</em> imaging. The estimated centroid of the object is shown as a green circle, while the cyan and red contours trace the 1\u03c3, 3\u03c3 and 5\u03c3 (per pixel) regions of [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and H\u00a0\u03b1 emission, respectively. Curiously, the long axis of emission seems to have a divergent velocity field, as the flux at either end is slightly redshifted relative to the centre.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=f-Ko32PAiy8tia41fLhLc60Uy5qRQ5SCD~VNWobU3ljm~nDlXapYlwZ-xBMzQVMkFsDY91eoC5YWOYM5egAAhzWCzAWmXw5kcqRMZ5xrwQj5Hu5~4odlcQji93Q4liS-8bWs6DdBRZcRCVnjcuAsqRhaFF6E2lBL5yk0z1hi6L3FlndnE8awan-ZoAegmkB00mzPxMbVx9jPqdkBOPNKnfOt8dRCfq~SlWKC2wpNPrlxwcqQTCyNQpSPbH~zBjtOu4H8r4FSoPb~TMDlSKf9-Oe2MQN8-xyUicLbNbQp5pwJCHBmxjld1-FcUrlrQxZSNlDp5d2ct7afGAHLX6OYJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cluster member CL49, an emission-line object (z\u00a0=\u00a00.3843) not seen in broad-band HST imaging. Curiously, the long axis of emission seems to have a divergent velocity field, as the flux at either end is slightly redshifted relative to the centre.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277393/stx1079fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277393\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=GJtderB0WESJ6kUXga0reD0ARwdXaXxQoGDjY-kaX75isEfMWHG-7VITrZupDLlVfRlvLtgtC8ybmGp7SoO0FfPtw2sFDRtS0o2GeoVNLDSixCpxg6psDq5nroq7dBaHyeR1xGfZHZcw8UKUrRbZuJPSB94-VlVqh2c7MIj6gLMGE8u017bA9briXDsaGv2OWDWYlHQZKgvfAheu~4NQUgciAgnqYotA1cyxdihBPLYJ5uL1qyYiv0-K-gTETVfB~tUM-1oJiMbCoFWyE8BmDYV~NfYuoBR6T5UZrB7Euc5LmEia2mJvJQlGfDP1UHTdkEiaj3fUKRTmbeMzQpSJyQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277393&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster member CL49, an emission-line object (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3843) not seen in broad-band <em>HST</em> imaging. The estimated centroid of the object is shown as a green circle, while the cyan and red contours trace the 1\u03c3, 3\u03c3 and 5\u03c3 (per pixel) regions of [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and H\u00a0\u03b1 emission, respectively. Curiously, the long axis of emission seems to have a divergent velocity field, as the flux at either end is slightly redshifted relative to the centre.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster galaxy positions are represented by green circles in the top panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. The redshifts themselves are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277395\" scrollto-destination=\"88277395\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster members.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Dec<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>m</em><sub>F435W</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>m</em><sub>F606W</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Listed emission/absorption lines refer to the most prominent features seen in the galaxy's spectrum.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277395\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277396 id=\"88277396\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Other objects</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to cluster members and multiply imaged systems, the catalogue also contains a number of foreground objects and singly imaged background objects at various redshifts. We identify four stars within the MUSE field of view, mostly located near the BCG. Beyond the Milky Way, we find 13 galaxies in the foreground of the cluster, between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.2 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.35. Nearly all of these objects are optically blue and have emission features, in particular a very strong H\u00a0\u03b1 line. However, object F11 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.3275) shows strong absorption line features, with only weak [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission. Behind the cluster, we find an additional 13 objects at redshifts between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.41 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.5. Here again, these systems are largely identified by strong [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and/or [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission lines, however object B4 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4655) is another absorption-line galaxy showing weak [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission. Information on all singly imaged objects can be found in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"88277398\" scrollto-destination=\"88277398\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>S1\u00a0</td><td>39.972\u00a0077\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.580\u00a05308\u00a0</td><td>0.0000\u00a0</td><td>\u22c6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S2\u00a0</td><td>39.970\u00a0365\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.585\u00a09742\u00a0</td><td>0.0000\u00a0</td><td>\u22c6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S3\u00a0</td><td>39.973\u00a0933\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.587\u00a03072\u00a0</td><td>0.0000\u00a0</td><td>\u22c6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S4\u00a0</td><td>39.964\u00a0779\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.580\u00a01536\u00a0</td><td>0.0000\u00a0</td><td>\u22c6\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>F1\u00a0</td><td>39.978\u00a0832\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.575\u00a04827\u00a0</td><td>0.2067\u00a0</td><td>H\u2009\u03b1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>F2\u00a0</td><td>39.975\u00a0921\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.575\u00a00762\u00a0</td><td>0.2070\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B7\u00a0</td><td>39.967\u00a0551\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.586\u00a01036\u00a0</td><td>0.6801\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B6\u00a0</td><td>39.969\u00a0464\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.589\u00a05997\u00a0</td><td>0.6037\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B7\u00a0</td><td>39.967\u00a0551\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.586\u00a01036\u00a0</td><td>0.6801\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B8\u00a0</td><td>39.967\u00a0227\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.589\u00a09252\u00a0</td><td>0.8040\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B9\u00a0</td><td>39.963\u00a0801\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.588\u00a02507\u00a0</td><td>0.8049\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B10\u00a0</td><td>39.978\u00a0094\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.585\u00a02708\u00a0</td><td>1.0606\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B11\u00a0</td><td>39.962\u00a0676\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.585\u00a01813\u00a0</td><td>1.0635\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B12\u00a0</td><td>39.976\u00a0042\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.589\u00a03204\u00a0</td><td>1.3398\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>B13\u00a0</td><td>39.979\u00a0281\u00a0</td><td>\u22121.590\u00a02451\u00a0</td><td>1.4497\u00a0</td><td>[O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277398\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277399 id=\"88277399\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 LENS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To measure the mass distribution of A370, we follow a procedure used in previous works (e.g. Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>): namely, we model the system as a collection of mass clumps, including both large-scale dark matter haloes representing cluster potentials and smaller, galaxy-scale haloes representing individual galaxies. Each halo, regardless of size, is assumed to have a truncated dual Pseudo-Isothermal Elliptical mass distribution (dPIE; El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). The description of a dPIE halo consists of seven parameters: position (\u03b1 and \u03b4), velocity dispersion (\u03c3<sub>0</sub>), position angle (\u03b8), ellipticity (\u03b5) and two scale radii (<em>r</em><sub>core</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>) that modify the halo's mass slope. Here, <em>r</em><sub>core</sub> represents the halo's inner core radius, inside of which the mass slope flattens instead of increasing isothermally. Finally, <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> represents the halo's cut-off radius, outside of which the mass slope drops more steeply.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">During the optimization process, we allow most cluster halo parameters to freely vary within a given prior distribution, but we fix <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> to a large value of 800\u00a0kpc (155\u00a0arcsec). This is because the current data do not extend far enough to meaningfully constrain its value. To limit the overall size of the parameter space, we place additional restrictions on the galaxy-scale haloes, adopting a light-traces-mass approach that assumes correlation between the observed baryons and their galaxy haloes. Galaxy positions, ellipticities and position angles are fixed to values measured from the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> HFF data, while <em>r</em><sub>core</sub>, <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> and \u03c3<sub>0</sub> are scaled based on the galaxy's luminosity (<em>L</em>), relative to an <em>L</em>* galaxy. At the A370 cluster redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$m^*_{\\rm F814W}$|</span> = 18.31. We fix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r^*_{\\rm core}$|</span> to be 0.15\u00a0kpc, while we allow <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r^*_{\\rm cut}$|</span> to vary with a uniform prior between 10 and 50\u00a0kpc. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r^*_{\\rm cut}$|</span> value is kept low to account for tidal stripping effects by the cluster haloes (Halkola, Seitz &amp; Pannella <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007a</a>; Natarajan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). Similarly, we allow (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\sigma ^*_0$|\u2060</span>) to vary, but we instead assume a Gaussian prior distribution with mean \u03bc<sub>pdf</sub> = 158\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> and width \u03c3<sub>pdf</sub> = 27\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, following the Bernardi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) observations of early-type galaxies in high-density environments in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we model three galaxy-scale haloes separately from the scaling relation: the two BCGs and another bright galaxy (GAL1) lying close to the System 2 giant arc. The southern BCG and GAL1 (objects Cl29 and Cl32, respectively, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) are close enough and massive enough to significantly affect the shape of System 2. The northern BCG mildly influences the orientation of the northern cluster potential. Like the other galaxy potentials, we fix the position, PA and ellipticity values to match the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> HFF data. We also fix <em>r</em><sub>core</sub>, though we assume different values (0.14\u00a0kpc for the BCGs, 0.06\u00a0kpc for GAL1) based on their magnitudes, which are consistent with the original scaling relation. The values of \u03c3<sub>0</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> are allowed to vary freely, using their magnitude-scaled values relative to <em>L</em>* as a starting point.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Individual galaxies that we include in the model as cluster-member haloes are selected through a colour cut, using the three optical HFF bands. Additionally, we limit the selection to bright galaxies (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.6), since beyond this cutoff \u2013 roughly equivalent to\u00a0\u223c0.02 <em>L</em><sub>*</sub> \u2013 galaxies will have a negligible effect on the mass budget. We also exclude galaxies at distances beyond <em>R</em>\u00a0=\u00a070\u00a0arcsec from the cluster centre (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a02<sup>h</sup> 39<sup>m</sup><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$59{^{\\rm s}_{.}}9$|\u2060</span>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121\u00b0 34<sup>\u0384</sup> 36<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>5), corresponding to <em>R</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0360\u00a0kpc in physical space, for similar reasons. For the colour cut itself, we construct the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013i814<em>W</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams and look for evidence of a red sequence. The colour\u2013magnitude diagrams are shown in the upper panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, along with the boundary conditions used to select candidate cluster members. These are given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n(-0.11 \\times m_{\\rm F814W}) + 4.06 \\le (m_{\\rm F435W} - m_{\\rm F606W})\\nonumber \\\\\r\n (-0.11 \\times m_{\\rm F814W}) + 4.45 \\ge (m_{\\rm F435W} - m_{\\rm F606W})\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>for <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n(-0.04 \\times m_{\\rm F814W}) + 1.74 \\le (m_{\\rm F606W} - m_{\\rm F814W}) \\nonumber\\\\\r\n (-0.04 \\times m_{\\rm F814W}) + 1.93 \\ge (m_{\\rm F606W} - m_{\\rm F814W})\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>for <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>. We then combine the two plots into a colour\u2013colour diagram and select galaxies that satisfy both red sequence cuts. The majority of these galaxies fall into a tight cluster locus (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, bottom). To measure galaxy photometry, we run SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) in dual-image mode, using the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band data as the detection template. In the region covered by the MUSE footprint, we further refine the selection process by including all spectroscopically confirmed cluster members (including the bluer, late-type galaxies missed by the colour\u2013colour cut) and rejecting all non-cluster members regardless of their colours or magnitudes.</div>                        <a id=\"88277404\" scrollto-destination=\"88277404\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=P0eiEOIvfT64uwQt9vE~rY7Fbad-yvw2YZw12tXdnbe~0GsDAGmgb~NlEqNpoBd2kG8Fk-0rGup~Rx2pIP0Ih3Jg9FRvOmVmEaHQxcbJmMtl7~Aeq3RP9W-hw1Eev4Lar~YCBY3s3SecBWdR6-bBurpe8ki0GgBx-ya8~SMDQ78j52V8R5DqJ5NQZ1D6jQfaXm3H8~ZTJB2u8UCPjPs5B8eYOO9pYEmRkZU~PWQfdeAyvlFhZIuCiMUch-w2IFLFudqjuvC4NP6j-VXp1fnESPuWZGsl0T0UrGXlWRFcOjPnBdEjVFn72~JcNmUSBUk9ykNwXAngW-g1f6LBtrNg8w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour criterion used to select galaxies for mass modelling. Top: objects selected from the (F435W\u2013F606W) versus F814W colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Diagonal lines trace the 3\u03c3 upper- and lower bounds defining the cluster red sequence, while a faint-end magnitude cutoff (mF814W\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.6) is represented by the vertical line. Galaxies selected through this criterion are shown in red. Additionally, spectroscopically confirmed cluster members are highlighted by green rings, and are included in the final model regardless of colour or magnitude. Middle: similar selection diagram, using the (F606W\u2013F814W) versus F814W colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Bottom: combination of the two colour\u2013magnitude diagrams into a colour\u2013colour diagram. \u2018Good\u2019 objects \u2013 those falling simultaneously within both cluster red sequences \u2013 are mainly located within a tight locus. The final set of colour\u2013colour selected galaxies are shown in red, while the spectroscopic galaxies are again shown as green rings.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277404/stx1079fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277404\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=AQ7EAb3x~bCE5BKj7HFc3HNy34NX5ya3iCiA1QDjmpeKO85Q1h7GuF6AZz8fyWstywe44x2MTyOL1XEEq1dOl6AQ28m~cSfoKUNvXL-kQLKpa00eHvZS4zBNdq7-tqx~IfOxWY9h2JeAjxbDdzHMi4rOsMXfWHpwahXBbptdSPI5tom5pc~Sp04lY2xEHknTJQh4RRw3gtnKjHSeQClWbjPp8QdTr22XfzSuiYwefjjsh2VQR-cgz9Ux-2~IJ9i5cs3An5tP~FM6iFc2ga8APkdYat7FeeCAtoMss3oD6R-KoZX429bsUOJrmqE2BMoseP6i7e7Eht9ZqEOx9ZdF7A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277404&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour criterion used to select galaxies for mass modelling. The final set of colour\u2013colour selected galaxies are shown in red, while the spectroscopic galaxies are again shown as green rings.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277404/stx1079fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277404\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=AQ7EAb3x~bCE5BKj7HFc3HNy34NX5ya3iCiA1QDjmpeKO85Q1h7GuF6AZz8fyWstywe44x2MTyOL1XEEq1dOl6AQ28m~cSfoKUNvXL-kQLKpa00eHvZS4zBNdq7-tqx~IfOxWY9h2JeAjxbDdzHMi4rOsMXfWHpwahXBbptdSPI5tom5pc~Sp04lY2xEHknTJQh4RRw3gtnKjHSeQClWbjPp8QdTr22XfzSuiYwefjjsh2VQR-cgz9Ux-2~IJ9i5cs3An5tP~FM6iFc2ga8APkdYat7FeeCAtoMss3oD6R-KoZX429bsUOJrmqE2BMoseP6i7e7Eht9ZqEOx9ZdF7A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277404&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour criterion used to select galaxies for mass modelling. Top: objects selected from the (<em>F</em>435<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>) versus <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Diagonal lines trace the 3\u03c3 upper- and lower bounds defining the cluster red sequence, while a faint-end magnitude cutoff (<em>m</em><sub>F814W</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a022.6) is represented by the vertical line. Galaxies selected through this criterion are shown in red. Additionally, spectroscopically confirmed cluster members are highlighted by green rings, and are included in the final model regardless of colour or magnitude. Middle: similar selection diagram, using the (<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>\u2013<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>) versus <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagram. Bottom: combination of the two colour\u2013magnitude diagrams into a colour\u2013colour diagram. \u2018Good\u2019 objects \u2013 those falling simultaneously within both cluster red sequences \u2013 are mainly located within a tight locus. The final set of colour\u2013colour selected galaxies are shown in red, while the spectroscopic galaxies are again shown as green rings.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We constrain the mass model with the positions of known multiply imaged systems, however, we first revise the interpretation of System 5, previously described as a three-image system (5.1, 5.2, 5.3). Image 5.3 is actually located close to a background galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.6 (object B6 in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) that perturbs the lens model, and we add it as an additional galaxy-scale potential. As illustrated by a simulation of the lensing effect on Images 5.1 and 5.2, this small perturbation convincingly produces a merging pair of two additional images previously identified as 5.3 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). Therefore, we update our constraint list to include the new Image 5.3 and Image 5.4 in the model. While we use nearly all of the 22 current systems (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) we exclude System 10, a faint radial arc without a secure redshift that also lacks bright counterimages. Because even small changes in the mass model produce wildly different predictions for radial systems, the lack of counterimages makes the system fully degenerate with the parameters of the northern cluster halo.</p>                        <a id=\"88277406\" scrollto-destination=\"88277406\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=PrhvrZ4FPb8Wnge3eyNRUJJGHqDYDxh6967yBSmm21D6XAzVCHVOGeR3dnzlpYBFpsWtxMncXMxJYHp~0ECDtQXC00iTnHF2Pym--L9BhnMvmjfWYcjnryUFt7UiZ6z8m4vwOODhdL91i~poV~~LF3E-Xq9-QhNwJ5A2GYvizmZ5Amq~85zdqWADqgSZ8fPKZQbVqaTevg1ZMEjgOqdYK8xKNIywelR-pC7AsOhVa9lC0FdWzlmPb8HZdLk~8l4dUaSbprZwFLo65uJIphgnm5OEOnri7Y54ipOq4v1xp9EsP0kVRtJEr4SB1TJSaedaKMw78kXZwnKMxCZ-Xhq0Ig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Our new interpretation of System 5. Top: an ACS RGB image of System 5. Bottom: a simulated image, using the lens model. In this simulation, a pixelized image of the galaxy is sent to the source plane and then back to the image plane to be compared with observations. The critical line at z\u00a0=\u00a01.2775 (red line in both panels) is affected by the background z\u00a0=\u00a00.6 spiral galaxy (B6; see Table 3) on the right and crosses the rightmost image previously known as 5.3. We interpret 5.3 as a merging pair of two additional images mirroring only part of the source. This is seen convincingly in the simulation, which reproduce the relative surface brightnesses of the observations well.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277406/stx1079fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277406\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=z-qwYc1LA3x0gnpfP2RTrO7nt0rFm9QYphF01b2x1CnxZSM1C7uAF-2XTMU3MxeFpj5O0NoXWhUKxwFNJjTP8GzxYPn4dn1VVH9hjhVZ-d1RfietQ00BwwLsOz5C2USrfzi3Hk3-M4dymi50jRmEEMloBOr4dZjlOIFbJkgtK0Oab2JBHys8fDPi6kSciaaMHl6Q12lehtiB7SMvnVeP49-ess071d8T8Jvn4MS-TeC3e0tL0L4LTKmFwXWvbVRavaBsxpcqKTW9kosITPmKrup9rO2IB40r1aq2zC2PnEe3ndcW6hE72SeoFVAPg-mtKmcLRaHqaP6g~lu7JF2csA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277406&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our new interpretation of System 5. Top: an ACS RGB image of System 5. Bottom: a simulated image, using the lens model. In this simulation, a pixelized image of the galaxy is sent to the source plane and then back to the image plane to be compared with observations. The critical line at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2775 (red line in both panels) is affected by the background <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.6 spiral galaxy (B6; see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) on the right and crosses the rightmost image previously known as 5.3. We interpret 5.3 as a merging pair of two additional images mirroring only part of the source. This is seen convincingly in the simulation, which reproduce the relative surface brightnesses of the observations well.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=PrhvrZ4FPb8Wnge3eyNRUJJGHqDYDxh6967yBSmm21D6XAzVCHVOGeR3dnzlpYBFpsWtxMncXMxJYHp~0ECDtQXC00iTnHF2Pym--L9BhnMvmjfWYcjnryUFt7UiZ6z8m4vwOODhdL91i~poV~~LF3E-Xq9-QhNwJ5A2GYvizmZ5Amq~85zdqWADqgSZ8fPKZQbVqaTevg1ZMEjgOqdYK8xKNIywelR-pC7AsOhVa9lC0FdWzlmPb8HZdLk~8l4dUaSbprZwFLo65uJIphgnm5OEOnri7Y54ipOq4v1xp9EsP0kVRtJEr4SB1TJSaedaKMw78kXZwnKMxCZ-Xhq0Ig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Our new interpretation of System 5. Top: an ACS RGB image of System 5. Bottom: a simulated image, using the lens model. In this simulation, a pixelized image of the galaxy is sent to the source plane and then back to the image plane to be compared with observations. The critical line at z\u00a0=\u00a01.2775 (red line in both panels) is affected by the background z\u00a0=\u00a00.6 spiral galaxy (B6; see Table 3) on the right and crosses the rightmost image previously known as 5.3. We interpret 5.3 as a merging pair of two additional images mirroring only part of the source. This is seen convincingly in the simulation, which reproduce the relative surface brightnesses of the observations well.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277406/stx1079fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277406\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=z-qwYc1LA3x0gnpfP2RTrO7nt0rFm9QYphF01b2x1CnxZSM1C7uAF-2XTMU3MxeFpj5O0NoXWhUKxwFNJjTP8GzxYPn4dn1VVH9hjhVZ-d1RfietQ00BwwLsOz5C2USrfzi3Hk3-M4dymi50jRmEEMloBOr4dZjlOIFbJkgtK0Oab2JBHys8fDPi6kSciaaMHl6Q12lehtiB7SMvnVeP49-ess071d8T8Jvn4MS-TeC3e0tL0L4LTKmFwXWvbVRavaBsxpcqKTW9kosITPmKrup9rO2IB40r1aq2zC2PnEe3ndcW6hE72SeoFVAPg-mtKmcLRaHqaP6g~lu7JF2csA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277406&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our new interpretation of System 5. Top: an ACS RGB image of System 5. Bottom: a simulated image, using the lens model. In this simulation, a pixelized image of the galaxy is sent to the source plane and then back to the image plane to be compared with observations. The critical line at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.2775 (red line in both panels) is affected by the background <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.6 spiral galaxy (B6; see Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>) on the right and crosses the rightmost image previously known as 5.3. We interpret 5.3 as a merging pair of two additional images mirroring only part of the source. This is seen convincingly in the simulation, which reproduce the relative surface brightnesses of the observations well.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">While some systems have only a single MUSE detection (Systems 16, 17, 18, 19 and 22), these objects are often bright in broad-band photometry, and we are able to identify their counterparts in the HFF data directly. In fact, many lens systems with MUSE spectroscopy have at least one counterimage that falls outside of the current footprint, since the GTO data only cover a fraction of the A370 field of view. Though we are unable to confirm these objects spectroscopically, we can identify them with the help of the lens model itself. Specifically, we start with known (spectroscopically confirmed) members of a given lens system and use the model to predict the location of counterimages. From this rough guess, we look for candidates in the HFF data that match the system members (i.e. galaxies with similar colours, morphology and shape), which we take to be the counterimages. We then optimize a new version of the model, including these other constraints. We can compare the models with and without the added constraints, and if the new results stay within an acceptable error limit: an average model rms displacement of 1\u00a0arcsec or lower, we keep the counterimages and start the process again. In this way, we are able to iteratively refine and improve the model until it converges on the best solution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the best A370 model, we identify 16 counterimages this way: Images 7.4, 7.5, 14.4, 14.5, 15.4, 15.5, 16.3, 17.2, 17.3, 18.2, 18.3, 19.2, 19.3, 21.3, 22.2 and 22.3. With the exception of the System 7 counterimages, they are all associated with newly identified MUSE objects, again highlighting the power of MUSE as a redshift engine. While the model also predicts the existence of Images 3.4 and 20.3, there are no obvious candidates in the available HFF data, so we do not include them as constraints. The remaining systems (8, 11, 12 and 13) fall outside of the MUSE footprint and lack secure redshift information. Thus, we use the positions of these systems as constraints but leave their redshift values as free parameters to be fit by the model. In some cases, the best-fitting model predicts additional counterimages for these objects (Images 8.3, 11.3 and 13.3), but we again find no obvious counterparts in the HFF data, so we do not use them as model constraints. This is because predicted positions without redshift have significantly larger uncertainties. While we do note that any object without a secure redshift may not be a real counterimage but instead the chance alignment of a different galaxy, the combination of model predictions and visual evidence from the <em>HST</em> data makes this scenario extremely unlikely. As a result, we do not consider this possibility in our current lens modelling. However, we will revisit these objects in future work with a larger MUSE mosaic. After adding and removing objects as described above, we are left with 21 unique systems with a total of 66 individual image constraints.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To optimize the model, we feed all parameters and constraints into the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a> (Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jullo &amp; Kneib <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) software program, which probes the full parameter space with a Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampler. To evaluate a given model, <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> reconstructs the parametrized mass distribution and transforms the constraint coordinates from the image (observed) plane to the source (undeflected) plane. In the source plane, the program calculates the barycentre of each constraining system, then transforms these results back to the lens plane, creating a set of predicted images that can be compared to observation. By minimizing the rms displacement between prediction and observation, <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> is thus able to objectively determine the \u2018best\u2019 model for a given set of input parameters (e.g. Kneib et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Following Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), our initial model includes two massive cluster potentials (each centred on a BCG) and the cluster galaxies selected from the colour\u2013colour cut outlined above. However, after several MCMC iterations with this model, we find that no combination of parameter values sufficiently recreates the observed image positions (i.e. with an average rms error\u00a0&lt;1\u00a0arcsec). In particular, we are unable to simultaneously model the positions of the systems in the north and the new MUSE-identified images near the centre. This is most noticeable in System 12, where typical model displacements can be as large as 6\u00a0arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To help correct this disagreement, we first add an elongated, bar-like mass potential (DM3) as a bridge between the two cluster haloes (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). This flattens the mass distribution in the region between the two BCGs, and improves the fit of the central, radial image constraints of Systems 7, 14 and 15. As a consequence of adding the bar, the northern cluster potential (DM2) becomes more elongated and its centroid moves further away from the BCG. This can be explained as a model degeneracy between the positions of DM2 and DM3, since there is a significant overlap between their mass distributions. In fact, the barycentre of the two components falls slightly to the south of the BCG itself.</p>                        <a id=\"88277412\" scrollto-destination=\"88277412\"></a>\r\n<div
