0.88\u00a0arcsec\u00a0</td><td>DM2\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$9.96^{+ 0.32}_{ -1.19}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$27.54^{+ 0.57}_{ -1.55}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.83^{+ 0.02}_{-0.03}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-124.3^{+ 0.8}_{ -0.9}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$129.8^{+ 4.5}_{ -5.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[800.0]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$857^{+21}_{-34}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u03c7<sup>2</sup>/\u03bd = 4.29\u00a0</td><td>DM3\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-2.29^{+ 0.41}_{ -0.88}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$36.56^{+ 2.28}_{ -0.88}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.76^{+ 0.02}_{-0.03}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$100.0^{+ 0.8}_{ -0.8}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$182.4^{+ 3.4}_{ -8.5}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[800.0]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1134^{+22}_{-23}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>log\u2009(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathcal {L}$|\u2060</span>) = \u2212133.64\u00a0</td><td>DM4\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-38.41^{+ 1.66}_{ -1.24}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$44.48^{+ 1.43}_{ -1.70}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.80^{+ 0.02}_{-0.02}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$73.5^{+ 4.2}_{ -2.3}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$51.4^{+ 8.8}_{ -4.3}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[800.0]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$531^{+21}_{-18}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>log\u2009(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathcal {E}$|\u2060</span>) = \u2212202.67\u00a0</td><td>DM5\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$44.27^{+ 0.11}_{ -1.71}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$53.79^{+ 8.08}_{ -0.28}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.75^{+ 0.04}_{-0.14}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-35.1^{+ 2.7}_{ -5.3}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$36.9^{+ 4.5}_{ -8.7}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[800.0]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$436^{+52}_{-57}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>BIC = 456.27\u00a0</td><td>BCG1\u00a0</td><td>[\u22120.01]\u00a0</td><td>[0.02]\u00a0</td><td>[0.30]\u00a0</td><td>[\u221281.9]\u00a0</td><td>[0.14]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$40.6^{+ 5.3}_{ -4.9}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$200^{+11}_{-14}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>BCG2\u00a0</td><td>[5.90]\u00a0</td><td>[37.24]\u00a0</td><td>[0.20]\u00a0</td><td>[\u221263.9]\u00a0</td><td>[0.14]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$51.0^{+ 5.0}_{ -2.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$280^{+17}_{-12}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>CL32\u00a0</td><td>[7.92]\u00a0</td><td>[\u22129.76]\u00a0</td><td>[0.26]\u00a0</td><td>[25.7]\u00a0</td><td>[0.06]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$5.9^{+ 4.6}_{ -5.7}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$101^{+7}_{-6}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>L</em>* Galaxy\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$46.1^{+ 2.9}_{ -1.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$199^{+9}_{-10}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN006\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN006\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>\u0394\u03b1 and \u0394\u03b4 are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (\u03b1 = 39.971\u00a034, \u03b4 = \u22121.582\u00a02597).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN007\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN007\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Ellipticity (\u03b5) is defined to be (<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN008\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN008\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277412\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Even after adding the bar, however, we are only able to reduce the model rms to 1.17\u00a0arcsec, with the northern systems still poorly fit. Therefore, we add an additional large-scale cluster potential to the model (DM4), centred near a group of bright galaxies in the northeastern corner of the cluster (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). This location is chosen both because of its proximity to Image 12.3 (the image constraint with the highest rms error), and because it is part of a \u2018crown\u2019 of galaxies sitting above the northern BCG. Since all of the galaxies in the crown are bright and have similar, cluster-like colours and several are spectroscopically confirmed to be cluster members (Mellier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) it is possible this collection represents another, unaccounted-for mass component of A370.</p>                        <a id=\"88277414\" scrollto-destination=\"88277414\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=edATFU6CsBIBuApUcsmt3pQJXTOESZUhor4xnkPOQH2NIhScz~2~A3C9ia-IM4NYwY7c54BXY7uyQzOB8edStDJSzmX5pQuKL-unOe~m0ld7CoZUsN7XpWGqZIh61mGPZG532Vk-o5sgi3VCBEnLGQZWto-ErnYKCiAvhVJh70NmRUK3ArUgzWAo8b0qEgFjS9sKb2vG8sjJMxTeYn2D-2F44keBGsK9I9Q9RaUPQKdPCx4bi5sBLtTjArgaEiQan950KHQzzxK4UQXQUPN~VyhUqmkdUZI74a6W7s0l4Rd72JMvLKC7YOrlunwy~NSPzjE3DQsQ~4~Tb2oDz~m9sQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Dark matter surface mass density contours (green) measured from the lens model. Contours are shown in steps of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0108 M\u2299\u00a0kpc\u22122, starting from 109 M\u2299\u00a0kpc\u22122. Highlighted in red are the centroids of the four cluster-scale dark matter haloes. Red ellipses are used to give a rough estimate of the relative shape and strength of each component, but we stress that the actual mass contours are much larger and less elliptical.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277414/stx1079fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277414\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=KAsCmXgk8lqrtayyNUSA9XIgKZaE~9UjcIoL5TAaN7SFdwVysFQAesA9rfTy5kZFKMpuX3YbtPXEudWHoDqK2psa4pMafr2BDdK4hB7LntXikl822EMNBqTUpWNiHZz7BQpyoDiejKBQMxTJrRhJK15j9K2cF-dlO-yCnRbT5HHlw8Xc~XWadlyUbl9J6sB0p9O2mcwPjOI62cVRlwFEvNMuuse6el~mJyruyMSsDgMUIWfWNpmIhYmWvTqg1s88CMVKBdWdv089hOeMwVBYNpU5b7YtR9vcOVbVgXBxoTOnEonArSgXA69YVFC5MlGEB11h5EvY8ffmoyIPPz4F3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277414&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dark matter surface mass density contours (green) measured from the lens model. Contours are shown in steps of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>, starting from 10<sup>9</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>. Highlighted in red are the centroids of the four cluster-scale dark matter haloes. Red ellipses are used to give a rough estimate of the relative shape and strength of each component, but we stress that the actual mass contours are much larger and less elliptical.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=edATFU6CsBIBuApUcsmt3pQJXTOESZUhor4xnkPOQH2NIhScz~2~A3C9ia-IM4NYwY7c54BXY7uyQzOB8edStDJSzmX5pQuKL-unOe~m0ld7CoZUsN7XpWGqZIh61mGPZG532Vk-o5sgi3VCBEnLGQZWto-ErnYKCiAvhVJh70NmRUK3ArUgzWAo8b0qEgFjS9sKb2vG8sjJMxTeYn2D-2F44keBGsK9I9Q9RaUPQKdPCx4bi5sBLtTjArgaEiQan950KHQzzxK4UQXQUPN~VyhUqmkdUZI74a6W7s0l4Rd72JMvLKC7YOrlunwy~NSPzjE3DQsQ~4~Tb2oDz~m9sQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Dark matter surface mass density contours (green) measured from the lens model. Contours are shown in steps of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0108 M\u2299\u00a0kpc\u22122, starting from 109 M\u2299\u00a0kpc\u22122. Highlighted in red are the centroids of the four cluster-scale dark matter haloes. Red ellipses are used to give a rough estimate of the relative shape and strength of each component, but we stress that the actual mass contours are much larger and less elliptical.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277414/stx1079fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277414\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=KAsCmXgk8lqrtayyNUSA9XIgKZaE~9UjcIoL5TAaN7SFdwVysFQAesA9rfTy5kZFKMpuX3YbtPXEudWHoDqK2psa4pMafr2BDdK4hB7LntXikl822EMNBqTUpWNiHZz7BQpyoDiejKBQMxTJrRhJK15j9K2cF-dlO-yCnRbT5HHlw8Xc~XWadlyUbl9J6sB0p9O2mcwPjOI62cVRlwFEvNMuuse6el~mJyruyMSsDgMUIWfWNpmIhYmWvTqg1s88CMVKBdWdv089hOeMwVBYNpU5b7YtR9vcOVbVgXBxoTOnEonArSgXA69YVFC5MlGEB11h5EvY8ffmoyIPPz4F3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277414&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dark matter surface mass density contours (green) measured from the lens model. Contours are shown in steps of 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>, starting from 10<sup>9</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>. Highlighted in red are the centroids of the four cluster-scale dark matter haloes. Red ellipses are used to give a rough estimate of the relative shape and strength of each component, but we stress that the actual mass contours are much larger and less elliptical.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As with the other cluster potentials, we allow the dPIE parameters of the crown component to vary freely within a set of priors, though we assume an initial configuration that is more elliptical (like the bar), to better account for the stretched nature of the crown. Including this additional mass clump further improves the fit, reducing the average rms displacement from 1.17\u00a0arcsec to 0.94\u00a0arcsec, below the benchmark level of rms = 1\u00a0arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To see if even more mass structures are needed to describe A370, we also test a five-clump mass model, placing an additional mass clump on the western side of the A370 crown. Like the eastern clump, we choose locations close to bright cluster galaxies \u2013 including the pair of elliptical galaxies near the top of the crown \u2013 though we do allow the centroid to vary around these locations. However, this does not significantly improve the fit (rms = 0.88\u00a0arcsec) and actually lowers the Bayesian evidence, possibly suggesting an overfit to the data (see Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>). Thus, given the success of the four-clump model in reproducing the image constraint positions, we treat its optimized parameter set as our \u2018best-fitting\u2019 description of the A370 mass distribution. Optimized parameters for all models can be seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, and the final model mass reconstruction is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277417 id=\"88277417\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277418 id=\"88277418\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 The case for additional mass clumps</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">While adding two new large-scale mass clumps to the model significantly improves the fit, it is important to ask the question \u2018Is this additional mass truly necessary?\u2019 In other words, are these new mass clumps real features supported by the data, or is it simply a case of overfitting in a sparsely sampled region of the cluster? To answer this, we look at both model and (perhaps more importantly) physical evidence.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From a purely statistical point of view, the Bayesian evidence value (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathcal {E}$|\u2060</span>) can discriminate between models, taking into account and in some cases penalizing additional terms and model complexities, while simultaneously evaluating goodness of fit. Models with larger evidence terms are preferred over those with smaller terms, providing an objective criterion for comparison (see e.g. Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). For the A370 models (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), we find that the evidence of the three-clump model (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log (\\mathcal {E})$|</span> = \u2212303.19) is significantly larger than that of the two-clump model (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log (\\mathcal {E})$|</span> = \u22121817.07), showing that the data strongly prefer a mass distribution that includes a flatter, central \u2018bar\u2019 component. The evidence term of the four-clump model is larger still (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log (\\mathcal {E})$|</span> = \u2212201.90) \u2013 though the relative improvement over the three-clump model is not as great \u2013 again suggesting a real need for the crown clump. Finally, although the more complex five-clump model has a marginally improved fit over the four-clump model (rms = 0.88\u00a0arcsec), its evidence value actually decreases (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log \\mathcal {E}$|</span> = \u2212202.67) suggesting that the fifth mass clump is unnecessary and that we are beginning to overfit the system. Additional tests, placing the fifth clump at several other locations throughout the crown, yield similar (or worse) results.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">As a complementary check on overfitting, we also calculate the Bayesian information criterion (BIC) term for each model: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n{\\rm BIC} = -2 \\times \\log (\\mathcal {L}) + k \\times \\log (n),\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}$|</span> is the model likelihood, <em>k</em> is the number of model free parameters and <em>n</em> is the number of model constraints. Lower BIC values are favoured over higher values, and for our models, we again see that the four-clump case (BIC = 455.35) is preferred over all others (we present all values in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), bolstering the claim that the bar and the crown are real, necessary features.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the physical side of the evidence argument, we first turn to the cluster light distribution. As previously mentioned, the presence of the northern crown of galaxies already suggests an additional mass distribution not captured by the two-clump model. To test this theory, we first isolate the cluster light in the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band (the filter where cluster members are brightest), keeping only the objects selected by the cluster-member colour\u2013colour cut (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>) and masking the rest. We then smooth the remaining light with a Gaussian kernel (\u03c3<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0=\u00a010\u00a0arcsec), providing a cleaner view of the light distribution. Comparing this distribution to the four-clump mass model ( Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, left), we find good agreement between the brightest points of the light map and the positions of the large-scale clumps. As expected, the southern cluster halo sits near the southern BCG, the combined northern cluster halo and bar surround the northern BCG, and the fourth clump sits on the eastern side of the crown. Even more promisingly, the orientation of the fourth mass clump is aligned with the distribution of the crown light, even though it is allowed to vary freely in the model. Assuming then that, at least to some degree, the presence of light traces the presence of mass, the agreement between the light map and mass model provides another argument in favour of the four-clump model.</p>                        <a id=\"88277423\" scrollto-destination=\"88277423\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ETSIZ9iFcYLTwEvQYc4neMbW~n~g2h8CcmbUxtuABqF6k3vn0DyiZ3Vj5iCHd8v5sWzZ614hlcn-YP0T3H1W3kI-gxpoaDpqSDmZnEAkhcXz-CWToGU8lDEHonRmGuj3GbHXGcCR9ors5GFyFfNjehQ5jqBoh3FdvK9SDhGZiHslfatGluFEKNakBDxZ3glr28dR0T5SkxEebolK2fcGfNn15SISx57CVXWJmb4VLjX0Jd6yuQNTmPBHCDqVaUUuhXEu0P3hJUdRrt8eY4z-CpKxUCXp8nu4bDQihBZsZvXf6MZQy00pgAeylQzWNQl3RqLYQKNnXLJmg7nbMV-o9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparisons between model mass clumps and two physical parameter maps. Left: the smoothed cluster light map. We see an agreement between the mass clump positions and the locations of the brightest cluster light. We also find a good agreement between the orientation of the light in the \u2018crown\u2019 and the fourth mass clump (DM4). Right: the X-ray gas map. We again see an agreement between the map and the large-scale clump positions, along with an agreement in shape and orientation of the X-ray gas contours (blue lines) and model mass contours (green lines). In both cases, the mass contours are the same as those presented in Fig.\u00a09. Taken together these two maps suggest that the bar (DM3) and the crown (DM4) are real features of the cluster, and not a simple case of overfitting the data.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277423/stx1079fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277423\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=EIaT0GUBFF8xp2yZd9vQf9KEWcJm3FAgZzm708tSVvkQJEDpODR-FXkfjawtAxyqjPCjz~XaAllSYKFHg7Ua1cBjf3ZufMME0hIVB-YQonsxQbTutuEIKCYBNU8toj~pP~4qMYg4Cj6mcwJrqp96aNNmtCVt1-LZqjrkOWB9Qlt0-6mRT7ET6WCJAMJ32E1l2j0jQeXaSOsWyc9kN8oPp8l9WRZUP67dBumDMlurqzDOF4gIZJ63cFPGtNf25RKw5wmNCYOPEQ~ywEF-7DByhZ~GqcfUa0iAHQsQiGLEEdqYXSAUeIq8bNzSj4~Aehcl~7Wq0TBpATW8wTNj-LuZ~Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277423&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between model mass clumps and two physical parameter maps. Left: the smoothed cluster light map. We see an agreement between the mass clump positions and the locations of the brightest cluster light. We also find a good agreement between the orientation of the light in the \u2018crown\u2019 and the fourth mass clump (DM4). Right: the X-ray gas map. We again see an agreement between the map and the large-scale clump positions, along with an agreement in shape and orientation of the X-ray gas contours (blue lines) and model mass contours (green lines). In both cases, the mass contours are the same as those presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. Taken together these two maps suggest that the bar (DM3) and the crown (DM4) are real features of the cluster, and not a simple case of overfitting the data.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ETSIZ9iFcYLTwEvQYc4neMbW~n~g2h8CcmbUxtuABqF6k3vn0DyiZ3Vj5iCHd8v5sWzZ614hlcn-YP0T3H1W3kI-gxpoaDpqSDmZnEAkhcXz-CWToGU8lDEHonRmGuj3GbHXGcCR9ors5GFyFfNjehQ5jqBoh3FdvK9SDhGZiHslfatGluFEKNakBDxZ3glr28dR0T5SkxEebolK2fcGfNn15SISx57CVXWJmb4VLjX0Jd6yuQNTmPBHCDqVaUUuhXEu0P3hJUdRrt8eY4z-CpKxUCXp8nu4bDQihBZsZvXf6MZQy00pgAeylQzWNQl3RqLYQKNnXLJmg7nbMV-o9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparisons between model mass clumps and two physical parameter maps. Left: the smoothed cluster light map. We see an agreement between the mass clump positions and the locations of the brightest cluster light. We also find a good agreement between the orientation of the light in the \u2018crown\u2019 and the fourth mass clump (DM4). Right: the X-ray gas map. We again see an agreement between the map and the large-scale clump positions, along with an agreement in shape and orientation of the X-ray gas contours (blue lines) and model mass contours (green lines). In both cases, the mass contours are the same as those presented in Fig.\u00a09. Taken together these two maps suggest that the bar (DM3) and the crown (DM4) are real features of the cluster, and not a simple case of overfitting the data.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277423/stx1079fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277423\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=EIaT0GUBFF8xp2yZd9vQf9KEWcJm3FAgZzm708tSVvkQJEDpODR-FXkfjawtAxyqjPCjz~XaAllSYKFHg7Ua1cBjf3ZufMME0hIVB-YQonsxQbTutuEIKCYBNU8toj~pP~4qMYg4Cj6mcwJrqp96aNNmtCVt1-LZqjrkOWB9Qlt0-6mRT7ET6WCJAMJ32E1l2j0jQeXaSOsWyc9kN8oPp8l9WRZUP67dBumDMlurqzDOF4gIZJ63cFPGtNf25RKw5wmNCYOPEQ~ywEF-7DByhZ~GqcfUa0iAHQsQiGLEEdqYXSAUeIq8bNzSj4~Aehcl~7Wq0TBpATW8wTNj-LuZ~Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277423&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between model mass clumps and two physical parameter maps. Left: the smoothed cluster light map. We see an agreement between the mass clump positions and the locations of the brightest cluster light. We also find a good agreement between the orientation of the light in the \u2018crown\u2019 and the fourth mass clump (DM4). Right: the X-ray gas map. We again see an agreement between the map and the large-scale clump positions, along with an agreement in shape and orientation of the X-ray gas contours (blue lines) and model mass contours (green lines). In both cases, the mass contours are the same as those presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. Taken together these two maps suggest that the bar (DM3) and the crown (DM4) are real features of the cluster, and not a simple case of overfitting the data.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we also look at the A370 X-ray gas profile, as the presence of hot X-ray gas is often used as a tracer of deep mass potentials. For this, we turn to publicly available, deep <em>Chandra</em> data: an 88 ks image of A370, observed using the using the Advanced CCD Imaging Spectrometer S-array (ACIS-S) camera (ID: 08700025, PI: G. Garmire). After smoothing the X-ray map using the <span class=\"monospace\">ASMOOTH</span> algorithm (Ebeling, White &amp; Rangarajan <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), we compare the smoothed X-ray map to the positions of the four-clump mass model components (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, right). While the results here are not as definitive as in the cluster-light case, we do still see a moderate agreement between the map and the clump positions. Generally, the X-ray contours are also slightly extended in the vicinity of the crown clump, again hinting at the presence of an additional potential well.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Focusing more closely on the X-ray contours, we can see that they follow a distinct box-like pattern, which is especially noticeable in the outskirts of the cluster. Interestingly, the mass contours in the four-clump model have a similar shape, largely driven by the overlap between the northern cluster halo and the central bar. Given the rough agreement between the X-ray and mass contours, it is possible that the best-fitting positions of the northern mass clumps are more than a simple degeneracy, but instead driven by physical parameters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thus, taken as a whole, the combination of physical and statistical evidence indicates that the additional mass clumps in the cluster centre and crown region are necessary components of the mass model. This suggests an even more complex mass distribution than previously thought, motivating future studies in this area.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=88277427 id=\"88277427\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Comparisons with other models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Thanks to the discovery of several new lensing constraints, our picture of the A370 mass distribution is beginning to evolve. While the addition of new mass clumps is the largest change, it is not the only difference. To get a better understanding of these changes and what they mean physically, we can compare our model to previous results. This is especially easy with the models presented by Johnson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), since they were both also generated with <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span>, using a similar set of parameters. On the whole, while the total mass of A370 remains largely unchanged between models, where the mass enclosed within a 500\u00a0kpc circular radius is \u223c8\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>14</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> in each case, the distribution of mass between various components does not. In particular, we find that the cluster halo associated with the southern BCG (DM1) is much rounder and more compact than either of the previous models, flattening the mass profile in this region. This is predominantly due to the number of radial, five-image systems seen near the southern cluster (Systems 7, 14 and 15), as a more elliptical mass distribution would break the symmetry and destroy the radial arcs. Conversely, the northern cluster halo (DM2) is more elliptical and tilted at a steeper angle away from north, though this is largely driven by model degeneracies between DM2 and the central bar component. Both cluster potentials are also considerably less massive in our model, which is another consequence of the bar. Finally, we note that our model favours a significantly larger <em>L</em>* galaxy velocity dispersion, placing more emphasis on localized substructure contributions to the total mass profile. A list of specific parameter differences can be seen in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> .</p>                        <a id=\"88277429\" scrollto-destination=\"88277429\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal -2.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN009\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN009\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Model Key \u2013 J14: Johnson et\u00a0al. -2.6}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN009\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN009\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Model Key \u2013 J14: Johnson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), R14: Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), L16: this work.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN010\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN010\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/88277429\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to specific model parameters, we can also compare the total mass properties of our model. For this exercise, we turn to the public models constructed for the HFF lens modelling initiative. In the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, we show the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve for our best-fitting model, compared to the magnification maps of three different HFF models: \u2018CATS\u2019, from the Clusters As TelescopeS team, (Co-PIs: J.P. Kneib and P. Natarajan), \u2018Sharon v.2\u2019 (PI: K. Sharon) and \u2018Zitrin-LTM\u2019 (PI: A. Zitrin). We select these models because they are constructed using only strong-lensing constraints, and because the resolution of their magnification maps at the core of the cluster is sufficiently high enough to compare their critical curves. In general, the shape of our curve largely traces the high-magnification regions in the other models, suggesting a broad agreement between our work and earlier studies. However, we do note that our curve has a boxier shape, due to the interaction between the northern cluster halo and the central bar and to the presence of the crown clump. Furthermore, the radial critical region (traced out by the internal orange line) is much larger in our model. This is again a result of the rounder, flatter mass distribution predicted by our model, and also highlights the increased area containing radial lensing constraints such as Systems 7, 14 and 15.</p>                        <a id=\"88277431\" scrollto-destination=\"88277431\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=CV0hMwanUdQIF1aKfp5VwDWDoApPQg5quOjmy07dTTFPpecinMRm2nGcWLmU1HQUjvGrIOogxrsdzkpyRmTke4CvQta4taeUg0as6L6Vbitih4cZQerJu7wN7jTyei4VBkPKSiKh0OjcOYYD1fSVABC7i4G2Q1nTZ9opNMW9FxUERToffhpos43-Xv21oiHEu2j2aqUVPePpcfwOQojP6nCsKg9FXIxF~OzV3c7w7QH42C9DGK~NQ2ZXLgU39V45NFIGgoOOYm6W7-zBJFuO75zo8iFFTEPv5JhhNRnre9I60FBvpsTB9a4P4GtoyX9MijzyGCI9a4KoPpRMBE-q-w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparisons between our best-fitting mass model and previous HFF models. Left: magnification maps of the CATS (blue), Sharon (green) and Zitrin-LTM (red) models, compared to the z\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve of our model (orange line). Areas of high magnification (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a020) appear as the coloured regions in each map. We see good agreement between our model and the others, but our model has a larger radial critical region (internal orange line) driven by the discovery of several radial lens systems. Additionally, our critical line has a boxier shape than the other models, due to the orientation of the northern cluster potential and the central bar (Table\u00a04). Right: radial surface mass density profile, using several HFF public models. Our model (orange dashed line) has a lower value at small radii, due to the radial caustic region. At\u00a0\u223c250\u00a0kpc, we see a distinct bump, which represents the additional mass clump in the crown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277431/stx1079fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277431\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=m-DXDMK3arSiHsTY4jAXu6xymDfS2pzhjrZQuNvmHhWXBo6dXTBvVyzRvNYSFJ3Lhg0HZ-ycmnroFTIfUSHC-ZhuqGi~HsBO1JWEdFre-Z~eMqTlG0NJ17fAHvjPYqgGi~FGQmQoPXQVqGYgtjWBTy4-MBnFzGs4F36JAImsDvS1WtFsUVSMWZp~N3xDhBJ6ZpGNrCkyNdU7qHA4wRoJqw7HeIqa33kwcPKttMBSm5RkFcXERCnOt~8YwSjHP7iUIhYFg~s0K~cwOZMVcN3iwW3zWFLiEfLYnCg0AWclxtoHIpjXGSHYrqIKDLWTU4WTZmZBF16Qxqt7MCLznx6gEA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277431&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between our best-fitting mass model and previous HFF models. Left: magnification maps of the CATS (blue), Sharon (green) and Zitrin-LTM (red) models, compared to the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve of our model (orange line). Areas of high magnification (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a020) appear as the coloured regions in each map. We see good agreement between our model and the others, but our model has a larger radial critical region (internal orange line) driven by the discovery of several radial lens systems. Additionally, our critical line has a boxier shape than the other models, due to the orientation of the northern cluster potential and the central bar (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). Right: radial surface mass density profile, using several HFF public models. Our model (orange dashed line) has a lower value at small radii, due to the radial caustic region. At\u00a0\u223c250\u00a0kpc, we see a distinct bump, which represents the additional mass clump in the crown.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=CV0hMwanUdQIF1aKfp5VwDWDoApPQg5quOjmy07dTTFPpecinMRm2nGcWLmU1HQUjvGrIOogxrsdzkpyRmTke4CvQta4taeUg0as6L6Vbitih4cZQerJu7wN7jTyei4VBkPKSiKh0OjcOYYD1fSVABC7i4G2Q1nTZ9opNMW9FxUERToffhpos43-Xv21oiHEu2j2aqUVPePpcfwOQojP6nCsKg9FXIxF~OzV3c7w7QH42C9DGK~NQ2ZXLgU39V45NFIGgoOOYm6W7-zBJFuO75zo8iFFTEPv5JhhNRnre9I60FBvpsTB9a4P4GtoyX9MijzyGCI9a4KoPpRMBE-q-w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparisons between our best-fitting mass model and previous HFF models. Left: magnification maps of the CATS (blue), Sharon (green) and Zitrin-LTM (red) models, compared to the z\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve of our model (orange line). Areas of high magnification (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a020) appear as the coloured regions in each map. We see good agreement between our model and the others, but our model has a larger radial critical region (internal orange line) driven by the discovery of several radial lens systems. Additionally, our critical line has a boxier shape than the other models, due to the orientation of the northern cluster potential and the central bar (Table\u00a04). Right: radial surface mass density profile, using several HFF public models. Our model (orange dashed line) has a lower value at small radii, due to the radial caustic region. At\u00a0\u223c250\u00a0kpc, we see a distinct bump, which represents the additional mass clump in the crown.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277431/stx1079fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277431\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=m-DXDMK3arSiHsTY4jAXu6xymDfS2pzhjrZQuNvmHhWXBo6dXTBvVyzRvNYSFJ3Lhg0HZ-ycmnroFTIfUSHC-ZhuqGi~HsBO1JWEdFre-Z~eMqTlG0NJ17fAHvjPYqgGi~FGQmQoPXQVqGYgtjWBTy4-MBnFzGs4F36JAImsDvS1WtFsUVSMWZp~N3xDhBJ6ZpGNrCkyNdU7qHA4wRoJqw7HeIqa33kwcPKttMBSm5RkFcXERCnOt~8YwSjHP7iUIhYFg~s0K~cwOZMVcN3iwW3zWFLiEfLYnCg0AWclxtoHIpjXGSHYrqIKDLWTU4WTZmZBF16Qxqt7MCLznx6gEA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277431&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparisons between our best-fitting mass model and previous HFF models. Left: magnification maps of the CATS (blue), Sharon (green) and Zitrin-LTM (red) models, compared to the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve of our model (orange line). Areas of high magnification (\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a020) appear as the coloured regions in each map. We see good agreement between our model and the others, but our model has a larger radial critical region (internal orange line) driven by the discovery of several radial lens systems. Additionally, our critical line has a boxier shape than the other models, due to the orientation of the northern cluster potential and the central bar (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). Right: radial surface mass density profile, using several HFF public models. Our model (orange dashed line) has a lower value at small radii, due to the radial caustic region. At\u00a0\u223c250\u00a0kpc, we see a distinct bump, which represents the additional mass clump in the crown.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">These features can also be seen in the right-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, where we show the radial surface mass density profile for several models (including Diego et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), starting from a point roughly centred between the two BCGs (\u03b1\u00a0=\u00a0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2^{\\rm h}{}39^{\\rm m}{}52{^{\\rm s}_{.}}937$|\u2060</span>, \u03b4\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121\u00b0 34<sup>\u0384</sup> 37<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>003). At small radii (&lt;100\u00a0kpc), our mass profile is lower than several others, since this region covers the flatter core responsible for the extended radial critical curve. On the other hand, our model profile is slightly higher than the others between 200 and 300\u00a0kpc, due to the crown mass clump.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Of course, important spatial information is lost when the mass map is radially averaged, so it is important to look for differences in the full 2D mass distribution, as well. For this test, we compare our four-clump model to the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), which is also generated from the HFF data, but constructed in a completely independent way, reducing potential sources of unknown bias. In that work, the driver model is constructed to recreate the positions of 10 very secure lens systems, including seven systems identified here (Systems 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7 and 9). Unlike our purely parametric approach, this model uses a broad grid of 2D Gaussians to characterize the smooth, cluster-scale mass distribution, along with a compact light-traces-mass component for bright galaxies (similar to our own method). To make the comparison, we subtract the free-form model's mass density map from our own map, measuring relative differences on a pixel-by-pixel basis. The results can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. Overall, we do see differences between the two approaches: the Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) model is generally more concentrated and slightly rounder. Our parametric approach shows a noticeable overdensity in the vicinity of the crown, due to the crown mass clump (DM4) in the east, and the extension of the northern cluster clump and the central bar (DM2 and DM3, respectively) in the north-west. The parametric model also has a larger fraction of total mass in the outskirts of the cluster, which is also seen in the radial profile presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. While model differences can be large at large radii \u2013 the parametric model is roughly twice as dense as the free-form model at the edges of the map \u2013 we note that the absolute mass density values at these distances are very small (\u223c10<sup>8</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0kpc<sup>\u22122</sup>) and contribute a negligible amount to the total mass budget. Conversely, the relative differences near the cluster centre are typically less than 10 per\u00a0cent, resulting in an overall good agreement between the two models.</p>                        <a id=\"88277434\" scrollto-destination=\"88277434\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ytDNWS1tDzPNd3HcnJO0qF2L4ineKC~e2bryuM3OzZNCi3IabYn-ZdOEgjiYeQRnfKYuz82wMAGlDD4c8FHzHflwIbepqLkVWRq-b~g9O4J~v~4rsVjdhgUhuBYFTql6Yfa4RK5dUO3aJ2ziaJFWMPnASUiTnQvu1a8DaGEIldiUWJ~YeeTMkRXMI9wOkRjGXeWmhUyLrs-mrMWzHeMCR7hYa0QoNuD1EzGcKKQm2KR9k2sBLfh-7AXiG2pdmt5jDj0KQ0GRzdX9x0I9zlV6xrZofFpn3IqHTLL4r6BxAbmJOhuc0~asKJiAdFjpp95s2EyKdjm5RhrX6ZcgZjljag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residual mass density map between our best parametric model and the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (2016). In this plot, red represents an overdensity in the parametric model, while blue represents an overdensity in the free-form case. Although there are differences in the spatial distributions of the models, the typical variation is less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent. We note that the largest deviations appear in the cluster outskirts, where the absolute mass density is small. As a result, the total mass is roughly the same in both cases.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277434/stx1079fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277434\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=PZoMOlnTWstH4WFyHWEkpUvRGRqJ2wfrdonaXeX1S3EnZY7c1U1SHjJByo-qBY2XiobOIGpsJ7PGq~ge-kK6VKRPZtNWE0VpVuh~8~ReyrTSs~SJBve2v1N0fvJ87UKxetXIe4AH01u6T6FYH9r1frXupo4PvAtXdBY18-ijUJP18XD3l8dBwskQplE2NfjcKJpikYPrEvYT600R0LwkjSFi-nqCuqbA9LwfB7W802rjN7PcDYAkQaLHoSdp0dKB13Tfa31hDiYCC01YTkEAPhVHMFINfY10wKaKzGu8ptWPg-sAB0yllgI3ea7Tu344MNRRc8IJ9x06hwFS4qLdHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277434&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residual mass density map between our best parametric model and the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In this plot, red represents an overdensity in the parametric model, while blue represents an overdensity in the free-form case. Although there are differences in the spatial distributions of the models, the typical variation is less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent. We note that the largest deviations appear in the cluster outskirts, where the absolute mass density is small. As a result, the total mass is roughly the same in both cases.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=ytDNWS1tDzPNd3HcnJO0qF2L4ineKC~e2bryuM3OzZNCi3IabYn-ZdOEgjiYeQRnfKYuz82wMAGlDD4c8FHzHflwIbepqLkVWRq-b~g9O4J~v~4rsVjdhgUhuBYFTql6Yfa4RK5dUO3aJ2ziaJFWMPnASUiTnQvu1a8DaGEIldiUWJ~YeeTMkRXMI9wOkRjGXeWmhUyLrs-mrMWzHeMCR7hYa0QoNuD1EzGcKKQm2KR9k2sBLfh-7AXiG2pdmt5jDj0KQ0GRzdX9x0I9zlV6xrZofFpn3IqHTLL4r6BxAbmJOhuc0~asKJiAdFjpp95s2EyKdjm5RhrX6ZcgZjljag__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residual mass density map between our best parametric model and the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (2016). In this plot, red represents an overdensity in the parametric model, while blue represents an overdensity in the free-form case. Although there are differences in the spatial distributions of the models, the typical variation is less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent. We note that the largest deviations appear in the cluster outskirts, where the absolute mass density is small. As a result, the total mass is roughly the same in both cases.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277434/stx1079fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277434\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=PZoMOlnTWstH4WFyHWEkpUvRGRqJ2wfrdonaXeX1S3EnZY7c1U1SHjJByo-qBY2XiobOIGpsJ7PGq~ge-kK6VKRPZtNWE0VpVuh~8~ReyrTSs~SJBve2v1N0fvJ87UKxetXIe4AH01u6T6FYH9r1frXupo4PvAtXdBY18-ijUJP18XD3l8dBwskQplE2NfjcKJpikYPrEvYT600R0LwkjSFi-nqCuqbA9LwfB7W802rjN7PcDYAkQaLHoSdp0dKB13Tfa31hDiYCC01YTkEAPhVHMFINfY10wKaKzGu8ptWPg-sAB0yllgI3ea7Tu344MNRRc8IJ9x06hwFS4qLdHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277434&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residual mass density map between our best parametric model and the free-form \u2018driver\u2019 model presented in Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In this plot, red represents an overdensity in the parametric model, while blue represents an overdensity in the free-form case. Although there are differences in the spatial distributions of the models, the typical variation is less than 10\u00a0per\u00a0cent. We note that the largest deviations appear in the cluster outskirts, where the absolute mass density is small. As a result, the total mass is roughly the same in both cases.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we can compare our model (and all models) of A370 to other clusters in the HFF programme. The combined rms error for our best-fitting model (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.94\u00a0arcsec) is higher than the error presented in Johnson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.82\u00a0arcsec), comparable to the error in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.93\u00a0arcsec), and smaller than the error presented in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 1.76\u00a0arcsec). However all of these rms values are larger than the best-fitting models of most other HFF clusters, such as MACS 0416 (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.6\u00a0arcsec; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) or Abell 2744 (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 0.7\u00a0arcsec; Jauzac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Instead, while not as large, our rms is more similar to MACS 0717 (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> = 1.9\u00a0arcsec; Limousin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Like MACS 0717, A370 is a complex cluster, with several interacting mass components covering a large field of view. In fact, the A370 \u2018multiple-image zone\u2019 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>), the region predicted to contain all multiple images out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a010), is the second largest of all of the Frontier Fields, behind only MACS 0717. Given the similarities, it is therefore unsurprising that the typical rms is also high.</p>                        <a id=\"88277436\" scrollto-destination=\"88277436\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=AC~zlXcyT3XFHZ8Xuhep1AZy229hdgSKJi8V75166LDYbvDMA28AQlJx6eRX1QSD8B4GcCYNiQEbugj6sXBQlsH0iuoin9lpR8WSFOHTtQpjQzlkxo~1quMIODDp2qXc0H58vymQgoOAr67jH2Sphl5k8shy8IYjLyUtApSeXb~Fg2MC1VRzh416OwfN5yoIska0oYSiijXIosLoVjNv62c19ksqzMhe5awFTq-y10wtFfGJ1hOMO-5gtHFIGHLDtN~3~xfPYmrw~Svw5gBDPWi~xNdNhchzE9uLa8VF8wurbB0YJ-2tyTc08yPDFAepeoFAYlq0GBsKnsivfzPGFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Extent of the \u2018multi-image zone\u2019 (yellow curve) as predicted by the best A370 mass model. This region represents the area that encloses all expected multiple images out to high redshift (z\u00a0=\u00a010). The MUSE data footprint (white square) is again included for reference, and is considerably smaller than the multi-image zone. Additionally, three critical curves are displayed, highlighting lines of high magnification for three redshifts: z\u00a0=\u00a01 (cyan), z\u00a0=\u00a03 (green) and z\u00a0=\u00a09 (red). These lines are heavily clustered around the BCGs and the northern galaxy crown (noted by the dashed contour). Finally, all image constraints used in the model are shown as magenta circles.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277436/stx1079fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277436\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=wtQnyEMBoRVLBUE9oNIanzzRmgPzVIs~KJB3wUvCOAdMOouGUcVOfrnUN9~i2gVG6jb4Zm7AzpQkZ8IdkT-tB-6Czq1hXcspxDwpqDv-N6d8R9DGEKK7MndJVGf1WRK~njbvS5hFE0qFAK9hqUzavEnSzZzg7Qbyc92l0yVQ3W3TSastDljnyij1rmBV1l8bPhzJJ0ASNOIrrQ8wGEIA~uvx15Ay9YNMMdIGX15eRZTUSJlZTe7RXpUK6Z0lqI8jluGWK64KW46hU65FivjTssYp84RfuDFNws~FH4Wb8-F5N85CJ70BPPFNxtLHPtxmvrSLZznkwY7oJvsmPuBvlQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277436&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Extent of the \u2018multi-image zone\u2019 (yellow curve) as predicted by the best A370 mass model. This region represents the area that encloses all expected multiple images out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a010). The MUSE data footprint (white square) is again included for reference, and is considerably smaller than the multi-image zone. Additionally, three critical curves are displayed, highlighting lines of high magnification for three redshifts: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 (cyan), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03 (green) and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09 (red). These lines are heavily clustered around the BCGs and the northern galaxy crown (noted by the dashed contour). Finally, all image constraints used in the model are shown as magenta circles.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/m_stx1079fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&amp;Signature=AC~zlXcyT3XFHZ8Xuhep1AZy229hdgSKJi8V75166LDYbvDMA28AQlJx6eRX1QSD8B4GcCYNiQEbugj6sXBQlsH0iuoin9lpR8WSFOHTtQpjQzlkxo~1quMIODDp2qXc0H58vymQgoOAr67jH2Sphl5k8shy8IYjLyUtApSeXb~Fg2MC1VRzh416OwfN5yoIska0oYSiijXIosLoVjNv62c19ksqzMhe5awFTq-y10wtFfGJ1hOMO-5gtHFIGHLDtN~3~xfPYmrw~Svw5gBDPWi~xNdNhchzE9uLa8VF8wurbB0YJ-2tyTc08yPDFAepeoFAYlq0GBsKnsivfzPGFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Extent of the \u2018multi-image zone\u2019 (yellow curve) as predicted by the best A370 mass model. This region represents the area that encloses all expected multiple images out to high redshift (z\u00a0=\u00a010). The MUSE data footprint (white square) is again included for reference, and is considerably smaller than the multi-image zone. Additionally, three critical curves are displayed, highlighting lines of high magnification for three redshifts: z\u00a0=\u00a01 (cyan), z\u00a0=\u00a03 (green) and z\u00a0=\u00a09 (red). These lines are heavily clustered around the BCGs and the northern galaxy crown (noted by the dashed contour). Finally, all image constraints used in the model are shown as magenta circles.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/88277436/stx1079fig13.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"88277436\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/469/4/10.1093_mnras_stx1079/2/stx1079fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639263387&Signature=wtQnyEMBoRVLBUE9oNIanzzRmgPzVIs~KJB3wUvCOAdMOouGUcVOfrnUN9~i2gVG6jb4Zm7AzpQkZ8IdkT-tB-6Czq1hXcspxDwpqDv-N6d8R9DGEKK7MndJVGf1WRK~njbvS5hFE0qFAK9hqUzavEnSzZzg7Qbyc92l0yVQ3W3TSastDljnyij1rmBV1l8bPhzJJ0ASNOIrrQ8wGEIA~uvx15Ay9YNMMdIGX15eRZTUSJlZTe7RXpUK6Z0lqI8jluGWK64KW46hU65FivjTssYp84RfuDFNws~FH4Wb8-F5N85CJ70BPPFNxtLHPtxmvrSLZznkwY7oJvsmPuBvlQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=88277436&ar=3800685&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx1079fig13.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Extent of the \u2018multi-image zone\u2019 (yellow curve) as predicted by the best A370 mass model. This region represents the area that encloses all expected multiple images out to high redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a010). The MUSE data footprint (white square) is again included for reference, and is considerably smaller than the multi-image zone. Additionally, three critical curves are displayed, highlighting lines of high magnification for three redshifts: <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 (cyan), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03 (green) and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09 (red). These lines are heavily clustered around the BCGs and the northern galaxy crown (noted by the dashed contour). Finally, all image constraints used in the model are shown as magenta circles.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To reduce the total rms further, we need to explore the other areas of the cluster with MUSE. This will help to refine the model even more and allow us to test whether or not our current interpretation is correct. In particular, the crown mass clump may only be a temporary solution; future data may require additional large-scale haloes, or even suggest an alternative to the crown. We cannot be sure of this until we have additional constraints in the north. Fortunately, such a survey is currently underway (PI: F. Bauer), and the results of this study will be the topic of a future paper.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277438 id=\"88277438\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we have presented a new mass model for the A370 cluster, taking advantage of deep HFF imaging and new MUSE spectroscopy. Our main conclusions are as follows. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a MUSE-based redshift catalogue for A370, consisting of 120 secure redshifts (\u03b4<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.1\u2009per\u2009cent), including 34 multiply imaged background objects (comprising 15 unique systems), 13 singly imaged background galaxies, 56 cluster members, 13 foreground galaxies and 4 stars.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Together, HFF and MUSE data are a powerful combination, greatly improving our ability to construct lens models. The MUSE spectroscopy is particularly valuable for this work, as it can be used to blindly identify new lensing constraints without selecting a specific redshift range.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">After constructing a mass model with the new multiply imaged constraints, we find two key differences with previous work. <ol class=\"number\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2003\u2003\u2002(1) A central core that is flatter and less massive due to an \u2003increase in radial lensing systems.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2003\u2003\u2002(2) The need for additional large-scale mass clumps (\u2018the bar\u2019 \u2003and \u2018the crown\u2019) to better fit lensing constraints in the\u00a0north of \u2003the cluster.</p></li></ol></p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A lack of model constraints in the north makes accurate comparisons difficult. We will need more MUSE data, covering a larger area of the A370 cluster to discriminate between possible interpretations. These data are currently being taken, and will be the subject of an upcoming paper.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additionally, our model can be used as a guide for upcoming observations, as high-magnification regions in our models (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>) should be ideal places to look for new, magnified high-redshift galaxies. With new MUSE spectroscopy on the way, the A370 cluster should continue to provide a wealth of new information in the future.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=88277441 id=\"88277441\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgments</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors wish to thank the anonymous referee for providing several helpful comments and suggestions to improve the manuscript. DJL thanks Jose M. Diego for providing a mass density map of his \u2018driver\u2019 model, which was useful for the quantitative comparisons in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>. DJL, JR, BC, GM, VP and JM acknowledge support from the European Research Council (ERC) starting grant 336736-CALENDS. This work has been carried out thanks to the support of the Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR) FOGHAR (ANR-13-BS05-0010-02) and the Origines Constituants et EVolution de l'Univers (OCEVU) Labex (ANR-11-LABX-0060). LW acknowledges support by the Competitive Fund of the Leibniz Association through grant SAW-2015-AIP-2. Some of the data presented in this paper were obtained from the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST) at the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI). STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span data-legacy-id=\"bib8\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib8\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib8\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div M. D.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">1999a</div>, <div class=\"source \">A&amp;A</div>, <div class=\"volume\">347</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">21</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\">\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib9\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"bib9\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib9\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib9\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib9\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"bib9\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">B\u00e9zecourt</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">J.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Soucail</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">G.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Ellis</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R. </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n</body>\r\n</html>\r\n\r\n", "Status": "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": " class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to specific model parameters, we can also compare the total mass properties of our model. For this exercise, we turn to the public models constructed for the HFF lens modelling initiative. In the left-hand panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, we show the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02 critical curve for our best-fitting model, compared to the magnification maps of three different HFF models: \u2018CATS\u2019, from the Clusters As TelescopeS team, (Co-PIs: J.P. Kneib and P. Natarajan), \u2018Sharon v.2\u2019 (PI: K. Sharon) and \u2018Zitrin-LTM\u2019 (PI: A. Zitrin). We select these models because they are constructed using only strong-lensing constraints, and because the resolution of their magnification maps at the core of the cluster is sufficiently high enough to compare their critical curves. In general, the shape of our curve largely traces the high-magnification regions in the other models, suggesting a broad agreement between our work and earlier studies. However, we do note that our curve has a boxier shape, due to the interaction between the northern cluster halo and the central bar and to the presence of the crown clump. Furthermore, the radial critical region (traced out by the internal orange line) is much larger in our model. This is again a result of the rounder, flatter mass distribution predicted by our model, and also highlights the increased area containing radial lensing constraints such as Systems 7, 14 and 15."}, class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Images labelled with an asterisk (*) fall outside of the MUSE cube and do not have secure redshifts. We identify them in the HFF data, using the A370 mass model as a guide.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Images in italics are predicted by the model, but no suitable counterimage is seen in the <em>HST</em> data. We do not include these images as model constraints, but we present them here for completeness. Image 16.2, which is in the MUSE field of view but predicted to fall behind a bright cluster galaxy, is also included here, since it is undetected in MUSE.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Redshifts enclosed in braces ({}) are fit by the model as free parameters. The fit range is given in the \u2018<em>z</em> range\u2019 column.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Redshifts for these systems are taken from Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span>2016).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Images labelled with an asterisk (*) fall outside of the MUSE cube and do not have secure redshifts. We identify them in the HFF data, using the A370 mass model as a guide.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Images in italics are predicted by the model, but no suitable counterimage is seen in the <em>HST</em> data. We do not include these images as model constraints, but we present them here for completeness. Image 16.2, which is in the MUSE field of view but predicted to fall behind a bright cluster galaxy, is also included here, since it is undetected in MUSE.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Redshifts enclosed in braces ({}) are fit by the model as free parameters. The fit range is given in the \u2018<em>z</em> range\u2019 column.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Redshifts for these systems are taken from Diego et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span>2016).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn                     });\r\n                    }\r\n                });\r\n\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlspage\", \"88277429\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().setTargeting(\"jnlsurl\", \"view-large/88277429\");\r\n                googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();\r\n                googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();\r\n                    googletag.enableServices();\r\n            });\r\n        </script>\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    <script>\r\n        var oupcookiepolicy_siteid =
